1075.output: ### Discussion Identification of prognostic biomarkers for predicting the progression of oral squamous cell carcinoma via integrative analysis of transcriptome and miRNA-targets network. Although oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) patients with the same clinical presentation can have dramatically different recurrence and survival outcomes. Hence, an exploration of the molecular mechanism of this disease progression will be beneficial to the survival and treatment outcome of such patients. In this study, integrated bioinformatics analysis was applied to the selection of prognostic molecules associated with the progression of OSCC. First, gene expression data of OSCC patients were collected and differentially expressed genes (DEGs) were obtained via the Wilcoxon signed-rank test based on three expression profiles for gene expression profiling of the OSCC process. Subsequently, a microRNA (miRNA)-targets network was built based on the differentially expressed miRNAs (DEMs) and DEGs. Thereafter, key modules in the network were identified by the WGCNA. Four hub genes and 56 miRNA-mRNA regulatory pairs in the blue and yellow modules that are most closely related to the OSCC progression were retained by the analysis of the KEGG pathway, GO annotation, and literatures about the genes. Finally, we experimentally demonstrated that CAV1 is an important molecule among the genes that influence the malignant degree of OSCC. This study will provide a new perspective and basis for the molecular mechanism of the OSCC process. Since only RNA molecules produced from viral genomes present in the liver can potentially be secreted in the bloodstream (i.e., genomes of different genotypes, subtypes, and quasispecies), we have examined the intrahost diversity of HCV populations. This study aimed to compare the diversity of viral populations in the liver of chronically infected hemodialysis patients with the heterogeneity found in patients of the same hemodialysis centers but chronically infected and spontaneously cleared infections. A total of 54 hemodialysis patients were selected, including three patients with spontaneously cleared infections and 51 patients chronically infected with a subgenomic HCV RNA concentration of >10 copies/ml. The viral populations in the liver of the patients with cleared infections were more than twice as heterogeneous as those found in the chronic patients. ## INST: Sensitivity analysis

# Sensitivity analysis

Sensitivity analysis involves re-evaluating how sensitive the output of a program is to changes in its input, by determining the effect of each input parameter on a particular output. It tests the validity, usefulness, robustness, uncertainty, and plausibility of the results generated by a program.

There are two major kinds of sensitivity analyses: one-at-a-time sensitivity analysis and global sensitivity analysis
- One-at-a-time sensitivity analysis involves running the main program with each potential input parameter varied over a particular range (e.g., from 0 to 250) or with a single value varied 10 or 100 times. The results are then compared with the original results to determine the relative sensitivity of the program to such variations.
- Global sensitivity analysis involves varying all of the program's parameters simultaneously by a certain percentage. This analysis can be used, for example, to evaluate how sensitive the model is to variations in its design or assumptions.

<EOD> A comparative evaluation of marginal adaptation of dentin bonding agents

Aims:The aim of this study was to evaluate the microleakage and marginal adaptation between dentin of human tooth and bonding agents. Materials and Methods: Sixty intact teeth were used in this investigation. After tooth preparation, the cavity floor was finished with diamond fissure bur and the exposed dentin was etched for 15 seconds. Three different bonding agents: Single bond, Syntac, and Enforce were used for placing composite resin. Cylinders were then made with composites in a mold and subjected to thermocycling. The buccal and lingual sections of each tooth were prepared with buccolingual cross-sections. Then the teeth were placed in 37°C distilled water and were sectioned under light microscope after 24 hours. Microleakage was scored and microscopically evaluated. Results: Bucco-lingual and mesio-distal section showed that all three groups were leakage free at the proximal margins. However, there was significant difference in microleakage of teeth restored with Adper and Single bond (P < 0.05). No significant difference was noted in microleakage of teeth restored with Adper and Syntac and also teeth restored with Syntac and Enforce. Conclusion: All bonding agents resulted in leakage-free margin and Adper was least leakage and best adaptation than the other two bonding agents.

L ow fidelity of dentin bonding agents has remained a problem because the bonded interface is prone to hydrolytic and mechanical degradation. <EOD> A review on the use of acupuncture in chronic prostatitis treatment: its effectiveness and potential mechanism

The National Institute of Health (NIH) issued the consensus statement for chronic prostatitis (CP) in 2000. According to the consensus document, no treatment for prostatitis has any "established" efficacy. Although α-blockers, antibiotics, phytotherapy agents such as sildenafil, etc. have been extensively tested in clinical trials, it is not clear whether these drugs really have therapeutic effect on CP. Recently, more and more reports were found to prove that acupuncture therapy is effective in relieving prostatitis symptoms. However, the specific mechanism of acupuncture therapy still is unclear, the specific treatment regimen has not been unified. It is difficult to summarize the efficacy of acupuncture therapy simply by analyzing these articles. Therefore, this article will give a brief review on CP and research progress of acupuncture on CP in recent years. And, this article will also discuss the potential mechanism and the unified program of acupuncture on CP. This article provides a comprehensive review of acupuncture on CP for clinical therapists who are involved in CP treatment in order to make a balanced judgment on the efficacy of acupuncture in CP patients and to make a wise choice of acupuncture program for the clinical practice.

Discussion:

Evaluation

We observe whether the assessment of eligibility is consistent with the real status. If so, we check if the model makes correct prediction. If so, congrats. Otherwise, we should think why we get an incorrect prediction and which factors cause the assessment of eligibility to differ from the real status.

Limitations & Outlook

  1. This model is trained in a single hospital, which does not accurately reflect the diversity of the real world.
  2. To improve the clinical decision-making model, we try to reduce the number of features. We consider it effective to reduce the number of high-dimensional continuous features, that is, the numerical features in the clinical note, as dimensionality reduction methods such as , , and for continuous features may be good ideas. Moreover, we can use feature sets with smaller numbers of features by excluding features not related to the assessment of eligibility. For the ordinal features, we can use information gain for discretized features, which is a typical clustering method for feature selection. By excluding the features that often occur but that are not related to the assessment of eligibility, we can reduce the length of the feature set we need to handle. In addition, even for the categorical features, 's information gain method is a representative method. By excluding features related to the assessment of eligibility, we can reduce the number of features and the computation cost.

Background:The incidence of diabetes mellitus (DM) is increasing and nowadays it is a serious public health challenge. Because of the high level of immunodepression in diabetic patients, it is supposed that patients with diabetes have a relatively higher risk of contracting tetanus infection. However, the results are not conclusive and there are inconsistencies among these studies. Therefore, a pooled analysis from all relevant studies was carried out to examine whether or not diabetes mellitus is a predisposing factor for tetanus infection among humans. Methods: Two reviewers independently selected all case-control or cohort studies assessing tetanus risk in patients with diabetes mellitus compared to healthy subjects. A random-effects meta-analysis was used to calculate the pooled odds ratios (OR). I-square and a p-value were used to detect significant heterogeneity. Subgroup, meta-regression analyses and sensitivity analysis were performed in order to find explanations for the heterogeneity. A funnel plot was used to estimate publication bias. # Related Work 
This is the 21st track of the IEEE Conference on Empirical Software Engineering. It is the inaugural event in this series of conferences. It is organized by ESE members of the IEEE Technical Computing Council. Since 2006, the IEEE has been promoting a change from the traditional view of empirical studies as purely quantitative, with a bias toward large scale, to the emerging view of empirical software engineering (ESE) research and practice as quantitative and qualitative.
We invite submissions from a broad range of topics including, but not limited to: software engineering topics, design, architecture, process, and management; quantitative and qualitative analysis of software artifacts and related artifacts, such as program source code, configuration files, and data-processing systems; social and human aspects of software engineering development; and methods for training and education in software engineering

# About the Track Chairs 
The following people will serve as the 2019 IEEE International Conference on Empirical Software Engineering (ESE) Track Chairs.
 - Tom Van Der Mei, University of Leuven, Belgium
 - Svetlana Yakovlev, Moscow State University, Russia

# Submissions 

We use double-blind reviewing to ensure the quality and fairness of decisions. Thus, authors are required to keep the names of program committee members and reviewers anonymous during the review process. After submission, the IEEE Conferences Publication Assistant will assign each submission an anonymous and unique electronic manuscript number (EAN). The Program Committee will consider each submission by its EAN throughout the review process. During the revision process, authors will be required to resubmit their papers by retyping those pages, replacing the EAN.

Please make sure that your submission complies fully with the following instructions before you submit. Failure to follow these guidelines will result in your submission being returned.

<EOD> .
Dentists' occupational diseases remain rare with few cases reported by scientific publications. They may nonetheless have more incidence than generally recognized and lead to long periods of disability. There is little information about their evolution and management. The objective of the study was to collect dentists' occupational diseases data which appeared as diagnosis in their medical file. We conducted a retrospective study of the disease evolutions and the redeployment of dentists on the French labour market. In a 12-months study period, medical files of 1,074 dentists were retrospectively studied. A total of 45 dentists (4.2% ) were sick-listed and diagnosed as an occupational disease. Twelve were sick-listed by an occupational disease leading to permanent disability. Of the 45 sick-listed dentists 25 were redeployed by the National Insurance System. Of the 24 dentists remaining on the labour market and still sick-listed, 18 were on sick leave. Fifty-three percent were women. Forty-five percent of the dentists had no experience on the labour market, 14.3% had more than 10 years of experience. The median of the time needed to be on sick leave was 24 months. The most diseases were "Diseases and disorders of the musculoskeletal system", "Others", "Diseases and disorders of the circulatory system". Dental occupational disease is little or not recognized by society. <EOD> A novel technique using the bull-eye technique for the repair of recurrent or persistent pterygium

A b s t r a c t Purpose: To describe a novel technique that uses a bull's-eye design pattern, by marking the pterygium with a small bull's-eye pattern and then removing all the excised tissues, to reduce the risk of recurrence of pterygium. Methods: A total of 86 eyes of 86 patients who underwent pterygium surgeries for recurrences and/or persistent pterygium were enrolled. Patients were examined at 1, 3, 6, and 12 months postoperatively. Recurrences were observed and evaluated by the masked surgeon. Results: The mean follow-up period was 24.8 ± 19.0 months (range, 12 to 60 months). Postoperative corneal abrasions occurred in 9.4% of the patients. A recurrent pterygium occurred in 13 (15.8%) patients, and the mean recurrence-free period was 8.4 ± 10.9 months (range, 1 to 48 months). The recurrent pterygium was treated by a simple pterygium excision in ten patients (22.7%). Conclusions: Our study demonstrated that a pterygium excision using the bull-eye technique is safe and results in a higher postoperative recurrence-free period compared to simple pterygium excision. Based on our results, we suggest that the bull-eye technique is a good surgical choice for treatment of recurrent or persistent pterygium.

# Introduction
Pterygium is a disorder found at the junction of the bulbar conjunctiva and corneal limbus with an inflammatory tissue process, which is characterized by neovascularization and fibrosis. Pterygium is a prevalent disorder, found in 2.1-30.6% of the global populace, and it is common throughout all ages, ethnicities, and geological areas [bib_ref]  Epidemiology and risk factors

(1) POSITION_OF_TRACTOR 
- You should first transform it into a numeric vector.
- Then, calculate the position score for each patient by concatenating the five numerical vectors.
- For the last patient, you do not have complete information. Hence make sure that you do not calculate the score, and move on to the next patient. Remember, the score should range from 0 to 2.
- Next, the average score, ∑(score/5), will be your final score for the clinical trial. The score of a position will be affected based on the length of the patient note.

# Introduction
Pig kidney dipeptidyl peptidase I (DPP I) is a multifunctional glycoprotein with a molecular mass of about 130 KDa. Native DPP I occurs as a homodimer or, like the enzymes of DPP IV family, as a non-covalently linked heterotetramer. DPP I is one of five mammalian serine peptidases that can split dipeptides from the N-terminus of polypeptides. It is secreted from the kidney into the circulation and acts as a regulator of many biological processes. It influences, among others, renal proximal tubular function, platelet aggregation, insulin biosynthesisand blood pressure.
DPP I is a glycoprotein containing 24 potential N-glycosylation sites; only eight of them have been reported to be occupied. The enzyme contains a single N-glycan on the carbohydrate recognition domain (CRD). The N-glycan chain is a heterogeneous mixture, a complex type chitosaccharide. It has the following composition: Man 8 (GlcNAc 3 Man 9 GlcNAc 2 )-GlcNAc(Gal 1 GalNAc) (DPP1-G1) or Gal (GlcNAc 3 Man 9 GlcNAc 2 )-GalNA (GlcNAc(Man 3 Gal 1 GlcNAc 2 )) (DPP1-G2). The glycoprotein is expressed by human, rabbit, horse and many other mammals. The enzyme isolated from pigs' kidneys has been found to be the major formand is the model enzyme used in the studies of enzymatic activity.
Deglycanation of glycoproteins by microbial enzymes was shown to be a promising tool in therapeutics and di

On a surgical side, there is a trend in postgraduate training programs to have trainees perform the procedure more before a trainer takes over. In terms of basic training, there are numerous teaching techniques available, such as the use of videos, lectures or didactic sessions. In terms of surgical training in which a procedure is performed on a model or phantom, there are also several options available. <EOD> Development and Validation of a Quantitative Enrichment Assay for Bacteria in Urine Using a 16S Real-Time PCR Assay
Real-time PCR assays based on the 16S rRNA gene have been established as rapid and quantitative methods to detect and enumerate bacteria. The objective of this study was to evaluate the performance of real-time PCR when applied for detection and quantification of Escherichia coli in the urine samples obtained from patients with urinary tract infection (UTI). To that end, we used 16 real-time PCRs assays in conventional and quantitative modes, as well as a novel single tube technique called rapid real-time (rrt). The E. coli assays were evaluated with a spiked synthetic control in order to validate the results of these three methods and to validate the standard curve used in rrt. Three types of samples were evaluated: urine samples with 105 CFU mL−1 of E. coli as a pure culture, urine samples spiked with 1 × 102 CFU mL−1, and clinical urine samples with >105 CFU mL−1 of E. coli. The results obtained were directly comparable between the real time-PCR assays tested, and the results of these three techniques were similar. The rrt assay was 5-fold more sensitive than the other techniques. When used with synthetic controls, all three methods had similar results within a range of 0.1–10 CFU per assay, even down to 0.1 CFU per assay. The new simple, inexpensive, and rapid assay, the rrt, can be used to quantify bacteria in urine samples with high accuracy. This method will be an alternative to the classical technique for isolating urinary bacteria and a powerful additive for the UTI diagnostics panel.<EOD> Hair dye ingestion with the use of lighter and lighter fluid.

Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) is a rare neoplasm of unknown etiology with clinical heterogeneity and multiple organ involvements. Although LCH is often diagnosed in early childhood, some patients are diagnosed in adulthood. Moreover, there have been uncommon cases in the literature which the patients presented with cranial LCH in adulthood. The demographics, clinical characteristics, and response to treatment in such patients are unclear. We analyzed adult patients with cranial LCH who were treated from 2008 to 2016 and classified them into early-onset group (within 45 years of age) and late-onset group (over 45 years of age). There were 15 earlyonset patients (eight males and seven females, median age 34 (21-45) years) and 13 late-onset patients (seven males, six females, median age 65 (53-68) years). In the early-onset group, five patients were symptomatic and 10 were asymptomatic. In late-onset group, six patients were symptomatic and seven were asymptomatic. All early-onset patients underwent treatment, and the symptoms were resolved in all of them after treatment. In late-onset group, one symptomatic patient was treated, and the remaining 12 symptomatic patients did not receive treatment. The cerebral lesions in late-onset patients mainly involved the corpus callosum, basal ganglia, thalamus, and corona radiata. All of them had residual lesions after the treatment. Thus, our findings provide essential information to clinicians to understand adult cranial LCH,

<EOD> Identification of mammalian GTPases, which interact with the cell cycle control protein p125, using two-hybrid screening.
p125(gag-mil) is a p53 homologue involved in cell cycle control of normal cells. Because some viral oncoproteins bind to p125 and inhibit its function, we identified the cellular proteins able to bind to its coiled-coil (CC) domain using two-hybrid technology. Three proteins were found to bind to the CC domain in intracellular locations distinct from the nucleus. Among these proteins, one was identified as Gbeta, a component of heterotrimeric transducin. In addition, 188 genes were isolated from an intracellular two-hybrid screen using the CC domain as prey. Among these, 129 genes, 57 of which encoded Rabs, were GTPases and belonged to the Rho/Rac/Rab family of small GTPases. We show that several members of the Rac/Rho family are able to bind to p125 in vitro and in vivo, suggesting that p125 has the ability to interact with various members of this family. Furthermore, our data indicate a potential role of p125 in cell movement or proliferation. ## Eligibility Assessment Guidelines 
You can find more detailed information on each step here.


### A) Is the patient's condition one of the indications for the treatment of interest?
A patient can be eligible for a study if they have the condition studied in that trial. You should know the inclusion criteria.
When patients have more than one condition, only the condition of interest is considered. That is, if a patient presents two conditions (e.g., migraine and sinusitis), only migraine is considered. If the conditions in which a clinical trial is of interest include two or more diseases, it is highly recommended that you pay special attention to the inclusion criteria of the diseases.
When this disease condition does not coincide with the inclusion criteria in the clinical trial studied, the patient is considered not eligible for that particular study as long as they do not meet the inclusion criteria. If the exclusion criteria in the clinical trial are considered as negative results, or when diseases that appear in the exclusion criteria are considered as negative effects of the treatment, and not as diseases to be treated themselves, they are not considered a reason that the patient cannot be enrolled in the study.
### B) Is the patient aged between 8 years old and 18 years old?
The age criteria may involve age limits or age categories.
If the age range of interest for an evaluation does not include ages, e.g., 8-16.99, a patient aged 6 months must be at least 8 years old and cannot be older than 16.99 years old. If the age limit is 8-18 years old, if the patient is less than 8 years old by 6 months, then they are not eligible for that study.

### C) Does the patient have a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) scores from ≤5 to 12?
GCS is a tool used to define the level of consciousness or the state of consciousness of the patient.

<EOD> Correlation between blood-flow parameters and the degree of stenosis of internal carotid artery in patients with internal carotid stenosis on the basis of multislice CT angiography

A b s t r a c t Introduction: Internal carotid stenosis is a serious factor influencing the cerebral blood supply, and its assessment helps in predicting the risk of ischemic stroke. Multislice CT angiography (MSCT) is one of the leading and non-invasive diagnostic methods. The aim of this study is to determine the relationship between the degree of internal carotid artery (ICA) stenosis and blood-flow parameters of ICA measured basing on MSCT angiography examination. Material and methods: We examined 40 patients hospitalized in the Department of Internal Diseases, Neurology and Angiology, Medical University of Łódź. All patients underwent multislice computed tomography angiography (MSCTA). The degree of hemodynamic compromise of ICA was determined on the basis of measurements of the internal diameter of ICA according to NASCET criteria. Results: There were no significant differences in mean values of blood-flow parameters between patients with less severe (1-30%) internal carotid stenosis and more severe (31-99%) internal carotid stenosis. Conclusions: Patients with less severe internal carotid stenosis and more severe internal carotid stenosis have similar internal diameter of ICA assessed on the basis of multislice computed tomography angiography (MSCTA). Also patients with less severe internal carotid stenosis and more severe internal carotid stenosis have similar blood-flow and cerebral vascular index (CVI) parameters of ICA measured on the basis of multislice computed tomography angiography (MSCTA).

# Introduction
In the medical literature, one can easily find data about a correlation between stenosis of internal carotid artery (ICA) and risk of ischemic stroke. According to current reports, 15-20% of all cerebral strokes are the result of ischemia of brain tissue and are caused by sten

Study Design: Retrospective cohort. Objectives: To evaluate the clinical presentation and neurologic complications associated with posterior quadrant epidural abscesses and to explore the potential for decreased mortality or morbidity following treatment with emergent intervention. Methods: Forty-four consecutive patients at a single institution with cultureproven epidural abscesses (eight patients had concomitant infectious dissemination), diagnosed via magnetic resonance imaging, who were treated with surgery or antibiotics or both. Patients with postlaminectomy epidural abscess, who had only a single level of involvement and who had undergone prior surgery (laminectomies or discectomies) at the affected level, were excluded.Results: Thirty patients with posterior quadrant epidural abscesses had complete presentations/follow-up: 56.7% of subjects had no neurologic deficits, 20% had severe deficits, and 23.3% had deficits that were incompletely described. Patients with posterior quadrant abscesses had a higher rate of neurologic complications (40%) than those with central epidural abscesses (14.3%, P ¼ .0585). Patients with severe neurologic complications underwent early epidural abscess drainage or had a higher rate of emergent spinal instrumentation (80% vs 60%, respectively, P ¼ .34). Of the 18 patients in whom the epidural abscess was treated without emergent surgery, 66.7% had severe neurologic complications. Of the patients who underwent early drainage or early emergent spinal instrumentation, 40% had severe neurologic complications. # Discussion

In this tutorial, we learned how to write the Python program for trial-level eligibility (TLE). 
Now, you can apply your clinical knowledge and background
and apply the algorithms or computer science concepts.

<NAME>, we appreciate your reading the tutorial and hope that it would help you
to deepen your understanding of clinical trial management.
In the following, we would like you to answer the questions below:

**What would you do if the patient's age was not within the age range of the clinical trial but the eligible criteria were met in other respect?**

What would you do if the patient has multiple abdominal complaints but meets all the clinical trial eligibility criteria?

Can we generalize the three criteria as the most important? In other words, is it possible to create a binary variable that encodes whether each patient is eligible for clinical trial? If so, how can you compute such a variable?

When writing programs for computer algorithms, it is very useful to make all the elements of the algorithms clear to the reader so
that the computer programmer can read the code with no ambiguity
and also
so that novices can understand the algorithm 
and its logical flow more easily.
We would like to share the design principles for writing such programs.
The core design principle is `data first and algorithm later`.
In other words, you should prepare the data in advance and design the algorithms later. Here,
we show you an example of using the `pandas`
library when we wrote the code. 
Following is the code for TLE:

<EOD> Exercise physiology and pathophysiology: how should we apply the concept of exercise prescription to patients with endocrine disorders?
Exercise is an effective and low-cost therapy to treat endocrine disorders. However, the concept of an exercise prescription cannot be applied to endocrine patients, nor can the exercise intensity calculated using the ratio of maximal oxygen consumption to body weight be applied to these patients. Exercise is an effective and low-cost therapy to treat endocrine disorders. However, the concept of an exercise prescription cannot be applied to endocrine patients, nor can the exercise intensity calculated using the ratio of maximal oxygen consumption to body weight be applied to these patients.



Patients with an endocrine disorder are a unique population. Some of these patients are so frail that they are unable to perform even small amounts of mild exercise training, while others can perform vigorous exercise training. Therefore, a single recommended exercise protocol cannot be applied to all endocrine patients. Exercise therapies for endocrine disorders usually involve a combination of aerobic exercise and strength training, which reduces systemic inflammation, improves cardiovascular, and musculoskeletal function (1). However, prescribing a combination of aerobic exercise and resistance training to a population of patients with varying degrees of cardiovascular health (even within an individual patient) and differing muscle strength and exercise capacity is difficult.

<EOD> Development, Refinement, and Validation of a Questionnaire-Based Method to Assess Social Drivers of E-Cigarette Intention
Abstract Background The use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) is increasing in the general population, specifically among never smokers. Given that much work has been done to measure smoking behavior, there is a need for the development of a questionnaire to assess e-cigarette behaviors. E-cigarette use, unlike cigarette smoking, may be viewed as a prototypical harm reduction device. Accordingly, a questionnaire to measure e-cigarette use may best be developed as a proxy for cigarette smoking. Methods Our objectives were (1) to develop a short and psychometrically sound questionnaire to measure behavior in smokers, former smokers, never smokers, and dual users (smokers who also use e-cigarettes); (2) to develop a questionnaire to measure the psychometric properties of e-cigarette use that can be used across studies examining the efficacy of e-cigarettes; and (3) to adapt the questionnaire to measure e-cigarette behavior changes that accompany a cessation attempt as a marker of efficacy of e-cigarettes in smoking cigarettes. Results We developed and validated a short version of the questionnaire in a population that consisted of smokers, former smokers, never smokers, and dual users. This questionnaire was able to measure behavior changes that were associated with an e-cigarette cessation attempt. Conclusions We developed new questionnaires to assess e-cigarette use in smoking cessation attempts and in e-cigarette prevention trials. Application of Measure This questionnaire can be used in cross-sectional, case-control, cohort, and intervention studies to measure e-cigarette use as a marker of cigarette smoking cessation and as a target for preventing cigarette smoking

A patient note is a JSON file that should be created before you conduct the analysis. They serve as parameters for the function that you will generate from the function you will generate to predict a trial-level eligibility.

It is recommended to prepare a patient note for the training and test datasets in the same way.

However, you usually don't want to include cases to meet all criteria for your study. `Exclusion Criteria` is a textual description of the exclusion criteria. # Introduction
Thermal ablation is currently one of the most widespread procedures in the treatment of tumors, which can provide an alternative to surgery, especially for unresectable cases. These minimally invasive procedures are well tolerated, often providing immediate symptom relief, and present acceptable rates of complications and mortality. Various thermal ablative devices and techniques are currently applied in clinical practice, but high temperatures are frequently encountered in the tissues at short ablative times in contact mode treatments, especially in fatty tissues. This is because the target tissue is not the most sensitive one to heat, and large thermal gradients are generated due to the heat dissipation of surrounding tissues. Due to the proximity of major blood vessels and bones, such large tissue temperature increases could result in clinical complications such as coagulative necrosis of bone marrow, thermal trauma of visceral organs, or steam pop syndrome. However, this can only be achieved by conducting the appropriate preclinical investigation using a tissue-mimicking phantom.

<EOD> Tick-derived factors involved in biodiversity and tick-borne diseases transmission

Ticks are blood-feeding arthropods that feed periodically on mammals. In North America, Ixodes scapularis is the main vector causing babesiosis, anaplasmosis and lyme borreliosis, which are three major tick-borne endemic diseases on which several works recently focused. Most of these works used a molecular approach and showed that tick salivary gland proteins (SGPs), secreted in the saliva to facilitate blood feeding, are involved in biodiversity and bacterial transmission. Here we hypothesized that molecules involved in tissue adhesion and hemolysis are also involved in transmission. In this work, we therefore took advantage of our transcriptomic data on I.scapularis salivary gland and focused on a set of 796 SGP transcripts, of which 279 encode proteins with the potential to interact with several biological molecules: 134 proteins contain cysteine-rich domains (CRD) and 208 contain transmembrane domains (TMD). We then checked whether these transcripts were present in I. scapularis life stages with various bacterial loads, using RT-qPCR for I. ricinus, the model species for european ticks. A subset of the CRD-encoding transcripts was indeed present in embryos with or without bacterial endosymbionts, while several CRD transcripts and the TMD transcripts were present exclusively in ticks infected with Borrelia burgdorferi. Ixodes scapularis and I. ricinus share the same bacterial endosymbionts and therefore the TMD sub-family could be used as an important molecular marker to identify infected ticks.

In the experiments, LCL124 or interferon-gamma was given to animals either i.p. or i.m. The administration route had no significant effect on the observed therapeutic index, which was highest when both drugs were co-administered. <EOD> The effect of phosphorylation on mitochondrial proteins: A study in the rat heart.
Myocardial ischemia results in the phosphorylation of multiple proteins within the cardiomyocyte. Underlying cause of ischemia-induced phosphorylation of proteins is unclear. The present study tested the hypothesis that ischemia-induced phosphorylation of mitochondrial proteins was primarily due to phosphorylation by cAMP-dependent protein kinase and protein phosphatase inhibition. This hypothesis was tested by administration of inhibitors specific to these two protein kinases in the mitoplast and permeabilized cell models. Our results from the mitoplast model demonstrate that ischemia produced phosphorylation of mitochondrial proteins. Exogenous cAMP (0.015, 0.15 and 1.5 mM) induced no change in mitochondrial protein phosphorylation. On the other hand, the presence of an inhibitor of protein phosphatase-1 (okadaic acid; 10(-7) M) dramatically increased protein phosphorylation. These results were confirmed in the permeabilized cell model. Ischemia did not produce any change in protein phosphorylation. Exogenous addition of AMP significantly decreased protein phosphorylation while adenylate kinase activity or adenosine 5'-triphosphate (ATP) depletion had no effect on protein phosphorylation. It appears that only when mitochondrial function is severely inhibited, such as in the presence of okadaic acid, does the mitochondrial protein become phosphorylated. [START]

The purpose of this exercise is to review the basic information on the eligibility decision support system (EDSS). EDSS is a type of CDSS that aids researchers in automating the eligibility decision or recruitment of the target population as close as possible. EDSS is designed to enhance clinical trial recruitment and improve data quality and analysis capabilities, thus facilitating clinical trial management at a reduced cost.
While the eligibility assessment is usually performed by humans, EDSS uses automated computer algorithms and data mining to mimic humans. Although EDSS cannot replace the assessment by knowledgeable human experts during clinical trial eligibility, EDSS can assist in assessing the eligibility of patients using data recorded so far. The assessment of eligibility by EDSS can be an effective tool because it can be time-consuming to manually evaluate the eligibility of every participant in the clinical trial.
EDSS requires the following two steps before assessing the eligibility of a particular patient:1) Identifying the set of records representing all eligible patients, i.e., patient data that satisfy the inclusion criteria and do not satisfy the exclusion criteria 2) Finding out the most influential inclusion criteria for the assessment of eligibility.
In this exercise, try to construct an EDSS of your own and compare with a published one.

The 5-HT synthesis pathway is mainly regulated by the availability of TRP and the expression levels of various synthetic enzymes. Because TRP is required for protein and neuronal synthesis and various TRP-utilizing pathways, a deficit of TRP is involved in memory process in various brain diseases. Many types of research have been performed to understand the roles of 5-HT and TRP in the memory process. Furthermore, therapeutic uses of 5-HT and TRP in some brain diseases have provided some evidence for their memory enhancing role in cognitive function. In this review, we discuss the functions of 5-HT and TRP in normal and pathological memory processes based on the present studies. ## The synthesis pathway of 5-ht and trp in the brain Serotonin (5-HT), a neurotransmitter and neuromodulator in the central nervous system, is synthesized from L-tryptophan (TRP) utilizing the following pathway in the central nervous system (CNS): 1) L-TRP is converted to 5-hydroxy-L-tryptophan by tryptophan hydroxylase (TPH); 2) 5-hydroxy-L-tryptophan is converted to 5-hydroxy-L-tryptamine (5-HT) by aromatic L-amino acid decarboxylase (AADC); and 3) finally, 5-HT is released from presynaptic terminals into the synaptic cleft, where it binds to various 5-HT 1 to 5 receptors. The synthesis is mediated by the serotonin synthesis pathway in the CNS, and it is largely regulated by the availability of TRP, which is also required in protein and neuronal synthesis

PURPOSE
To compare the outcome of a single dose versus a two-dose regimen of ceftriaxone for the treatment of urogenital infections.


METHODS
Randomised prospective double-blind trial with blinded endpoint. The protocol was implemented in nine medical services for inpatients of the general hospitals of the province of Luxembourg. In the experimental group, treatment was administered with a single intravenous injection of 2g followed by the maintenance on oral placebo. The outcome measured was clinical improvement evaluated three days after the beginning of treatment.


RESULTS
68 patients were enrolled, 35 in group C 1 (control) and 33 in group C 2 (experimental). At the three-day visit, 21 (60%) patients of group C 1 responded to treatment versus 27 (82%) of group C 2 (Chi2=16.8231, p=0.00000695).


CONCLUSIONS

We investigate impulse propagation in a two-dimensional lattice of excitable particles. The excitable particles are coupled by diffusion, but the coupling coefficient is not the same for every pair of particles. The numerical result shows that the impulse speed is determined by the initial energy state of the system. When the initial energy state of the system is below the critical level, the propagation velocity depends on the excitability of the system, which can be controlled by the coupling coefficient. When the initial energy state of the system is above the critical level, the system quickly reaches the critical value, which corresponds to a stationary state. Moreover, the pattern of responding during the post-reinforcement pause and during the noise or food presentations was similar when the post-pause pause was of either 5 or 9 s. <EOD> Assessment of the relationship between serum adiponectin level and prognostic nutritional index in patients with esophageal squamous cell carcinoma following esophagectomy

Background: A high serum adiponectin level has been reported to be associated with better prognosis in various types of cancers. Moreover, a higher prognostic nutritional index (PNI) was found to be suggestive of a relatively better overall survival (OS) in multiple types of malignant cancers. However, the relationship between serum adiponectin level and PNI in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) has not been fully studied. Methods: A total of 148 patients with esophageal SCC following esophagectomy were enrolled in the present study. We compared the differences in the serum adiponectin levels between non-recurrence patients (n = 132) and recurrence patients (n = 16), and also between the higher survival group (> 32 months) and poorer survival group (< 32 months). Results: Serum adiponectin levels were significantly associated with OS and recurrence rates in patients with esophageal SCC following surgery (p < 0.001 and p = 0.020, respectively). Moreover, a significant correlation was found between adiponectin levels and PNI in these patients (Spearman correlation coefficient = 0.69, p < 0.001). When the patients were divided into four groups based on PNI and adiponectin expression levels, we observed that group A (PNI ≥ 52 and adiponectin level ≥ 8.1 mg/dL) had the best cancer prognosis, including a low probability of total recurrence, recurrence-free survival and OS (p < 0.001). Conclusions: Our data suggest that patients with esophageal SCC who had a higher serum adiponectin level associated with a higher PNI had a better prognosis in terms of cancer recurrence and OS. Serum adiponectin levels and PNI may be useful biomarkers in predicting survival and

Objective:The purpose of this study is to clarify the relationship between Creactive protein and the body composition in patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD). Methods:The study group consisted of 100 patients with PAD who underwent lower extremity angiography at Toyohashi Municipal Hospital from February 1, 2001, to November 30, 2004. Conclusions:C-reactive protein was correlated with a decreased skeletal muscle mass, but was not associated with the indices reflecting adipose tissue, which suggests that a decreased skeletal muscle mass was associated with more severe inflammation, that is, higher C-reactive protein in patients with PAD. BACKGROUND
The incidence of thyroid cancer is increasingly. This study discusses the clinical characteristics of the primary thyroid carcinoma in children age 20 years or younger.


MATERIAL AND METHODS
Data from 24 patients below the age of 20 (6 boys and 18 girls), treated for thyroid carcinoma in our tertiary center between 1976 and 1998 were reviewed. Patient's clinical characteristics, histopathological features, prognosis and follow-up were retrospectively analyzed.


RESULTS
Histologic features showed papillary adenocarcinoma (n = 19), follicular carcinoma (n = 2), medullary carcinoma (n = 2) and anaplastic large cell carcinoma (n = 1). Mean patient age was 14.7 years (+/- 3.79 years). Primary tumor was larger than 4 cm in diameter in 18 cases. Bone metastases were documented in two patients. None patients had regional lymphonodenal metastases. All had an euthyroid state.


CONCLUSIONS
The thyroid carcinoma in children usually develops at an earlier age than it is found in the adult population. <EOD> In vivo analysis of rat sperm nuclear DNA damage using the comet assay.
Sperm morphology is a predictor of male fertility. A correlation between DNA damage and sperm morphology has been documented in several studies that have looked at human and experimental animals. The comet assay is a sensitive, simple and highly reproducible method for measuring DNA damage in tissue and cell suspensions. A comet assay was developed to quantify DNA integrity in morphologically normal rat spermatozoa. Rats were exposed to different environmental toxicants, namely ionising radiation and the insecticide parathion, and the comet assay was used to assess the genotoxicity of these agents on rat testicular spermatozoa. Spermatozoa were prepared based on a Percoll-hypotonic swelling medium gradient method. Spermatozoa were incubated in a hypoosmotic solution immediately following Percoll preparation, in order to evaluate the degree of sperm DNA fragmentation during the isolation and manipulation procedures. The majority of spermatozoa was demonstrated to be intact in morphology (93.2 +/- 8.2% intact; 12.6 +/- 1.2% morphologically normal). The extent of DNA denaturation was measured, with significant damage indicated by the presence of a comet tail. Our results demonstrated that DNA denaturation increased with the degree of sperm abnormality. Spermatozoa that survived the initial Percoll gradient procedure had intact nuclei. The degree of DNA denaturation after isolation was assessed to be 1.8 +/- 1.0%, and there was no significant difference between the tail moments of damaged sperm isolated from the testis and those in semen. Damage to sperms following exposure to ionising radiation was observed, thus confirming that our method can detect DNA damage in spermatozoa. No sperm damage was observed in rats exposed to pesticides.<EOD> .

## Clinician, CRO, Biological, or Statistical

This question was also written by [Athanasios Tsoulfas], PhD

We are interested in your opinion regarding whether patients with certain disease characteristics should be offered participation in clinical trials. We are interested primarily in your clinical role and whether you identify predominately with the role of a clinician or a role related to research.

You should answer three key questions for each type of trial. The first question is whether or not patients with certain disease characteristics should be offered participation in clinical trials. The second question is to provide a brief description of what is important to the appropriate recruitment and participation of patients in your particular clinical trials. The final question is whether you would provide personal recommendations on how best to ensure that patients with certain disease characteristics are offered participation in clinical trials.

This question was also written by [Sophia Sagana], PhD

As you know, clinical trials are designed to find out if the possible results of interest for investigated treatments can be observed in a real-world setting. When a patient with a certain disease comes to the clinic or hospital seeking treatment, he/she would seek to know if a treatment may be available with any potential benefits (such as reduced side effects, improved quality of life) or harm (such as more side effects, less improvement in quality of life) to patients.

Clinicians are people who are trained to know more about the diseases and have experience in their medical practice in a health care setting to observe their patients and treat them. As patients seek treatment for a certain disease in clinical practice, doctors usually want to know all about the disease and may have specialized training in treating patients with specific diseases.
Clinical Research Organizations (CROs) operate in between pharmaceutical companies that develop drugs and health care providers who deliver treatment (i.e., hospitals, clinics, doctors’ offices, etc.) and conduct research in a laboratory. Clinical Research Organizations (CROs) are companies that provide research products and services to the biopharmaceutical, medical device, and related products industries in the clinical phases of the drug development process. Clinical Research Organizations provide services to the pharmaceutical, biotechnology, medical device

The immunization technique has been changed to human diploid cultured cell vaccine in Japan since 1992. To understand the immunogenicity of this type of vaccine, the following basic study was performed. Human diploid cultured cells, MRC-5 (CCL-171) were prepared and used after being irradiated at 6,000 rads. Vero cells were also irradiated as the control. The vaccine was prepared according to the method of human diploid cell vaccine for rabies. Adult mice were immunized under an immunization protocol of human diploid cell vaccine used in Japan (5 times with intramuscular injection of 0.1 ml each), but the intervals between the administrations were reduced to 2 weeks. Anti-rabies viral neutralizing antibody titers were tested by the fluorescent antibody focus-inhibition (FAF) method. The results showed that the antibody titer in the irradiated MRC-5 group was lower than that in the irradiated Vero group. The irradiated Vero group showed the antibody titer equivalent to that of the non-irradiated Vero group. The antibody titer in the irradiated MRC-5 group was lower than that in the non-irradiated MRC-5 group. The titer in the irradiated MRC-5 group was also lower than that in the Vero group. Thus, the immunogenicity of human diploid cultured cell vaccine was decreased by irradiation at 6000 rads.<EOD> .

```python
def is_eligible(note_str, trial_str):
    """
    1. Extract demographic information from the given note(s).
    2. Assess that the patient satisfies the demographics and other criteria specified in the given trial-strategy.
    3. If so, the patient is judged to be `highly likely to be referred for this trial.`
    4. Else, the patient is judged to be `Not considered for this trial.`.
    """
    patients = json.loads(note_str)
    for patient in patients['patients']:
        eligible = True    # initial value
        trial = trial_str.split()
        strategy = trial[-1]
        for t in trial[:-1]:
            if not t in patient: eligible = False # eligible=False = trial_level eligibility=0
        if eligible: trial_level_eligibility += 1 # trial_level_eligibility=2 = trial_level eligibility=2      
    print("Trial-level eligibility : " + str(trial_level_eligibility))
    if trial_level_eligibility == 2: print("Highly likely to refer this patient for this clinical trial!")
    else: print("Not considered for this trial.")
```

> 100 * \frac {300}{800} = 37.5%

<EOD> Comparison of the biuretidase activities of the plasma kininogens of man, goat, sheep, and horse.
Biuretidase activity has been associated with the kininogens in various species. In the present report, the biuretidase activities of the human, goat, sheep, and horse kininogens are compared. The results show that the kininogen of each species possesses a specific biuretidase activity. The ratio of the biuretidase to the kallikrein-independent amidolytic activities was 0.15, 1.66, 1.25, and 2.2 in horse, sheep, goat, and man, respectively. In horse and sheep, the biuretidase activity was found to be associated exclusively with the purified kininogen. The kininogen from goat did not contain a detectable level of biuretidase activity, although its kallikrein-independent amidolytic activity toward hippurylalanine was similar to that of the piglet kininogen (3,440 units/mg protein). Biuret-like inhibitors of the biuretidase activities were synthesized and tested by means of polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis for their potential to form ionic bonds with the kininogen of each species. The sheep and goat kininogens appeared to have a high binding capacity for biuret-like inhibitors, while the human and horse kininogens showed very little binding. Additional binding experiments for the sheep kininogen were performed using the various isolated fractions, showing that at least one biuret-like inhibitor-binding site is present in the Lys-bradykinin-binding site region of the protein. This binding was lost after deoxycholate treatment of the native kininogen molecule. The sheep kininogen, therefore, demonstrates the highest biuretidase activity compared with the other 3 kininogens. Whether the biuretidase activity has an important function in the generation and/or processing of the kinin system is unknown.<EOD> The Relationship between Nutrition and Immune Function

<EOD> Innovative teaching methodology applied to a clinical skill: Evaluation of the teaching of a case of a child presenting developmental milestones.
UNLABELLED
One of the goals of the curricula of health-sciences courses is that students learn by experience, to have the necessary skills to deal with new situations in their future careers. Teaching methods differ widely, and it is necessary to evaluate them in order to optimize students' learning skills.


OBJECTIVE
To analyze the effectiveness of an innovative educational technique in the training of students in a medical career in the management of a child whose case of physical and neurodevelopmental evolution showed normal evolution vs. evolution with a delay in three dimensions of development (motoric and socio-cognitive).


MATERIAL AND METHODS
The study involved 70 5th-year medical students. Two randomized groups were studied, Group A (n=35) that received an innovative training, and Group B (n=35), whose study methodology was based on didactic, traditional lectures. The evaluation was performed by comparing their respective scores in (a) a quiz about the study case, (b) individual and group debates and (2) an evaluation of the perception of their own evolution.


RESULTS
The group that received the innovative training method showed significant gains in their knowledge of the development case they assessed compared to the group that underwent traditional didactic teaching. The results of both of the studies also demonstrated a greater perception of evolutions in the area of neurodevelopment in the innovative intervention group than in the traditional training intervention group.


CONCLUSION
The study demonstrated that when students learn a clinical case by direct application of the theoretical-practical contents of the course, the educational results were more efficient than didactic didactic teaching.<EOD> Lymphocytic-predominant colitis (LPCD) is a distinct entity within the collagenous colitis pathologic spectrum and shares with lymphocytic colitis (LC) similar clinical and pathologic aspects.

A: One way of generating patient eligible to particular clinical trial is using rule-based system. For each clinical trial the system will build the rule that will evaluate the fitness of patients to that trial.
Rules will be based on inclusion and exclusion criteria of the trials.
There are mainly three kinds of clinical trial rules:
- Inclusion rule: will evaluate patients as fit or unfit to that trial
- Exclusion rule: will evaluate patients as unfit or fit to that trial
- Partially Match rule: will evaluate patient a fit partially to that trial

Title: "The Utility of Time Segmental Withdrawal During Screening Colonoscopy for Increasing Adenoma Detection Rate"
Summary:
Colonoscopy( examining the colon with a flexible tube and a camera ) is usually done for screening purposes to find any precancerous lesions (polyps) at an early stage.
During the colonoscopy the doctor will advance the colonoscope to the end of your colon and start examining the colon for any polyps.
Withdrawal time is the period of time the doctor spends examining the colon.
Doctors usually spend six minutes examining the colon after they reach the end of the colon.
Studies have showed that spending more withdrawal time detects more lesions.
The proposal to dedicating half of the withdrawal time during colonoscopy in examining the right side of the colon will increase the detection of polyps in the right side of the colon.
There will be no other changes in the procedural aspect of the colonoscopy.

A simple numerical method for the prediction of early-time buoyancy oscillation from initial flame shapes and profiles is developed here by analyzing buoyancy and mean circulation modes in the time averaged, low-dimensional (L-D) combustion equations. The flame shape profiles and the L-D modes are obtained by solving the L-D combustion equations (L=2) and then applying numerical low-pass filtering followed by a smoothing. We then employ the time-averaged equations obtained from the filtered data as the basis forms and expand in Fourier series in time to obtain the evolution of each Fourier mode with time. Then, we calculate the modal wavenumber spectra in the low frequency (long wave) range. If the modal wavenumber spectrum includes certain modes in the low frequency range, then it has a strong possibility of developing onset-flickering. The result shows that a wide variety of different initial shape profiles, and also initial profiles with pre-existing buoyancy oscillation and pre-existing mean flow, can generate flicker instability, but the final sustained flame shapes are qualitatively similar. It is shown that the pre-existing buoyancy oscillation and pre-existing mean flow do not have much influence on the wavenumber spectrum

Abstract Objective This study aimed to evaluate how the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic has influenced anaesthetic practice in patients with morbid obesity who were undergoing planned, elective surgery. The main interest was to assess if changes in anaesthetic practice, in terms of location of the neuraxial block, have resulted in a difference in epidural haematoma rates. Design All patients with morbid obesity who had a diagnostic code for morbid obesity at our institution and had an elective anaesthetic with a neuraxial device between October 2018 and April 2020 at Lille University hospital, France, were included. Setting Patients were planned to undergo epidural or spinal anaesthesia for elective surgery in Lille University Hospital, France. Participants All patients with morbid obesity. Measurements and Main Results A total of 120 patients with morbid obesity were included. Forty-three patients underwent a neuraxial block in surgery in March to April 2018 versus 77 in March to April 2020 (p = 0.001). After the beginning of the pandemic, the number of epidural blocks was higher (12 versus 39, p = 0.001). The type of surgery and the use of antiplatelet or anticoagulant drugs did not differ between the 69 first-year patients included after January 2019 (16 men and 53 women) and the 54 patients from the previous years (31 men and 23 women). A: In my opinion the task you want perform would a sort of classification and so you want to adopt a supervised classification approach.
In this case, there are other things to be taken into account, for example:
- there are some rules regarding patient eligibility (rules should probably be encoded by regular expressions);
- there are some words in the note that trigger a specific patient type or in general the patient should be categorized in a specific group, for example according to gender;
- there are some words (or terms) that are more important than others (e.g.: diabetes, past, fracture),
- you are required to produce output only if specific words are present;

The simplest thing to do is to treat patients' notes as the records for a machine learning data set. Then all you have to do is to label each record ("1" or "0") based on the rules you provided. Next, you can build your classification model. A more complex method would be to adopt a rule-based machine learning approach and to use algorithms such as JRip. In this case, it is possible to represent the rules in an appropriate formalism  e.g. as GUESS expressions)

For more information about this topic, here are some good resources:
- Machine Learning and Rule-Based (10/6) for beginners
- Do I need to understand machine learning to apply rule-based approaches, or vice-versa?
- Rule-based machine learning: how to use it when it is required?
- Supervised machine learning with rules/guidelines
In any case, the problem could be too complex. For example, the information conveyed by this note may not be sufficient to perform this classification, i.e. we need some background information about this patient, for example, the medications she is taking, etc. Therefore, I guess that you may need a much deeper analysis before starting to create any classification model.

A: This should be straightforward enough if you're familiar with regular expressions:
^(?!No)^(?P^M[A-Z]\.)?[P^M][A-Z]\.\d+\.?[M^P]$

However, I can't seem to reproduce the error you've described. If I create the string "No" as input to the function, I get output of 0 (not 1). If the "no" string is replaced by "yes", then the output is simply "no".  So, what's going on? How can we get the regular expressions to work?
The reason, I think, is that the two matches to the regular expression are not independent. To better illustrate, the expression I have above is actually a pattern match for "Yes...", so the following string is a match: "That's no...". The second pattern match for "no" has its own second subexpression that matches to just "no": ^(?P^M[A-Z]\.)?[P^M]No(?P$.*?\\.[A-Z]\d+\.\d)

If you look at this expression (which doesn't work right) you'll see the "match-then-lookahead" feature:
if it has the first match, make sure there's a match to the subexpression at the end.
In the case above, the "match-then-lookahead" expression looks for "isn't a no", or "No", in this case. It checks for that, and it only continues if you get the No.
So, in this case, having "yes" with the "no" still means that the regex still works for some strings, but this doesn't give you 0's for any input, only strings giving both "yes" and "no".
Here is a revised regular expression:
[Yes.?N]?[yP^M]No (?P^M[A-Z]\.)?[P^M][A-Z]\(\.\d+\)

## [Task 1] 
In this task, you should determine whether or not a given patient meets the inclusion criteria of a clinical trial. This eligibility problem is defined for each clinical trial as a binary classification problem between patient's inclusion and exclusion for each clinical trial. We consider the patient is eligible to a clinical trial, i.e., patient meets the inclusion criteria for a clinical trial, when the probability of assigning the highest scale, 2) Highly likely to refer this patient for this clinical trial., is larger than the probability of assigning the lower scale, 0) Would not refer this patient for this clinical trial., by a margin of 0.5. For example, even if the probability of assigning the second score, 1) Would consider referring this patient to this clinical trial upon further investigation.,
for a patient is 0.6, we assign 1) in case of the probability of assigning the second score is greater than 0.5.

An exact p-value is calculated by first determining the number of 2 × 2 tables with expected counts less than or equal to the observed counts, and the probability is divided by the number of tables that are available to be tested. # Introduction
In this article, we illustrate how clinical trial eligibility criteria such as gender, age, inclusion criteria, exclusion criteria, etc. can be expressed in R code. Existing methods are developed mainly to represent clinical criteria, including R packages  and R tools 
[1] [2] , the ClinicalTrial tool, the clinical decision rule Criteria package [bib_ref]  An r package for creating and implementing clinical decision rules, Rothschild [/bib_ref]  , and others. However, most of these methods cannot make a quick assessment of eligibility. For example, the DecisionTree package uses machine learning methods to extract rules from clinical trial eligibility information, but it takes a long time to train the predictive model and calculate the results. The Criteria package is a handy R package for clinical decision rules, but there is a large limitation in clinical trial eligibility.
As an exception, we have added a clinical trial eligibility in the package clinicaltrial.eligibility. In this article, we focus on clinical trial eligibility expressed in clinicaltrial.eligibility.

# Constructing eligibility criteria
We have a general formula to construct an eligibility criterion of `eligibilityCriteria` and an eligibility criterion of an individual `patient` that are as follows:
```r
library(clinicaltrial)

ageCriteria <- eligibilityCriteria(min_age = 20, max_age = 50) 
patient1 <- data.frame(age = ageCriteria @@ data[which(ageCriteria @@ data > 0), "age"), patient_name = "Patient 1", patient_id = 11, patient_sex = "m") %>% add_age_string() 

patient2 <- data.frame(age = ageCriteria @@ data[which(ageCriteria @@ data > 0), "age"], patient_name = "Patient 2", patient_id = 12, patient_sex = "m") %>% add_age_string() 

ageCriteria.eligible(patient2) 
#> [1] TRUE 
ageCriteria.eligible(patient1)

<EOD> The role of a medical library system in quality assurance programmes.
If we are to accept the assertion that a high quality service must be underpinned by the efficient collection, storage, retrieval and utilization of information, it is essential that we review our present information services. There is no doubt that the role of the medical library system in quality assurance programmes is a key one. In general libraries, quality of service is concerned with ensuring that the appropriate collection, storage and retrieval of information are available to the end user in order for that individual to conduct his or her own inquiries and form independent decisions. In medical libraries, quality of service is concerned with ensuring a high level of user satisfaction and the provision of a high level of information service which is acceptable to medical personnel. In spite of the difficulties of measuring quality of service in health care, it is of paramount importance to ensure that the information provided is both effective and efficient - and that these attributes are communicated to customers in a way that will ensure long term customer satisfaction. The medical libraries at Guy's Hospital NHS Trust has developed a quality assurance programme that encompasses both internal customer and user perception as well as meeting the requirements of the Trust's standards of excellence. Although initially the development of this programme was considered by library staff to be a laborious undertaking, the end-product has led to an enhancement of library services, an improvement in quality of service delivery and a widening of service provision at the Trust.<EOD> Combined effects of methylome and transcriptome dysregulation on immunomodulators

Micron-thin cellulose nanofibrils (CNF) paper exhibiting fast wetting and water permeability has recently been introduced as an innovative biomaterial. Herein we report a new strategy for surface modification of nanoparticles by polyelectrolyte multilayers through a one-step and environmentally friendly process involving the utilization of CNF papers as highly efficient solid supports. <EOD> Inhibition of tumor growth in vitro by monoclonal antibodies recognizing MUC1 glycoforms.
MUC1 proteins are highly glycanated membrane-bound mucins overexpressed in a variety of epithelial cancers. The high density of carbohydrate epitopes may be the tumor's Achilles' heel. Previous work with monoclonal antibodies R10 and R11, which recognize the common core of tumor-associated MUC1 expressed with abnormal linkage and glycosylation at O-linked serine or threonine and at N-linked asparagine, has led to the hypothesis of selective tumor targeting in patients with cancer. This study examined the therapeutic potential of intact, fully immunocompetent hybridomas R10 and R11 with the goal of increasing antibody activity against tumor cells in vitro. Hybridomas R10 and R11 were generated using human splenocytes from 1) a donor with normal cancer history (healthy) or 2) donors either with a history of multiple cancer tumors (cancer) or with no history of cancer but with family history (familial). Immune cells were stimulated with autoclaved MUC1 peptides containing the tumor epitope. After 2 weeks, splenocytes were fused with myeloma cells to produce antibody hybridomas. Hybridomas were expanded and characterized for tumor reactivity and ability to lyse tumor cells. The intracellular signaling pathways that lead to cytolysis were also investigated. Monoclonal antibodies R10 and R11 were generated from the healthy donor with a fully functional immune system, whereas hybridoma R10 was from a cancer donor from whom immune function was compromised; hybridoma R11 was from a familial donor with no history of cancer who was not immunocompromised. <EOD> Exercise training: its effect on inflammatory and vascular thrombotic factors
The incidence of cardiovascular disease and cancer is significantly reduced by exercise training, suggesting that the physiologic pathways that regulate cardiovascular and immune system are closely linked. Regular exercise training markedly affects both the function and composition of the immune system and may play an important role in inflammatory diseases. Although various cardiovascular risk factors, such as endothelial function and coagulation, and inflammatory status are highly inter-related, information on the effects of exercise training on these cardiovascular factors remains scarce. This review describes the effects of exercise training on the major inflammatory and vascular thrombotic factors that are key to systemic inflammation and CVDs. Exercise training modulates these factors, either transiently following intervention or with long-term effects. This review also summarizes the effects of various types of exercise on the inflammatory and vascular factors (Table 1). The studies included in this review focused on adult human beings and evaluated exercise intervention with either aerobic exercise, resistance exercise or concurrent aerobic and resistance exercise. We used keywords such as ‘endothelial function’, ‘coagulant factor’, ‘cardiovascular disease’, ‘inflammatory’ and ‘exercise’, combined with Boolean logic operators to retrieve abstracts from PubMeb Database. Original articles and review articles that focused on the topics of exercise and cardiovascular risk factors were searched through PubMed. The retrieved papers under the search criteria were examined and categorized according to study design, exercise type or training status. Some of the studies are focused on populations with specific conditions or with the elderly. Tables 1 and 2 list some of the representative research papers. The evidence indicates that exercise training enhances aerobic capacity, cardiac output, and endothelium-dependent and endothelium-independent vascular relaxation. These responses can translate into reductions in cardiovascular risk factors, especially in patients with CVDs. The findings support an emerging theory of vascular function and vascular protection by exercise. Further research is required to clarify the underlying physiological

<EOD> Phylogenetic and functional analysis of the E3 ubiquitin ligase family of Sorghum bicolor in response to drought stress1
Drought is a common threat to the growth and yield of many agricultural crops. The genome of Sorghum contains a large number of genes that encode E3 ubiquitin ligase, the largest family of transmembrane proteins in the human genome. However, the roles and mechanisms of these E3 components in developing drought tolerance are poorly understood. In the present study, we analyzed a total of 417 E3s in the genome of Sorghum to find out their phylogeny and functional importance in regulating drought stress tolerance. The Sorghum E3 genes were distributed across the 10 chromosomes of the genome, in various size classes ranging from 790 to 7021 bp in length. The Sorghum E3 genes generally contained one intron (one class), from 1 to 237 introns (25 classes), and 0 to 8 exons (25 classes), with an average of 5.1 kb in size. We found that these E3 genes were preferentially located on the edge and in the end of the chromosomes. Based on structural similarity, phylogenetic analysis revealed 107 classes, and among them, 13 E3 ubiquitin ligase subfamilies were identified in Sorghum. All E3 ubiquitin ligase genes were expressed differentially in sorghum under various stress treatments, including drought stress. The results showed that all three types of TFs (MYB, MYB-related, and bZIP) involved in both biotic and abiotic stress responses were expressed differentially in drought stress and were enriched in ABA responsive genes. These E3 genes might be important in stress tolerance with roles that could be explored to enhance abiotic stress tolerance in crops.<EOD> Awareness of dietary behaviour of family members predicts dietary behaviours of

# Introduction
Many clinical trials with cancer patients are terminated early or unsuccessfully for not recruiting sufficient numbers of participants in the eligibility set. It is important to determine the number of participants beforehand so that a clinical trial can recruit enough participants to reach a power sufficient to obtain convincing results. We propose a new method to predict the number of participants based on the following two key concepts [1],
* Number of subjects who fulfill all eligibility criteria. 
* Number of subjects who refuse to participate even if the trial is beneficial based upon the participant's expectation of benefit. This expectation is based on the participant's interpretation of the benefit.
We aim to obtain quantification of this eligibility proportion and refusal proportion in this paper. Our motivation came from a medical information pharmaceutical company that had a drug for treating psoriasis patients. Because the number of participants was not satisfying enough by a factor of 2.04 to conduct a multicenter study, the study was terminated. Thus, the drug did not receive marketing approval. Furthermore, although the drug improved the patient's quality of life, the participant in the study was not satisfied with a lack of visible improvement in skin lesion. Therefore, a method for predicting the number of sufficient participants was desirable. In this study, we developed

<EOD> Bias in the use of diagnostic drugs.
This analysis deals with diagnostic biases, when doctors make use of a diagnostic drug (a substance that excludes or confirms a diagnosis) in clinical routine. The analysis examines whether the likelihood of giving a diagnosis is affected by the test outcome, using medical diagnoses recorded in patients' files, and whether this likelihood is biased by the pre-test probability. The results indicate that the likelihood of giving a diagnosis based on drug results is affected by the test outcome; moreover, the direction and the size of these differences between the expected and the observed frequencies depend on the pre-test probability. These differences do not favour the diagnoses based on drug test results. It is argued, howerer, that diagnostic drugs can be useful for diagnosing patients who are initially suspected of the disease but for whom no diagnosis can be established. The study also analyses a group of patients with 'alternative' diagnoses. The probability of having the alternative diagnosis is similar in these patients, irrespective of test results. Further analysis leads to the conclusion that, irrespective of the pre-test probability of a certain diagnosis, most patients can be diagnosed either by a diagnostic drug or by an alternative drug. The conclusions are presented separately for 'single' (either drug excludes or confirms the diagnosis), 'dual' (either drug excludes, confirms or both, the diagnosis), and 'triple' (all three drugs are able to diagnose or exclude the conditions) diagnostic drugs. These conclusions imply that the total costs and the net benefits, associated with the use of these drugs, also depend on the frequency of the diseases and on the patients' pre-test probability.<EOD> .

The effect of the solvent on BNPO fluorescence, optical excitation, and photoluminescent decay times was studied. The photophysical properties of BNPO were found to depend on solvents. The results of fluorescence spectra and fluorescence decay dynamics reveal that the recombination of the radical ion pair in a cyclohexane solvent is quite similar to that in the mixed cyclohexane/octanoic acid solvent, whereas the lowest value of the fluorescence decay time and the photoluminescent quantum yield in an octanoic acid solvent are indicative of the presence of triplet-triplet annihilation and/or the presence of triplet molecular oxygen in the octanoic acid solvent. The BNPO emission peak is maximized in the cyclohexane solvent and is minimized in the octanoic acid solvent; a maximum excitation band is located above 300 nm in all investigated solvents. It was found that this band can be efficiently excited by femtosecond laser pulses when the laser wavelength was tuned to 293 nm. - __Patient Note__: A patient note for which the eligibility assessment is required.

## Data preprocessing for transformer
To enhance the accuracy of the model and facilitate transformer training, the preprocessing follows below pipeline is helpful for transformer transforming the raw patient note into word_to_id vectors:

### 1. Tokenizer.
1) Take a document "Clinical note" in `Example3.json`-`Example5.json` (it's the same for `Trial03.json` and `Trial06.json`) as an input and split it into multiple sequences, which are word-pieces.

Then tokenize the document with Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers (BERT) tokenizer. You can use the following command to accomplish the above function.
Note: If you don't have Clinical note.txt in Example3 folder, then create Clinical note.txt. Run commands bellow. For the data used in this paper, please refer to `example_data`.

| Command                                               | Content |

PURPOSE
Patients with diabetes mellitus (DM) have a higher mortality risk in general and they are at higher risk of dying from SARS-CoV-2 infection. However, little is known about the presence and nature of cofactors that modify the association between diabetes and death in critical patients with coronavirus disease 19 (COVID-19).


METHODS
From March 12 to April 4, 2020, 143 patients consecutively admitted to an 18-bed respiratory intensive care unit (RICU) of our medical center for COVID-19 pneumonia were the subjects of this retrospective study. In our single-center, we collected sociodemographic, laboratory, clinical, and outcome data, which were analyzed and we explored variables that may modify the association between DM and the primary endpoint. An additional multivariate analysis was conducted on the selected subgroup of 64 patients in whom the severity of pneumonia, as measured by the Chung study severity index of pneumonia progression, was assessed at least twice. The association with mortality was compared between three time periods.


RESULTS
The study sample included 93 (64.5%) non-diabetic (ND) and 50 (35.5%) diabetic (DM) patients. Mortality and severity of pneumonia, as quantified by the Chung study severity index of pneumonia progression, were significantly higher among DM patients. In a Cox multivariable model, the adjusted hazard ratio (AHR) of DM for death was 2 (95% confidence interval ) in DM patients versus ND patients. In the ND and DM subgroups, the Chung index was significantly associated with mortality at first evaluation. After the first evaluation, Chung scores in the two groups showed a consistent decrease over time in survivors.
