<EOD> A Novel Method to Reduce the Frequency of the Laryngeal Penetration
Airway management is an important element in anesthetic care. However, airway events such as failed tracheal intubation, aspiration pneumonia, and postoperative sore throat remain serious problems. Aspiration is one of the most frequently observed airway complications in various airway management strategies. Laryngeal penetration during airway management is one of the major aspiration events of airway management. In this study, we tested a novel device for preventing Laryngeal Penetration. Thirty adult patients were participated in this study. One of the lids with Velcro was placed over the patient's upper airway in the sniffing position. All patients showed laryngeal penetration without velcro during the laryngoscopy and manual laryngeal-mask airway insertions. A total of 22 patients (73.3%), laryngeal penetration occurred during the laryngoscopy in velcro group compared with 27 of 30 patients (90%) in the control group (p = 0.048). All of the patients could successfully pass velcro over the upper airway by a single or assisted attempt without any failure case. Using this novel device, we could decrease laryngeal penetration during laryngoscopy. We believe that our device could be a potential new method to improve current airway management strategies.<EOD> .

<EOD> Prevention of aortic arch malformation in C57BL/6J newborn mice with a mutation of the Npr2 gene
Arterial congenital defects occur sporadically in humans and are also found in mice; however, systematic studies of the genes causing congenital lesions of major arteries are few in number. This study aimed to identify the genes associated with aortic arch development in neonatal mice. Npr2, a cyclic GMP‐dependent protein kinase II substrate, is thought to be involved in arterial development. To evaluate a newborn arch formation using inhibitor of the Npr2 protein, we created hybrid mice containing wild‐type C57BL/6J and ENU‐mutated C3H/He backgrounds. Npr2 mutant male mice died just at birth because of truncation of the aortic arch; additionally, these mice exhibited short umbilical cord and small lung with few blood vessels. We found that the Npr2‐inhibitor‐treated pregnant mice delivered pups with complete heart block that showed no cardiac or aortic defects. This study demonstrates a novel role for the npr2 mutant in the formation of the aortic arch in neonatal mice, and the NPR2 protein may be a promising target for investigating genetically engineered human congenital heart disease. <EOD> Pharmacology and therapeutic potential of GPR52.
GPR52 is a recently discovered G protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) belonging to the class C family. Because only little information about its ligands is available, this GPCR is still poorly studied. GPR52 has been isolated by means of an affinity-based biotechnological approach using the amino-terminal fragment of chemokine CXCL14 as an antagonistic chemokine-like GPCR ligand. GPR52 is preferentially expressed in brain, especially in the striatum and the hippocampus. A knockout model of GPR52 has been generated and shown to have no major physiological alterations, in contrast to GPCRs of class A. In fact, GPR52 deficiency induces several behaviours, which are usually observed under stressful conditions, and leads to reduced depressive-like responses. These features suggest that GPR52 might be a modulator of behaviour-dependent signalling cascades. Moreover, GPR52 may control physiological activities in the brain, including the modulation of synaptic plasticity, which represents the cellular bases of memory and learning. GPR52 expression has been detected also in peripheral tissues, especially in the pancreas. GPR52 binding sites appear to act as regulators of the insulin secretion mechanism regulating the levels of intracellular GTP, which are in turn related to insulin release. This finding suggests potential pharmacological applications of GPR52 agonists or antagonists in diabetes mellitus. In conclusion, the study of GPR52 may open new opportunities for the development of therapeutic strategies aimed to cure neurodegenerative and endocrine diseases, such as diabetes and Alzheimer's disease.<EOD> Development of an automated method for the evaluation of glucocorticoid receptor binding, its use in the development of GR-125808 (R1881) a potent synthetic non-steroidal agonist.

Proper innate immune response to invading pathogens is essential for host survival which requires a delicate control of intra-cellular signaling pathways. MicroRNAs are recently emerged post-transcriptional regulators of gene expression implicated in a wide array of developmental, physiological and pathological processes. A few studies describe the role of MicroRNAs in regulation of host response to bacterial lipopolysaccharide stimulation in different cell types and tissues. Here we describe microRNA and mRNA expression profiles in response to the systemic administration of lipopolysaccharide (LPS) in the liver. A large number of altered microRNA and mRNA were identified in a rat model of acute inflammation which were not limited to inflammatory process but also affected other cellular activities such as the protein folding and cholesterol metabolism. Increase in the expression of proinflammatory mediators and co-stimulatory molecules at gene level was observed in liver. The expression of immune response genes was regulated during the LPS stimulation as well as by the transcriptional, post-transcriptional and epigenetic mechanisms. Interestingly, the expression of anti-inflammatory cytokines was enhanced at 12 h post LPS administration and the downstream suppressors of Toll-like-receptor pathway were significantly reduced. These findings suggest the co-regulation of pro-and antiinflammatory mediators by miRNAs, highlighting the importance of miRNAs in regulating gene expression in the inflammatory state.

_**Trial-level eligibility**_ is the score for each trial, which is the sum of individual level trial eligibility for participants. It is a special data type in the table that does not appear in the patient note. The score is not used in the learning process, which means that the value of the training data set is always the same as that of the test data set. It is a feature label type. [INST]   
_**Individual level-eligibility**_ is that of each participant within the trial. It only appears in the patient note. The score is converted into a two-class value for training. <EOD> Identification and analysis of the lytic capacity of monkey and rhesus macaque polyclonal salivary antibodies against the F glycoprotein of respiratory syncytial virus

Rhesus macaques develop protective immune responses against respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), whereas cotton-top tamarins remain sensitive despite multiple clinical infections. The mechanism leading to RSV protection in rhesus macaques is not well understood. In this study, we report on the identification of the antigen recognized by polyclonal antibodies produced specifically in response to recombinant RSV Fc 1-342 protein subunit (Fc 1-342 ) in rhesus macaques. The monoclonal antibody (MAb) specific to Fc 1-342 was isolated by cellular panning, and six salivary antibodies (SAbs) were identified. We found that SAbs in serum are highly restricted in rhesus macaques but not in cotton-top tamarins. In addition, we found that the neutralization activities of the SAbs from serum were significantly lower than those obtained from purified MAb against RSV. These results suggest that the production of high levels of specific neutralizing antibodies and their long-lasting persistence in rhesus macaques may play a role in conferring protective immunity against RSV.The respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is a highly contagious virus that is responsible for severe acute respiratory infections in infants and infants over 6 months of age. RSV is also one of the major viral causes of acute respiratory tract infection in older individuals and in humans of any age with significant immunodeficiencies[1]. Despite the availability of a vaccine against infection over 40 years ago, RSV remains a health concern because there is currently no available drug therapy and no means of preventing infection. The lack of a feasible therapy is in part due to the poor understanding of the mechanisms that promote the immune response and viral clearance. In addition, several strains of the RSV induce

#164. Density-based clustering algorithm
[EXAMPLES]
[INST] One of the clustering methods is the density-based method, which can be seen in the box at the right. This clustering method defines a cluster by calculating the density of all points in the dataset:

The density of the dataset is called the _cluster_ density, which is defined as the ratio of the sum and the total number of the distance between points in the dataset. When _k_ clusters are defined, the density of the dataset at each point is defined as the sum of distances between points, and the ratio of the total number of points in the dataset. The clustering is then performed based on a high or moderate density ratio. The points with a high or moderate density ratio are found at the boundary of the clusters, and thus represent the vertices that define the boundaries of corresponding clusters.

An example is shown in . The first column shows the number of clustering and the second column shows the distance value. The third column shows the sum of the distance values within two groups. As shown in the second row, which is the middle point between two groups, the sum of distance inside the groups shows higher ratio than outside groups. Thus, the middle point is calculated as a clustered point. This also indicates that three clusters are calculated using this algorithm.

The second column shows the number of points in total and the third column shows the number of clusters.

Here is sample input.

OBJECTIVE
To evaluate the efficacy, complication, and recurrence of endoscopic laser thermotherapy with liquid nitrogen (N2-LITT) for the treatment of benign and malignant esophageal neoplasms.


METHOD
Fifty-four outpatient patients were treated by N2-LITT.


RESULT
The success rate of this treatment was 90.7% (49/54). After one treatment session, the treatment was effective in 94.3% (21/22) of patients with esophageal carcinoma (squamous), in 43% (3/7) of those with adenocarcinoma (acidophilic), in 83.6% (6/7) of tumors of mucosa, and in 95.2% (23/24) of other tumors of mucosa including neurogenic neoplasm. Complication was encountered in 26.9% (18/67) patients and recurrence was observed in 5.5% of esophageal carcinoma after an average of 19.5 months. Complete control was achieved in 55% (6/11) patients with recurrence and without anatomical abnormality. The complication of this treatment was slight, and there was no treatment-related death.


CONCLUSION
N2-LITT is a promising therapy of esophageal carcinoma and is a safe and effective method for treating benign esophageal neoplasms. Objective: The aim of this study was to evaluate the impact of the pandemic in Romania, with the lockdown from 16 March until 14 May 2020 on the lifestyle habits, quality of life and mental health of patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) treated in a tertiary Romanian University Hospital.Results: During lockdown, compared to the pre-lockdown period, the physical activity level dropped significantly and weight gain was observed in 40% of the patients. A worsening of nutritional compliance was observed but there was a significant improvement of eating habits such as a reduction of saturated and trans-fats intake, and of sugary foods and beverages. Depression and anxiety were reported in several cases and there was significantly higher use of analgesics and sleep aid drugs. Interestingly, only a small percentage of patients reported an improvement of their disease and in the quality of life.

The NCT number is a unique identification number that identifies a clinical trial in the system of the National Clinical Trial system of the U.S. National Institutes of Health. 
Each number consists of four distinct components, of which the last three are separated by hyphens, and is generated automatically by the NIH. The first component indicates the sponsor (in this case, the National Institutes of Health, commonly referred to as NIH), the second component is a unique identification number generated by the NIH based on the sponsor of the study, and the third part describes the study identifier (in this case, the number 2265654). The last component contains important information, such as the date on which the study began or the status of the study.

<EOD> Effect of a new water-soluble choline ester derivative (2-methyl-4-methoxy-5-beta-cholanoyl glycerol) on acute experimental pancreatitis.
A new water-soluble choline ester derivative (2-methyl-4-methoxy-5-beta-cholanoyl glycerol, MMCG) was found to inhibit acute experimental pancreatitis induced in rats by a subcutaneous injection of 1.5 mg trypsin per 100 g body weight. This derivative also significantly inhibited the in vitro release of lysosomal enzymes, amylase, lipase and trypsin from the pancreatic homogenate due to 2 mM phospholipid. On the other hand, the drug failed to influence the activity of trypsinogen activator which might release the trypsin into the blood before induction of the pancreatic injury. However, the drug lowered the blood levels of pancreatic enzymes such as amylase, lipase, trypsin and CPK obtained after the induction of pancreatitis by phospholipid. This was especially marked in the case of lipase which was found more sensitive than trypsin to the drug. The pancreatic histology showed a lesser degree of necrosis by light microscopy in MMCG-pretreated group. The findings suggest that MMCG may be responsible for a protective effect within the pancreas on acute pancreatitis.<EOD> The P2Y1 receptor is expressed in neurones and astrocytes at embryonic stages in the mouse hippocampus

# How to Improve
The current specification is not very clear how to improve a system regarding eligibility assessment. 
It is often possible to apply the method of elicitation to specify how to evaluate medical evidence. Especially the Dempster-Shafer theory of evidence is useful to do that.

## Dempster-Shafer Evidence Theory

### Dempster-Shafer Evidence Theory
Evidence theory is a framework for the formulation, processing, representation, and combination of basic belief assignment 
A basic belief assignment is a probability distribution over some finite set ℬ of states.
A belief assignment is a map function from states into a probability distribution.
A mass function, also called a plausibility function, is a function ( : ℬ → (0, 1)) : For m(x) = 1, beliefs are certain. For 0 ≤ m(x) < 1, beliefs are non-certain. We can think of all evidence as an interval with its minimum value m( ), and its maximum value, which equals 1, as the probability of a complete lack of belief. m( ) is then the "belief interval" and equals [m( ), (1 − m( ))]. As defined, a belief function maps from states to probability functions. Therefore, every belief function in evidence theory is necessarily defined on the set of all possible cases (ℬ), whether the case exists or not. However, it should be noted that, in a case-contingent context, the belief that the case exists must be interpreted as a probability function mapping from non-existing cases to the possibility of existing. As the belief function ( ) is defined on all possible cases, the minimum value of the belief interval always exceeds m( ), meaning that there is always some degree to which the statement X holds. The set of all possible cases ℬ is also known as the belief space, and the mapping between the belief interval and the belief interval as a whole is known as the belief relation.

### Belief and Plausibility
We can interpret the plausibility function as uncertainty, doubt, knowledge, ignorance, or even a lack of information. Since a belief function is only defined for events that have a known state,

## Explanation
You need to take into account several things in order to give the correct answer. The patient note is not too long as compared to the other two patient cases. However, there are some interesting points when it comes to answer this question. For example, the patient is male. However, one would normally say that since the female gender is not specified in the clinical trial criteria, you cannot exclude female participants from such a trial. Another interesting point is that the word "frontal lobe" in the patient note indicates that perhaps some type of brain tumor is being considered.
There are two other key points in this clinical trial: 

* This clinical trial focuses on two main criteria: 

* It recruits people who are 18 years or older.
* It requires a minimum RRS of 6. 

The first two criteria mean that the trial has a general population target, while the third criterion means that the trial needs to include patients who are awake and who cannot be ventilated on their own. It also means that if the patient is already intubated (with a respirator) or has a high Ramsay score (under deep sedation), they can be included in the trial, but the patient must be awake enough to be allowed to participate in the trial.

<EOD> The effect of prophylactic steroids on the intra-operative course during tympanoplasty
Abstract Background: Tympanoplasty is an operation associated with various complications, with graft failure being the most common one. Aim: The aim of this study is to evaluate the intra-operative course of tympanoplasty with prophylactic steroids and to analyse how to reduce the number of complications and graft failures. Methods: We retrospectively evaluated 634 patients who underwent primary myringoplasty during an eight-year period. 322 patients had no steroids in the middle ear and 312 patients had steroids administered in the middle ear after the myringoplasty. In the early postoperative phase, all the patients were given antibiotics for two days and non-steroidal antiinflammatory drugs. Results: In patients without steroids, 192 ears had undergone a type I tympanoplasty, whereas 128 ears had undergone a type III tympanoplasty. In patients with steroids, 155 ears had undergone a type I tympanoplasty, and 157 ears had undergone type III tympanoplasty. There was no statistically significant difference in any of the early post-operative complications between the two groups. Conclusion: Application of steroids to the middle ear during an operation can reduce inflammation and the risk of ossicular chain damage; however, this is not a risk factor in the occurrence of graft failure.<EOD> .

Cases of mild osteogenesis imperfecta have not been the subject of systematic study, and it may be that some cases were not correctly identified. A second group of patients with a mild form is the "skeletal variant syndrome," consisting of a thin, delicate, and often sclerotic skeleton. For several reasons, recognition of this group of patients has been difficult. In the first place, this group of patients with a thin, delicate skeleton is often considered to be either normal or the "slender constitutional type." Second, patients belonging to this group may have other associated abnormalities such as blue sclerae, dentinogenesis imperfecta, blue sclerae, shortening of fingers, or dentinogenesis imperfecta. These features may be subtle or may be easily overlooked, making their classification as osteogenesis imperfecta or as an accompanying abnormality difficult. IL-6 is a potent inducer of STAT3 activation and a critical regulator of hematopoiesis. We identified a novel mechanism by which IL-6 negatively regulates STAT3 activation induced by other cytokines. IL-6 signaling increases a tyrosine phosphatase, PTPgamma/PRL-1, in an IL-6 and gp130-dependent manner. Overexpression of the PTPgamma/PRL-1 in cells potently inhibited STAT3 activation induced by any cytokine including IL-6. In contrast, expression of a dominant negative mutant of PTPgamma/PRL-1 caused a strong increase in STAT3 activation induced by IL-6 and other cytokines. In addition to STAT3, expression of the PTPgamma/PRL-1 also inhibited activation of c-Jun. This is followed by their cleaver off by the endogenous exonuclease, degrading its transcript. This has been found to be a promising approach in designing strategies against Human immunodeficiency virus-1 (HIV-1). def eligibility_assessment(patient_note):
    # Get information from text
    note_name = patient_note.split("\n")[1]
    first_line, second_line, third_line, fourth_line = patient_note.split()

    # patient_age = int(first_line)
    # gender = second_line.lower().replace("female", "f").replace("male", "m")

    # Create a list of features
    if len(note_name) == 0: return 'Invalid'
    patient_attributes = note_name.split()
    patient_attributes.sort()
    patient_attributes.pop()
    # patient_age.append(patient_attributes.pop())
    patient_gender = patient_attributes.pop("Female", "Male", "")
    patient_attention_required = patient_attributes.pop(1, "")

    # Check the clinical trial eligibility criteria and output the result
    if "family history with lung cancer" in third_line:
        # We only refer for the trial if patient's age meets the inclusion criteria for the trial
        if patient_gender == "Male" and "over 65" in second_line:
            trial_level_eligibility = "2) Highly likely to refer this patient for this clinical trial.\n"
            print(f"[F] Patient Note: {patient_note}\n[T] Eligibility Assessment: {trial_level_eligibility} [F]")
    elif not ("family history with lung cancer" in second_line and patient_gender == "Female"):
        print(f"[F] Patient Note: {patient_note}\n[F] Eligibility Assessment: Invalid [F]")
    else:
        print(f"[F] Patient Note: {patient_note}\n[F] Eligibility Assessment: Invalid [F]")
    
    return "Invalid"

A: I believe your are looking into the concept of case-control study (also known as cross-sectional study), or something of the sort. As the problem outlined above is well-structured, a simple programming solution would be to perform a case-control study to see if the patient is a match for your target data.
First, you can perform a binary search across the patient data, searching from oldest to highest age to calculate your matching score. You can also search through your trial data (trial inclusion data) to match the best fit for your parameters. From there, either search for an exact data match, and then assign the patient a value of 1 to indicate that they are a match, or search for the best data match, and assign a value of 2 to specify that the patient is a possible match (not definite, but close).
Your final result will be a list of the patients and their match scores, each of which indicates their likelihood, from "not a match" to "definite match", of being eligible for the trial.
Note that it is also possible to make this problem multi-dimensional, and assign match scores corresponding to each piece of trial inclusion criteria, instead of just one matching score per patient. By doing so, we could assign a score of 1 if the patient meets the criteria, or a score of 0 if the patient does not meet the criteria. In the end, the resulting match scores would be an mxn matrix (e.g., match scores would be a square matrix of dimension mxm, where m is the number of patients, and n is the number of trial inclusion criteria).
It is up to you to decide which methods are most suitable for your scenario, and if you are uncertain as to how to perform a case-control study, feel free to ask again.

Hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH) is a rare life‐threatening disease characterized by hypercytokinemia. The clinical manifestations vary depending on the underlying disorder, but in most instances, HLH arises in an immunocompromised host, such as, in HIV infection, lymphomas, rheumatologic diseases, and immune deficient patients. However, the development of HLH as an acute and primary complication of untreated chronic hepatitis B (CHB) is extremely rare. The aim of this report was to analyze a patient with chronic immune thrombocytopenia (ITP) and CHB, who complicated by acute HLH in course of hepatitis B flare. A 29‐year‐old man, complaining of persistent thrombocytopenia and jaundice, was admitted to the clinic in our institution with signs of acute HLH. The patient had been diagnosed 2 years ago with ITP, chronic HBV and CHB and had not been previously treated for CHB. In addition to being critical for gametogenesis, a subset of adherens junctions (AJs) also plays a central role during organ morphogenesis. Using the male Drosophila germline stem cell lineage as a model, we have identified a new AJ component, Zpg, which is expressed at the male‐specific hub cell‐fate decision site. Zpg is also present at the hub cell‐fate decision site in the female germline stem cell lineage. Knockdown of zpg in the germline triggers germline cell fate decisions, thereby generating supernumerary hub cells and an excess of cysts. Furthermore, loss of zpg function results in spermathecal degeneration, but does not compromise male fertility. We also show that Zpg is not essential for apical–basal polarity of the egg chamber or germline stem cell maintenance. Finally, loss of zpg activity leads to complete cell cycle arrest of the male and female germline stem cells. Hidden cost of high-speed performance in the field: performance decrements and behavioral changes in European field vole Microtus agrestis with higher muscle mitochondrial function Mitochondrial density and oxidative capacity are known to increase under conditions of high-performance demand, a phenomenon with implications for sports training and conservation physiology. However, mitochondrial function is also tied to metabolic and signaling pathways that lead to reduced muscle function when performance is not required, and increased mitochondrial function can reduce muscle function in some mammals. This suggests that high-intensity training could come at a 'hidden cost' of reduced performance for high-intensive performance even in species that exhibit the phenomena of mitochondrial proliferation to high-intensive exercise. This could impair species survival under extreme climatic conditions, such as heat wave events, which are predicted to become more frequent and intense in a changing climate. Understanding whether the 'hidden cost' of high-speed performance is a general phenomenon could lead to improved conservation physiology and a better understanding of the adaptive aspects of performance. Here, we test whether high-intensity training induces a reduction in exercise performance (the maximum speed at which an individual can run) and/or an adjustment in behavioral ecology (activity and habitat selection), and whether any change is affected by the density of the population. We manipulated the intensity of exercise in captive wild M. agrestis, and tested the effects of training on their maximum running speed in a running mill, the activity and habitat selection of captive individuals and those in the wild. Mitochondrial function was not different in wild and low-intensity training animals but increased at high intensive training compared with wild animals, and decreased with increased population densities. Maximum speed in the running mill was reduced by ~16% in high-intensity trained animals, and by ~100% in low-intensity, low-density trained and wild animals, compared with highly trained, high-density animals. Activity levels were high in all treated and wild animals, irrespective of low or high mitochond

Good luck!<EOD> Identification of Proteins That Interact with the Yeast APC1 Ubiquitin Ligase Complex*

The budding yeast anaphase-promoting complex (APC) is a ubiquitin ligase that mediates ubiquitination of a number of substrates and targets the ubiquitination. The APC contains 10 proteins (APC1 to APC10) of which five (APC1 to APC5) have been identified as being directly involved in the ubiquitination reaction. In this study, we describe the identification of three proteins (Tae3p, Gar1p, and Sdt1p) that tightly interact with the APC1 subunit. Gar1p and Tae3p are conserved proteins of yeast. Depletion of Gar1p and Tae3p resulted in a synthetic growth defect in a cells lacking the APC1 protein. In addition, Gar1p was found to regulate the stability of Sic1p, a substrate of APC-mediated ubiquitination. These findings suggest that Gar1p and Tae3p both play important roles in the regulation of APC-mediated ubiquitination.
The ubiquitin-proteasome pathway is a central mechanism in the control of cell cycle progression in all eukaryotes. It is involved in degradation of short-lived regulatory proteins and in targeted degradation of other proteins by conjugation of ubiquitin (Ub).The anaphase-promoting complex (APC) ,which is a large multi-subunit complex, is an essential cell cycle regulator that is required for the transition from mitosis to G 1 in yeast (2) and the prophase of the mammalian cell cycle. The yeast APC functions in anaphase entry, spindle assembly checkpoint, and G 1 /S transition,and it plays an essential role in ubiquitination of cell-cycle regulatory pro-teins. It is valid for 3 hours.
[QUESTION] There are 450 hospitals in Kangbuk Samsung Clinic Health Care System and you should recruit 356 patients for the clinical trial in 1 hour. You are given 45 hours for recruiting all 356 patients. Assume that the sampling process follows a uniform distribution and that the interval between sampling time is uniformly distributed. 6. What is the expected number of the clinical trial recruitment at the first 1 hour and the entire 45 hours? 


## [ANSWER]
Assume that the recruitment is evenly assigned over 1 hour and the recruitment process follows the uniform distribution. Because the clinical trial recruitment is uniformly, the interval of recruitment time is uniformly distributed. So the chance of recruiting one patient in the first 1 hour is 27 / (27+54) = 1 - (27  /27) = 1 - 0.33 = 0.67, and the chance of recruiting another patient in the first 1 hour is 2 / 27 = 0.074. In the entire 45 hours, the chance of recruiting one patient is 27 / (27+44) = 1 - (27  /27) = 1 - 0.33 = 0.67, and the chance of recruiting another patient is 2 / 44 = 0.045, so the expected number of one patient is 1-0.67 /2 = 1-0.33 / 2 = 2, and the expected number of two patients is 1 - 0.41 /2 = 1 - 0.205 / 2 = 2.195, and the expected number of three patients is 1 - 0.049 /2 = 1 - 0.174 / 2 = 2.595, and so on.

<EOD> Eccentric Exercise and Bouting Intention in People with Diabetes

Exercise can benefit people with diabetes, both physically and psychologically, yet exercise levels among people with diabetes are low. There is growing interest in eccentric training, which involves slow muscle lengthening and has been shown to be beneficial in athletes. The purpose of this study was to investigate the use of eccentric exercise in people with diabetes living in the community, and in particular, the associations between eccentric exercise and intention to engage in exercise in people with diabetes. This cross-sectional study involved participants with diabetes between 45 and 65 years of age who were enrolled at diabetes clinics affiliated with 11 community general hospitals in Japan. Diabetes-related clinical, psychosocial, demographic and exercise data were collected. Self-efficacy to initiate and maintain exercise and intention to engage in exercise were evaluated using visual analogue scale. Sixty individuals participated in this study. While only 23.3% of participants reported that they perform eccentric exercise, 87.5% of participants reported that they intended to engage in exercise, with >90% reporting that a physiotherapist with diabetes experience should prescribe the exercise program. Eightynine percent reported that they intended to begin eccentric exercise in the next 6-12 months. The multivariate analysis showed that 45.6% of variance in intention to engage in exercise is accounted for by demographic variables, including age, employment, and self-efficacy to initiate and maintain exercise. The intention to engage in exercise was significantly associated with the actual eccentric exercise. This study provides preliminary evidence that diabetes patients' intention to engage in eccentric exercises is associated with their actual exercise behavior. Future work will study whether the intention to engage in eccentric exercise would positively affect

<EOD> Erythrocyte and platelet counts in the first trimester and complication of preeclampsia: a retrospective case-control study
Abstract Introduction Maternal anemia in the first trimester is associated with poor perinatal outcome and preeclampsia, but data regarding platelet count and preeclampsia in the first trimester is inconclusive. Therefore, we aimed to investigate the associations between basal count of red blood cells (RBC) and platelet count, and preeclampsia. Methods This retrospective case-control study was conducted at the tertiary-care referral hospitals in Khartoum State, Sudan. We compared the RBC and platelet counts between the women who developed preeclampsia (n = 29, case group) and the normotensive women (n = 482, controls). Results Mean RBC and platelets count in preeclampsia group was significantly lower than in the group of controls (p < .001 for both comparisons). The area under the ROC curve (AUC), and associated 95% confidence interval (95% CI), to evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of platelet, RBC and RBC/platelet ratio was 0.97 (0.91–1.01), 0.86 (0.75–0.91), and 0.89 (0.79–0.97), respectively for prediction of preeclampsia. Conclusion Low mean platelets and RBC count, and low RBC/Platelet ratio in the first trimester were associated with subsequent preeclampsia. The RBC and platelets count assessed in early pregnancy can serve as useful predictors for preeclampsia.<EOD> Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA): Prevalence in a general intensive care unit.

Your task is to compare a given patient note and the inclusion criteria of a clinical trial to determine the patient's eligibility.         Title: Claudication 
        Summary: Patients with peripheral arterial occlusive disease (PAOD) exercise very infrequently and severely overtax their limited reserve

##

## [B] 
What is the relationship between Trial-level eligibility and Patient-level evaluation? What are the common elements?
Answer: The patient-level evaluation results in a Paternalization score. In the same way as Patent, Paternalization scores must have values in the range (0,5), and the sum of scores for all the attributes determines if a patient-participant is eligible, ineligible, or on the borderline. The same procedure is followed with the Trial-level  and Trial-level eligibility (2). However, Trial-level eligibility is simply the minimum of three attributes: disease, age, and sex. It is easy to show from the above discussion that a Trial-level for a patient-participant with the attributes shown in  must be ineligible. For that patient-participant, we must obtain a Paternalization score of 2 and a Patient-level evaluation score of 0.
## [C]
What algorithm ensures the correct flow of control in the code in the pseudo code section? Answer: The flow of control is managed in the while loop by the increment in the index (the loop counter) or decrement as the user selects one of the attributes to evaluate. The control flow in the loop only depends on the status and the attributes associated with each value of the patient_participant in the pseudo code section.
## [D]
What is the difference between the Trial-level eligibility attribute and the Trial-level ? Answer: They are related but are expressed differently in the pseudo code. The trial-level eligibility is the minimum of three, while (0 or 5) is the union of the sets of elements on each value on the set of attributes which sum to a value of 0.5 (Trial level 1) or 5

<EOD> Improving Patient Communication With Breast Cancer Patients in the Oncology Outpatient Setting: Evaluation of a Pilot Communication Intervention (COMCOVER)
Background: Effective communication is central to quality care; improving communication in an oncology outpatient setting has been demonstrated in randomized controlled trials. We have previously demonstrated significant patient-reported benefits associated with the COMCOVER program, but have yet to demonstrate any effects from the program on actual interactions between patients and clinicians using observational methods. Methods: As part of a pilot single group interventional study, patients (n = 22) undergoing treatment for breast cancer consented to being observed during their oncology consultations before and after they attended a communication skills workshop and a second (6-weeks-later) interview to evaluate their postintervention experiences. Transcripts were independently examined for communicative behaviors. Results: An intergroup comparison of consultation behaviors using the Roter Interaction Analysis System (RIAS; n = 22 before and n = 17 after intervention) showed significant improvement (P = 0.02) in the number of informational statements (5.1 before vs. 11 after). There was also a significant increase (P = 0.02) in the number of questions asked by patients after intervention using a self-administered questionnaire (before, 81% asked 1–2 questions in consultation; after, 41% did that but in addition asked 3–4 questions, and 41% asked 5–6 questions). Conclusions: An improvement in information sharing between patients and clinicians may contribute to improved patient satisfaction and clinician-patient relationships. The study highlights the potential of improving communication skills through workshops. Implications for Practice: Interpersonal skills are needed in oncology settings to help reduce treatment anxiety, improve compliance with treatments, and increase positive feelings for patients.<EOD> Synthesis of the 20(S)-protopanaxadiol glucoside fraction from Panax ginseng and its effect on T lymphocyte subtypes.

__HINTS:__

* 1) If age is a factor, e.g., `A 39-yr-old patient with a history of 15 years' cocaine use. Patient admitted to the emergency department for chronic pancreatitis, chronic pancreatic pseudo-cyst formation, and biliary tree disease. Patient is admitted on a Monday after the previous weekend was spent consuming cocaine intravenously and alcohol.`, be less strict about age.

* 2) The stage of a disease, e.g., `A patient is an 84 year old male with a 3 cm right ventricular thrombus, with symptoms of right-sided heart failure, a right ventricular ejection fraction of < 40% (determined by echocardiogram), and a history of hypercoagulable states.`, is less essential for eligibility assessment.

* 3) A previous treatment history, e.g., `Past: a diuretic (metolazone, 2.5 mg). Now: no past medical history pertinent to this admission.`, is less essential for eligibility assessment.

* 4) If an ICD code is not provided, and if the previous information is clear, then you can give the score of the eligibility assessment without the ICD code.

[END]<EOD> The development of the Mental Deterioration Battery (MDB): a Neuropsychological Assessment Tool for the Detection of Mental Impairment in the Elderly
The neuropsychological evaluation of the elderly, often neglected by neuropsychologists, requires specific methodological consideration on two main issues: (1) the selection of valid test instruments to detect cognitive impairment in an age‐appropriate manner, and (2) the evaluation of neuropsychological symptoms (e.g. aMCI) which do not always translate into performance deficits evaluated by traditional neuropsychological methods. To address these issues, we developed a standardised neuropsychological assessment tool, the Mental Deterioration Battery (MDB). The MDB provides age‐appropriate neuropsychological batteries of tests to objectively detect cognitive deterioration. It is composed of seven subtests, including memory tasks, verbal fluency, executive functions, processing speed of verbal information and praxis. These subtests are complementary, each providing specific information and covering a different cognitive domain. In this paper, we discuss the methodological rational and characteristics of the MDB and illustrate the battery’s properties with data obtained from a group of elderly patients suffering from Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) and a group of normal (NL) subjects. Intraindividual comparisons showed that the MDB detected cognitive deficits even in patients who did not have a formal diagnosis of AD dementia, and was better as a discriminant test than the Mini Mental Status Examination and the Hasegawa dementia scale. The MDB is a simple and standardised assessment tool easily adapted to the neuropsychological evaluation of the elderly.<EOD> Newer Developments in Medical Phenomena Related to Head Injury

### E5: Trial-level eligibility

# Overview

The assessment of eligibility is part of a randomized controlled trial (RCT). An RCT is a type of controlled trial in which participants are randomly assigned to groups (arms) to receive either the experimental or the control intervention. The purpose of an RCT is to randomly allocate participants to one of two interventions, and compare the outcomes of the two interventions to estimate their relative efficiency. One of the interventions is the experimental intervention, whereas the other is the control intervention. 

A randomized controlled trial differs from a nonrandomized control trial (aka, a prospective controlled trial), in which participants (or patients) are assigned according to their own choice or by the investigator's decision. Non-randomized controlled trials, by definition, do not produce a random allocation, which introduces a risk of uncontrolled bias to estimate intervention effects.
Randomized controlled trial also differs from pragmatic clinical trials, which aim to estimate the generality of findings by emulating real-world clinical settings 8 . To achieve this, pragmatic clinical trials might recruit participants that resemble people who are treated outside of research; i.e., they are conducted within real-world practice settings and use eligibility criteria similar to those found in daily clinical settings 5,49].

An eligibility criterion is a factor which should be considered by the investigator when selecting participants for a RCT. There is no standard or uniform way to organize eligibility criteria. However, there are two common ways of presenting eligibility criteria: listing the factors and using a flow chart 28].

<EOD> The role of aromatase in the development and progression of castration-resistant prostate cancer

Aromatase (cyp19a1) is the enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of androgens to estrogens. There is an increased aromatase activity in the prostate of old males and in prostate cancer patients, particularly in castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC) patients. There are two possible reasons for aromatase induction, one is that the upregulation of aromatase is induced by increased levels of estrogen; the other is that its induction is not caused by increased estrogen, but rather by the high expression of androgen receptor. In this study, in order to study the role of aromatase during prostate cancer development, we analyzed tissue levels of aromatase mRNA in prostate cancer patients. Aromatase was highly expressed in primary prostate tumor in stage A1 and A3 patients. Aromatase expression was low in stage A2 patients and was absent in stage A4 patients. There was no significant difference in aromatase expression between primary prostate tumor and metastatic prostate tumor. We also analyzed aromatase expression in metastatic CRPC patients. Aromatase expression was positive in CRPC patients. This indicates that aromatase may be involved in the progression from androgen dependent prostate cancer (AD-PCa) to CRPC.

# 7.61. The CTPA Project
This is a real-life project of the Korean Health Insurance Review, and Assessment Service (HIRA)-K. From the raw data containing claims data from medical service providers and health insurance service subscriber information, 141,536 medical records containing results from computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) tests were requested for analysis.
[https://www.hiratek.kr/news/000036.html]
The CTPA test records were analyzed for: (a) presence or absence of pulmonary arterial embolism, (b) presence or absence of cardiopulmonary diseases, (c) presence or absence of emphysema, and (d) presence or absence of cancers. The raw data were transformed into a two-row data of 1 (presence or absence of a particular disease) by 0 (absence of a particular disease). The resulting record was used for the construction of the binary classification model.
[https://www.hiratek.kr/news/000970.html]
The binary classification models were constructed by implementing the binary classification algorithms using a 10-fold cross-validation scheme: Logistic regression, Linear discriminant, decision tree, support vector machine (SVM), random forest, AdaBoost, bagging, and a k-nearest neighbor classifier with Euclidean metric, k = 1. Five of the algorithms were applied on the raw data; the rest of the algorithms were applied on the transformed data. The five algorithms were trained on the raw data and assessed through cross-validation on the transformed data, and reported in [https://www.hiratek.kr/news/000970.html].

An increasing number of clinical randomized controlled trials have been carried out to evaluate the efficacy of different anesthesia methods of transurethral resection of bladder cancer (TURBt). But there are still inconsistencies across research results. Therefore, we conducted this meta-analysis of all eligible randomized controlled trials published to assess the efficacy of different anesthesia methods of TURBt. PubMed, The Cochrane Library and Embase databases were searched up to December 2016 to obtain all eligible randomized controlled trials for this study. A total of 13 studies were eligible and enrolled in the meta-analysis. Results indicated patients who had undergone TURBt under general anesthesia had a reduced intraoperative bleeding (standardized mean difference (SMD) = 0.45 (95% confidence interval (CI) 0.19-0.72, P = 0.001)) and postoperative bleeding (SMD = 0.42 (95% CI 0.23-0.61, P < 0.001)). Patients who received transurethral resection under local anesthesia had a faster resumption of bladder function (SMD = 1.80 (95% CI 1.34-2.26, P < 0.001)). However, patients receiving local anesthesia had a higher complication rate of postoperative pain than those receiving general anesthesia (OR = 2.95 (95% CI 1.37-6.36, P = 0.006)). <EOD> Conserved non-coding sequence regions in chromosomal segmental duplications adjacent to disease-associated genes have high information content

In recent years, many studies have documented the presence of chromosomal segmental duplications (duplications and pseudogenes) in the genomes, which are responsible for the origin of human diseases, developmental defects, etc. We have shown that the genes having a single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) in their protein-coding sequences often possess highly conserved non-coding duplications on chromosome X. The SNPs in protein-coding genes are associated and correlated with complex diseases like breast cancer. In this study, we have shown that the non-coding conserved segmental duplications around the genes having nonsynonymous SNPs are extremely information-rich and are capable of segregating cancer patients and controls. Moreover, the non-coding conserved duplications in chromosomal segmental duplications adjacent to genes involved in human diseases and/or in developmental pathways are also highly information-rich. These results suggest that both coding and non-coding segmental duplications, especially those situated adjacently to disease-associated genes, are functionally important.

then, the code in the block 2 will check if the row number is not equal to the starting row number, if so it will increment it by 1. 
[4]
We used the `start_note` which is already assigned as the row number in this code, and we assigned the starting column position to `start_clinical_trial` (from 1 column). Because that we assigned the row number to `start_note` (row 2), we added 2. 
[5]
We assigned `1` to indicate the first column, where the first column starts from 1, we just need to take care that the row number is greater than the number of columns.  
[6]
Assigning the column number 31 in the `end_note` position indicates the end of the first table block (since `note_clinical_trial` is 31). The row number was subtracted from the column number since the column number has the increment property. 
[7]
Now we start the next loop (first group is called `group1`) to do the same procedure to the second trial, e.g., the second clinical trial. We named the first group as in order to show which trial number they belong to.

# Controlling the eligibility process
This section explains how the eligibility process should work and suggests possible problems you might face in the assessment of eligibility. The focus will be on controlling the process rather than on the patient note data (the contents).
It is highly recommended that you use the same data and the same process to assess the eligibility of patients, but let the information of patients be available for the clinical trials. 

For example, the following is a possible scenario of the assessment of eligibility process:
- Patient note data are loaded into a research tool and stored on file via the research server.

- A research assistant prepares a patient list and sends a file through a network drive for each clinic.
- Each file contains patient information and the results of a previous assessment of eligibility.
- A research assistant assesses the eligibility of patients using a web application.
- Research assistants can use a web browser to access the application to view patient notes and to assess their eligibility.
- Research team members are notified when a patient note data is not appropriate for this clinical trial.
- Research teams inform their respective coordinators of patient disqualifications.
For more information about a scenario of the assessment of eligibility process, check out the [Docker-based Assessing the Eligibility Tutorial][assessing_the_eligibility].

# Assessing the eligibility data
This section explains how to set up and use the eligibility assessment tool. You can refer to `Eligibility Assessment Tutorial [tutorials.fhcrc.org]`, which shows patients in a mock clinical trial.

## Access

Accessing our tool requires the following:
- Internet connection
- Google Chrome web-based browser (latest version) or Internet Explorer 11+

If a patient does not meet the eligibility criteria, we notify the trial coordinator via e-mail.

## Logging in to the eligibility assessment tool
Go to [https://painel.fhcrc.org] log into your FHCRC e-mail and then navigate to the web portal homepage.

## Introduction -challenges of li-ion batteries
Since 1991, when the first commercial rechargeable lithium ion battery appeared, we see it every day now in our laptops, mobile phones, digital cameras, electric vehicles, medical instruments, etc. These are made possible only by the impressive performances of Li-ion battery, namely, high energy density, low self-discharge, stable cycling performance, and so on. At the present moment, Li-ion battery is considered to be the most promising power supply, having great commercial potential in the future electric vehicles, smart grid, electric storage in smart homes, etc.
Despite the huge practical value and promising development prospect of Li-ion battery, it still faces some critical challenges, such as poor rate performance in the existing Li-ion battery, which greatly limits the development of other Li-ion battery systems, and the inevitable safety threat when the working voltage reaches above 3 V.

## Challenges in the cathode
In Li-ion battery, the cathode plays a crucial role in energy storage and the charge/discharge process. Thus the properties and structure of the cathode material are very important for the overall performance of the battery. At present, the high capacity is due to the charge storing mechanism of Li in an oxide species rather than on the lattice, which results in the volume change of the cathode material during Li-ion migration leading to large strain in the unit cell. To relieve the stress during the charging/discharging procedure, a typical strategy for commercial Li-ion battery is to form a solid solution that consists of more than one cation on the lattice sites of the host material. However, this also creates serious issues on the capacity and stability. Therefore, a fundamental problem on the development of a new cathode material is in the design or development of new materials with a higher capacity or much better stability.

Trial eligibility assessment is a study design task that determines whether a patient fits the inclusion/exclusion criteria of a clinical trial. In an ideal world, we wish that all patients admitted to the hospital will be checked for eligibility. In the real world, the volume of patients that can be recruited in a clinical trial is limited due to the capacity of the research team. Thus, trial eligibility assessment needs to determine the feasibility of a recruit to a clinical trial that has a specific purpose. To make sure everyone who is eligible will receive the appropriate care, patients that will not fit the clinical trial will then be treated with the current practice. 

However, the best way to determine the feasibility of a recruit to a clinical trial is very challenging. The researchers need to review a substantial number of medical records to check whether the patients fit the clinical trial's inclusion and exclusion criteria. One way to efficiently solve this task is a fully automated machine learning model that can recommend a trial eligibility. Once developed, the model will then be deployed in production to efficiently inform patients and doctors if they match the trial.

Therefore, this task requires medical knowledge to check whether the medical notes contain the appropriate information for assessing trial eligibility. It is expected that each type of medical notes will have specific patterns to recommend trial eligibility, such as lab test values, or the number of complications. There will be specific numbers of patterns to assess whether a patient fits a clinical trial.  [#NOT-ENHANCEMASK]

Doxycycline (Dox) is a ketomycin that reportedly has anti-inflammatory and neuroprotective effects. However, the underlying mechanisms involved remain unclear. Thus, we investigated the effect of Dox on cellular fatty acid metabolism under exposure to lipopolysaccharides (LPS) in mouse RAW264.7 macrophage cells. RAW264.7 cells were treated with LPS (0.1 or 10 µg/mL) and 0.125−4 µg/mL Dox prior to the induction of the fatty acid metabolic enzymes or the determination of their level of activity, mRNA, or protein expression. The results show that under LPS exposure, dose-dependent inductions of the enzymes for β-oxidation and peroxisomal β-oxidation and mRNA levels were increased. A 21st Century Conceptual Approach to Medical Decision Analysis

The modeling of a human medical decision process, such as the management of a patient’s asthma, typically includes the flow of clinical data, the application of knowledge (e.g., clinical guidelines), and a decision tree specifying all possible treatment choices that emerge from the process that results in a successful patient outcomes. 

Conceptually, the process is analogous to workflow in which a flow diagram is a type of process map where the components encompass all the steps carried out to produce goods or services.  The clinical process is the patient data flow. Conceptually, clinical guidelines are the clinical decision rules and decision trees are the clinical-decision algorithm. Conceptually, the process leads to a successful patient outcome, such as a reduction in an increase in a patient’s blood pressure. In medical decision modeling, the concept underlying the decision tree for patient management flows through the clinical decision rules, then the clinical-decision algorithm, then follows through with the patient’s clinical outcome and costs, which the analyst has to establish (e.g., cost of medication, cost of hospitalization) is then compared with the success score. 
A successful patient outcome with the clinical process and the clinical-decision algorithm resulting in the optimal clinical decision will have the highest success score. 

The process of flow analysis identifies bottlenecks to improve workflow. This analogy to work flow and how the clinical data flow through the clinical-decision algorithm in medical decision analysis will benefit the individual, organization, and society by improving the clinical and financial results for the patient, as well as increasing the efficiency of the clinical process (e.g., reducing a patient’s hospitalization time, reducing a patient’s medication costs, reducing a patient’s risk for a medical error, and reducing a patient’s probability of developing a drug-related side effect). 

What Is a Process/Flow Chart?

A flow chart, or process diagram, or process map provides a convenient way to graphically show the steps required to perform a task. The flow chart consists of three components: 

   1. Process. A process is shown by using a rectangular shape.
   1. Flow. Flows are shown by using

<EOD> Phytochemical and Biological Activities of Cynara humilis Jacq. Leaves, Flower Heads, and Roots

In order to perform a biological and phyto-chemical study of Cynara humilis, extracts were obtained from flower heads, leaves, and roots. Gas chromatography coupled to mass spectrometry (GC/MS) analysis showed that C. humilis flowers had a high concentration of oleic acid (30.53%) followed by linoleic acid (29.70%) and palmitic acid (15.08%). On the other hand, sesquiterpene lactones were the main compounds found in the essential oil and the extracts obtained from flowers, leaves, and roots, reaching as much as 82.16%. The in vitro antioxidant activity was assessed using several in vitro methods and showed that the dichloromethane extract showed the highest activity in the DPPH radical scavenging method with an IC 50 value lower than 50 g/ml. The cytotoxic activity was evaluated on 3 tumor cell lines KB, HeLa, and HepG2 using the MTT method, and the values of the IC 50 showed a weak to moderate activity of C. humilis extracts and essential oil.

# Introduction

By using air-stable and inexpensive Cu(i) catalytic system, styrenes could react with 2-aminobenzoquinones to form the corresponding benzofuran derivatives with high atom and redox economies in moderate to high yields. The tandem process was composed of two steps: the formation of enamine intermediate was followed by a sequential intramolecular substitution to provide an important dihydroquinolinone intermediate, then a Cu-catalyzed reaction of the latter compound with a second equivalent of styrene furnished the corresponding benzofuran derivative.<EOD> A Novel Function for the Dystonia-associated GTPase Activating Protein Pink1 in Mitophagy

Mutations in the PTENinduced kinase 1 (PINK1) protein give rise to the autosomal-recessive disorder Parkinson's disease, a progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the loss of substantia nigra pars compacta neurons in the midbrain. PINK1 has been implicated in mitochondrial function and oxidative stress, and its loss-of-function mutations alter mitochondrial morphology and function. However, the precise role of PINK1 in mitochondrial biology is currently unknown. We now show that PINK1 is required for both mitophagy and mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) integrity. Inactivation of the Parkinson's gene PINK1 results in the accumulation of dysfunctional mitochondria, loss of mtDNA and fragmented mitochondrial distribution. PINK1 acts as a key regulator of a mitochondria-associated oxidative stress response pathway that leads to the formation of mitolysosomes and the engulfment of damaged mitochondria into autolysosomes for degradation.

<EOD> Impaired Influenza-Specific Antibodies and Impact on Viral Replication of Human Cytomegalovirus in HIV Infected Patients
Objective A growing number of observations point out the presence, at infection with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), of many opportunistic viruses that coexist and interact, creating a highly complex polymicrobial infection. An interaction between human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) and influenza has already been described and is of particular interest. Material and Methods We compared HCMV and influenza-A serological profiles of patients receiving antiretroviral therapy, with those of healthy controls and assessed the impact of this influenza-positive HIV+ population on viral replication. Viral loads from supernatants of HMCV-positive human lung cells were also determined. Results HIV seropositivity was not related to the seropositivity of influenza, but it was associated with a decreased seropositivity of HCMV. In addition, HCMV IgG seropositivity was positively associated with influenza virus A IgG seropositivity. Influenza positivity and seropositivity were associated with increased HAART duration, and improved immune reconstitution. Finally a reduced level of HMCV viral load was noted in the samples from influenza-HIV/patients in comparison to those from HIV-only patients. Conclusions In conclusion our study described for the first time an interesting interaction between influenza-A and HCMV. A positive link between the exposure to the 2 viruses was observed. Finally these data also illustrate the strong link between these viruses and viral replication and support the concept of antiviral therapy for HCMV and influenza.<EOD> A multilingual database of 1024 Chinese medicine ingredients in English and Latin with simplified structure in Chinese

<EOD> Mixed inhibition of angiogenin ribosylation by the pig and rabbit anti-angiogenin F (Ab-F) IgGs.
It has been previously shown by one of our laboratories that anti-angiogenin (Ab-A) antibodies, obtained upon immunization of rabbits with angiogenin exhibit inhibitory activity towards angiogenin ribosylation in in vitro experiments. We now report the unexpected result that immunization of rabbit or pig with angiogenin results in antisera which contain not only anti-angiogenin F (Ab-F) IgGs (comprising IgG1 and IgG4) but also IgG (of the IgG1, IgG2, IgG4 and IgM isotypes) and IgA anti-ribosolytic activity. These antibodies showed a differential pattern of inhibition exerted towards the ribosylation and hemagglutination of angiogenin. Whereas IgG-class and IgM antibodies only partially inhibited ribosylation, they completely abolished hemagglutination of angiogenin. These two activities of angiogenin were also equally inhibited when angiogenin was coated with Ab-F IgGs. IgG class antibodies thus appear to modulate the hemagglutinating and ribosytic activity of angiogenin in vitro, whereas IgM, IgA and IgG1 or IgG4 are involved in the modulation of the ribosytic activity.<EOD> Transduction efficiency and gene integrity of a recombinant adenovirus containing E7 or E6 genes of human papillomavirus 16 in HeLa and H1299 cells.

<EOD> Diversity of gastrointestinal symptoms in patients with diabetic autonomic neuropathy.
We studied the relationship of gastrointestinal symptoms to autonomic function in type 2 diabetic patients. Anorectal manometry was performed on 76 consecutive patients with diabetes for a mean period of 7 years. Anorectal and colon manometry findings included: resting pressure, anal and rectal sensation and squeeze pressure, and rectal-anal-resting inhibitory reflex (RIR). Patients who developed colon dysfunction were compared with those who did not in terms of the presence of gastrointestinal symptoms and autonomic function evaluated by the heart rate response to standing test. The overall frequency of gastrointestinal symptoms among diabetic patients was 55%. Dysphagia and abdominal distension were the most common symptoms. No differences were observed for gastrointestinal symptoms and autonomic function, assessed by the heart rate response to standing test. However, patients who developed colon dysfunction in the further follow-up period had an increased frequency of gastrointestinal symptoms, mainly dysphagia, anorectal hyporeflexia and increased residual rectal pressure, when compared with those without colon dysfunction. We concluded that the presence of gastrointestinal symptoms may predict colon dysfunction in patients with type 2 diabetes, probably as a result of a lower quality of life and more insulin resistance; the presence of autonomic neuropathy seems to play a minimal role in this pathogenic process.<EOD> .

<EOD> Intervention to address adverse events during the admission of newly diagnosed childhood leukemia patients improves the emotional state of the nurse

Background Interventions to improve adverse events during the hospital stay are rarely evaluated, although they significantly contribute to the quality of care. This study aimed to measure and compare differences in the state of the nurse's mood in the Pediatric Oncology Service (POS) before and after applying a series of recommendations to improve adverse events encountered by the nurse in childhood leukemia patients.MethodsThe study was performed using a prospective multicenter study using the Emotional State Visual Analogue Scale (EVAS) and the Perception of Nursing Assistance (ENA) scale. Three cycles including the application of recommendations for changes in patient support were performed; these changes were based on the quantification of adverse events. The EVAS assessment was applied to assess the state of the nurse's mood as a measure of empathy, at three distinct cycles, prior to the changes (cycle 1), immediately after the recommendations were applied and adjusted (cycle 2), and three months after the recommendations were applied and adjusted (cycle 3). The EVA scale consists of marking a point on a 10.0-cm horizontal line that represents the range from being very satisfied or very happy, to being very dissatisfied or very unhappy (a score of 0 being very dissatisfied or very unhappy and a score of 10 being very satisfied or very happy). The ENA-10 scale was also applied to assess nursing assistance at the same three distinct cycles of the EVA scale. The ENA-10 scale consists of six questions rated on a scale from 1 to 4; 1 being "totally inadequate" and 4 being "totally adequate".ResultsThe results demonstrated that empathy (State of Nurses Mood) for childhood leukemia patients increased from a baseline score of 7.43 ± 1.36 to 10.00 ± 0.0 during three continuous cycles of implementation of recommendations to improve adverse events. <EOD> Development and evaluation of patient and practitioner educational material designed for women with pelvic floor dysfunction.
ISSUE ADDRESSED
Pelvic floor dysfunction, including urinary incontinence and faecal incontinence, disrupts the quality of life and can be treated conservatively or surgically. This study aimed to develop and evaluate patient and practitioner educational material designed to manage pelvic floor dysfunction.


METHODS
Fifty-eight women participated in interviews to obtain the content of a pelvic floor dysfunction information booklet. Following booklet development, 48 practitioners (25 nurses; 19 physiotherapists; four general practitioners) from private and public health services in Sydney metropolitan and Country NSW completed a written evaluation of the content, presentation, and readability of the booklet. Face-to-face interviews were conducted with 47 of these practitioners to identify their perceptions of the booklet's influence on practice.


RESULTS
Nurses reported higher content satisfaction than physiotherapists (P < 0.01). Nurses' satisfaction with the booklet in relation to communication with doctors did not change significantly (P = 0.879). Nurses reported that reading the booklet increased patient engagement (P < 0.001). Although practitioners reported an improved knowledge of how conservative and surgical management may be beneficial, they questioned where within their workflow the booklet would fit.


CONCLUSIONS
The development, content, and evaluation of patient and practitioner education for women with pelvic floor dysfunction have advanced practice. Additional implementation studies are needed to integrate this resource into practice.<EOD> Long-Term Comfort and Hospiclinic Effect of Anterior Segment Surgery with Self-Gelling Chitosan Contact Lens

Title: Phase III Study on TP-3656341 (TP-3656343) for the Treatment of Mild to Moderate Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) Patients (TP0307; CNTO-1500)


Summary:
Terumo Pharmaceuticals, Inc. (formerly known as Center for Genetics and Cell Therapies, Inc.) has developed the compound TP-3656341 (compound 1) as an inhaled medication for the treatment of mild to moderate chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). In a previous phase II clinical trial, approximately 40% of study participants experienced a treatment effect. TP-3656343 (compound 2) is a novel compound and was derived from compound 1 via structural modification to further improve the effect of compound 1 in a phase 1 clinical trial.


Inclusion Criteria:

<EOD> Vestibular disorders.
Vestibular disorders are common, their management is extremely varied and their investigation is often challenging. This review considers epidemiology, clinical presentation, investigation and management. It highlights the current knowledge gaps which exist, and the lack of evidence of many proposed diagnostic tests and treatments. Background Clinicians routinely make clinical judgements about the level of ‘disabledness’ displayed by individual people presenting for clinical care. However, there is presently no evidence-base for this activity, nor are methods used to determine the prevalence of disability well developed. Aim We describe a standardised procedure adopted in two health and social care settings to assess disability by applying an instrument called the ‘Clinical Evaluation of Language Fundamentals – Third Edition–Short Form’ (CELF-3–SF). In a pilot of this procedure we estimate the levels of disability in attendees to a hospital specialist clinic for neurorehabilitation, and investigate the extent to which the instrument might be useful for this purpose. Methods The CELF-3–SF is a brief but robust measure of communication disability. For this pilot, the CELF-3–SF was administered as part of a standardised assessment of all patients attending a hospital neurorehabilitation service. Results The CELF-3–SF was easy to administer and well tolerated by patients with neurodisability, as demonstrated in the pilot, with very high completion rates. This novel tool was able to identify patients with neurodisability but not neurodegeneration. Discussion and conclusion The brief nature of the CELF-3–SF and its ready acceptability to patients with neurodisability suggest that this could be part of a routine clinical assessment. This in turn has the potential to improve understanding of the extent of neurodisability and drive more appropriate provision of care.<EOD> .

# Example of Evaluation Criteria in an NLP Application (2020-05-27)
This application is used to extract evaluation criteria of a clinical trial and create a JSON file that includes not only evaluation criteria but also other features such as inclusion criteria, exclusion criteria, and patient notes.
It can be used to check a dataset using evaluation procedures and generate a machine-readable file that is required for the evaluation process.

Here is the example of evaluation criteria in the [Evaluation](https://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/david-bh/Evaluation/blob/master/Notebooks/Evaluation.ipynb) of a clinical trial.

Then you should run `extract_evaluation.py` so that the evaluation criteria are extracted using rules in an evaluation_trial_criteria.json in a directory (`extracted-evaluation_criteria` directory) that contains `evaluation_criteria.json`. <EOD> Immunological reactions of the human endocervix.
The present results demonstrate several similarities regarding the distribution of immunoglobulins, complement components, and immune globulins in the cervical mucus and in the vaginal discharges. These similarities, however, suggest the existence of some immunological barrier between the vagina and the uterus which would explain the infection rate of the upper reproductive tract.<EOD> Aging and cardiovascular diseases: the role of mitochondria.
The age-dependent cardiac functional decline and the aging-related increase in cardiovascular diseases (CVD) are incontrovertible facts. The aging-related mitochondrial dysfunction, in terms of its decline in function, metabolism, content and quality, is suggested as the key mechanism for the cardiac functional decline with aging. Mitochondria play critical roles in metabolism, signal transduction, apoptosis and programmed cell death, all of which are key steps in aging. The main objective of this review is to summarize current understanding of the potential role of mitochondrial dysfunction in the aging process with a focus on CVD. First, we will summarize the mitochondrial function in terms of metabolism, energetics, quality control and interorganellar communication. Next, we will compare the mitochondrial function in the aging myocardium versus the endothelium. Finally, we will summarize the potential mechanisms underlying mitochondrial dysfunction in the aging myocardium, which may be key mechanisms for the aging-related increase in CVD.<EOD> .

<EOD> Evaluation of microplate methods for assays of murine serum antibodies to sheep erythrocytes and bovine serum albumin.
Four enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (ELISAs) using microplates were evaluated: (i) ELISA for antibodies to sheep erythrocytes (SRBC) in mouse sera, with horseradish peroxidase conjugates of goat anti-mouse IgM, serotype-specific antisera and o-phtalaldehyde (OPA) as substrate, (ii) one-stage ELISA for estimation of antibodies to bovine serum albumin (BSA), with monospecific enzyme conjugates and OPA as substrate; (iii) two-stage ELISA for estimation of antibodies to BSA, with monospecific enzyme conjugates and para-nitrophenylphosphate (PNP) as substrate, and (iv) one-stage ELISA using monospecific enzyme conjugates and PNP as substrate. The results obtained with microplates were compared with classical enzyme/peroxidase and colloidal gold immunoperoxidase methods. All three ELISA techniques gave highly reproducible results (the coefficient of variation was less than 10% for within- and between-run evaluation) which were highly correlated with immunoperoxidase techniques. For all microplate ELISAs, the results obtained with polyclonal and monoclonal antibodies were comparable. In the microplate ELISA, with serotype-specific antisera, the results obtained with IgG fractions were comparable to those obtained by use of whole serum, as in the reference technique. In this system, titration of IgG fraction was performed in parallel with serum by use of an ELISA with monospecific reagents and PNP as substrate, in order to determine the equivalence of the two serum dilutions, in terms of anti-SRBC antibody concentration.

## Explanatory text
The factors that allow someone to participate in a clinical study are called inclusion criteria. They are based on characteristics such as age, gender, the type and stage of a disease, previous treatment history, and other medical conditions. This patient may need to meet the criteria of this particular clinical trial. 
The assessment of eligibility is generally a three-point scale: 0) Would not refer this patient for this clinical trial; 1) Would consider referring this patient to this clinical trial upon further investigation; and 2) Highly likely to refer this patient for this clinical trial. 
If the assessment of eligibility is negative, do not repeat the Trial-level eligibility on the same patient. 
The clinical trial, e.g., `Title: Natural History of Isolated Deep Vein Thrombosis of the Calf`, includes factors that allow someone to participate in a clinical study. There is no data on the risk of isolated deep vein thrombosis limited only to the calf. Based on your knowledge, is this patient eligible for this clinical trial? If the answer is 'yes', please refer the patient for this trial by giving the Trial-level eligibility: `2) Highly likely to refer this patient for this clinical trial.`. Rhinosclerosis, a benign rhinopharyngeal angiopathy, is a common condition. It affects the nasal mucosa and more rarely extends into the maxillary sinuses, as was apparent in the case report presented. The most common manifestation is a red patch or a smooth or papillated swelling of the anterior rhine. Treatment of rhinosclerosis is controversial. In a minority of patients, corticosteroids have sometimes been considered beneficial. In the case discussed here, medical management failed, necessitating surgical removal. After surgery, steroid therapy was unsuccessful. A follow-up of 7 and a half years was performed: no recurrence or complication was seen. In the case of maxillary sinus involvement, total removal must be discussed, even in the absence of complication.<EOD> Neurodevelopmental Disorder (502.89)
The Neurodevelopmental Disorder (502.89) diagnostic code is used by providers when there is an initial diagnosis of an unspecified neurodevelopmental disorder. The developmental age of children diagnosed with a neurodevelopmental disorder may be delayed due to various causes. Many of these children may have a genetic component wherein the child inherits the mutation from the parents. The mutation may be inherited from one or both parents. Children with a genetic disorder can have symptoms throughout their life which may affect their intelligence quotient. Most of the children with these disorders have an extremely low IQ that is severely disabling and impacts their functioning. These children are less likely to function in the typical classroom and may not be able to perform all activities that others have performed.
Children with Neurodevelopmental Disorder Diagnosis Symptoms
Children who have been diagnosed with having the Neurodevelopmental Disorder diagnostic code (502.89) often experience a number of symptoms. Below is a list of the symptoms that children diagnosed with a Neurodevelopmental Disorder may have.
- Delayed language development
- Delayed social, emotional or physical development
- Lack of physical abilities
- Lack of attention
- Inability to recognize others
- Excessive physical movements
- Hyper
