<EOD> Influence of Hexavalent-Iron-Ion and Carbon-Bioconcentration on Toxicity of Water Quality in the Lagoon, Chesapeake Bay, Virginia, USA

The waters of the Chesapeake Bay, USA, have been degraded by the discharge of sewage, phosphate, fertilizer, and heavy metals that impair fisheries and recreation. Using pH, total organic carbon (TOC), ferrous-iron (Fe 2+ ), total iron (Fe), and dissolved oxygen (DO) analyses, we discovered that many estuaries, including the Chesapeake Bay, are deficient in Fe, which impairs their health. We developed a novel non-photosynthetic bioconcentration procedure based on bacterial growth in the presence of Fe (III), phosphorylated-TOC (phosphate-TOC), ascorbic-TOC (ascorbate-TOC), and Fe 2+ ions of bacteria, phytoplankton, and sediment to address the deficient Fe content and associated toxicity in Chesapeake Bay. In situ, the 4 h procedure reduced the Fe 3+ concentration (1420 mg L −1 ) in the Chesapeake Bay, from an excessive Fe-ion level of 1420 mg L −1 before bioconcentration, to an appropriate Fe-ion level (355 mg L −1 ) after bioconcentration (BC). These observations indicate that the bioconcentration method successfully reduced the toxicity of Fe 3+ ions in Chesapeake Bay, by promoting the growth and biosorption of bacteria and phytoplankton on excessive Fe 3+ ions with bioconcentration.

<EOD> Assessment of liver steatosis by transient hepatic elastography during percutaneous liver biopsy.
PURPOSE
To evaluate whether transient hepatic elastography (TH) during percutaneous liver biopsy can improve assessment and prevent complications.


MATERIALS AND METHODS
A total of 2160 ultrasound (US)-guided percutaneous liver biopsies were performed in 1742 patients. In this single-center retrospective and prospective study, 65 of these patients had 67 liver biopsies performed after using the Mprobe for transient elastography in addition to US. US alone was used for the evaluation of liver steatosis for the other 779 patients. The grade of liver steatosis was assessed by TH in patients with the biopsy before using the Mprobe and compared with the assessment during that biopsy by using two-dimensional US.


RESULTS
The mean biopsy length was 2.37 cm in patients with TH before liver biopsy or 2.24 cm in those without it (P = .62). The mean biopsy time was 4.08 minutes in patients with TH before liver biopsy or 2.95 minutes in patients without TH (P = .009). Of the 65 patients with TH during liver biopsy, one had intraoperative pain and needed to be given local anesthetic (0.17%; 1 of 590 patients who had a biopsy without TH during the biopsy; odds ratio, 2.0). Three (0.46%) patients had mild localized complications in the form of subcutaneous hematoma in a liver biopsy in which TH was combined with US alone; this rate was not significantly decreased (P = .44) in patients with TH with US (0 of 67 biopsies). Four of 67 patients with TH and US had a positive biopsy (6%), and 63 of 67 patients had negative biopsy (94.01%).


CON

> ## Feedback on the dataset

This dataset is derived from a clinical dataset that contains information about patients, which was used in a previous academic conference. The participants of this clinical study were assigned a reference number. However, the data that we processed did not contain any reference numbers. Since the purpose of this dataset was not to reproduce an actual study, we have replaced each patient's reference number with a patient id, which consists of six random letters.

<EOD> A survey conducted by the University of Michigan is currently running to better understand the ways that people in the United States think about and use robots. The survey will help developers to better understand the market, and also people who don’t necessarily trust artificial intelligence (AI) to gain a better understanding about how to communicate with technology.
The survey takes around 18 minutes to complete, and participants will take part in a 30-minute focus group. People taking part in focus groups will be rewarded with a $50 Amazon gift card.
What Are We Trying to Find Out?
- Do you own a smartphone or some kind of home assistance robot?
- Which of the following words come to mind when you think about robots?
- How often do you think about the following things at work?
- How likely do you think it is that robot intelligence will increase by 2030?
- In what ways can you see robots taking over your work?
- Do you use the following online services?
- How much do you feel that you depend on the technology you have in your home?
- To what extent do you think of yourself as a part of the technological world?
- Are you comfortable having a computer control your home activities?
- Which of the following do you have access to in your home?
- Do you believe that robots could be a dangerous threat to humanity?

Title: A Prospective Study of a Nerve Conduction Block Method and a Nerve Growth Factor for the Treatment of Chemotherapy-induced Neuropathy in Cancer Care


Summary: The chemotherapeutic agent in the treatment of a cancer is responsible for the destruction of the peripheral nervous system and results in peripheral neuropathy. Although no treatment guidelines can be established for neuropathy, the treatment strategies include using an aggressive approach to prevent or to reduce neuropathy as soon as chemotherapeutic agent is started. Nerve conduction block method is effective in the prevention and treatment of peripheral neuropathy by the use of a selective nerve block. Nerve conduction block is not recommended for the treatment of chemotherapy-induced neuropathy (CIN) in cancer care because it affects the normal function of all nerves. In the case of CIN, an alternative treatment using nerve growth factor (NGF) is effective for relieving the symptoms of neuropathy. Although the use of NGF for the treatment of peripheral neuropathy is under evaluation, no previous study has evaluated the efficacy of nerve growth factor (NGF) for the treatment of chemotherapy-induced neuropathy (CIN) in cancer care (1).

This study aims to assess the efficacy of NGF on a CIN model by measuring the electromyogragaphic (EMG) amplitude and the muscle strength. Diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) is a promising new technique for the in vivo estimation of white matter tissue properties. This technique is being investigated as a method of characterizing white matter integrity in a range of diseases, including multiple sclerosis and spinal cord injury. The aim of this study was to develop reliable quantitative DTI metrics for describing changes in white matter following spinal cord injury (SCI) in a rat model. We performed longitudinal studies of SCI at three time points (seven days, four weeks, and six weeks) using ex vivo DTI and T2-weighted studies on fixed tissue. Signal intensity, fractional anisotropy, mean diffusivity, axial diffusivity, and radial diffusivity were analyzed. DTI values at seven days were lower for all DTI variables (P < 0.05) than controls. Fractional anisotropy, mean diffusivity, and radial diffusivity returned to control levels at four weeks. Axial diffusivity remained significantly lower than controls, until six weeks. Using longitudinal DTI studies after rat spinal cord injury, we found that fractional anisotropy, signal intensity, and mean and radial diffusivity can be used to identify acute and chronic lesions. A combined measurement of the DTI parameters found from our acute studies and the axial diffusivity measurement from our chronic study could potentially improve the accuracy of future DTI studies of spinal cord injury.<EOD> Genetic Variability of Hepatitis A Virus in Mexico

Background:A high seroprevalence of antibodies against hepatitis A virus (HAV) in Mexico has been reported. <EOD> Neonatal outcome in pregnancies complicated by diabetes and gestational diabetes: A retrospective study from north India

Objectives:To study the perinatal mortality and morbidity in infants born to diabetic and GDM mother. Method: We retrospectively analyzed neonatal outcome in diabetic and gestational diabetes (GDM) mothers. 77 diabetic and 140 GDM mothers having pregnancy complications like hypertension, prematurity, macrosomia neonatal hypoglycemia and need to KMC were included. Outcome of infants was analyzed in terms of perinatal mortality and neonatal morbidity. Result: Neonatal mortality rates were (4.3% in diabetic and 2.14% in GDM group; p = 0.37). Neonatal hypoglycemia was seen (17.1%) in GDM group and only (1.3%) in diabetes group (p < 0.01); whereas macrosomia was seen (19.1%) in diabetic group and only (7.8%) in GDM group (p < 0.001). Neonatal mortality was higher in large for gestation neonates (LFG) (10%) of diabetic mothers than GDM mothers (0.7%). Neonatal hypoglycemia was significantly associated with LFG neonates. Conclusion: We conclude that neonatal hypoglycemia and macrosomia are common in diabetic and GDM pregnancy. Higher LFG and neonatal hypoglycemia adversely affects outcome in diabetic and GDM group.KeywordsIntrauterine growth retardation, macrosomia, pregnancy complicated by diabetes and GDM, neonatal outcome, perinatal mortality, hypoglycemia.Cite as: Kumari S, Kushwaha P. Neonatal outcome in pregnancies complicated by diabetes and gestational diabetes: A retrospective study from north India. North Am J Med Sci 2013; 5 (9): 538

INTRODUCTION
We report the results of our experience in the treatment of children with non Hodgkin's lymphoma.


METHODS
Analysis is made of all children with non Hodgkin's lymphoma below 15 years managed over an 18 year period by three independent teams, retrospectively reviewed. We have no patients with Hodgkin's lymphoma.


RESULTS
Sixty eight children were identified. Twenty-nine were treated with the LH 79, EORTC 58931 protocol (98% received COPAD alone). A 90% complete remission rate was achieved. The EFS at 5 years for the group is 78%. BFM 90 is now being adopted for our national study on lymphomas. Twenty-eight children were treated by chemotherapy-only (35% received cyclophosphamide, vincristine and prednisone as in COPAD) according to protocols developed by the individual teams. A 75% complete remission rate was achieved, although the EFS at 5 year is 30%.


CONCLUSIONS
There is no statistical difference in survival between our multidrug chemotherapy and COAP regimen, but we still need to test the chemotherapy-only protocol in our experience.<EOD> .

Community health workers (CHWs) are frequently involved in physical activity (PA) promotion studies; however, the effectiveness of these strategies has not been systematically reviewed. The purpose of this systematic review was to examine the role of CHWs in studies designed to increase PA and decrease sedentary behavior in all populations. Searches were conducted in MEDLINE, Cochrane Library, CINAHL, PsycINFO, SportDiscus, APA PsyArticles, and Google Scholar. All studies were included if the study used one of 3 eligibility criteria: the intervention was to be community based, the intervention was designed to increase PA and/or decrease sedentary behavior, and the intervention was to be delivered by a CHW. A total of 26 studies met review inclusion criteria (n=26). Only 13 of these studies tested hypotheses related to changing PA (n=13). The studies with a PA focus examined a wide array of populations, and no consistency in intervention type was found. Studies lacked adequate controls and blinding. Few of the included studies (n=3) used CHW-specific theoretical models to inform the intervention. Findings of this systematic review suggest the need for a better understanding of what makes CHW-involved PA interventions effective.<EOD> .

The Effects of Sound Energy on Pulmonary Gas Exchange, Phase III Clinical Trial

Purpose

The major objective of the proposed study is to evaluate the safety, including possible side effects, and also efficacy of sound energy to enhance pulmonary gas transport. This goal will be accomplished by testing the effects of sonic pulmonary pressure oscillations on the rate and volume of gas transport using a newly designed breathing circuit that can deliver pressure oscillations in a manner similar to that encountered during breathing, and by conducting cardiorespiratory studies at rest and during exercise in healthy volunteers.

Animal research was conducted in dogs that breathe spontaneously through a tracheostomy. The sound energy was delivered through a special circuit placed on top of the breathing tube, the pressure of which was adjusted to an optimal level to achieve an audible but not distressing sensation in the animals. Under conditions of increased inspiratory time and decreased expiratory time associated with the oscillatory breathing circuit, the following changes were seen in ventilation, which indicate improved pulmonary gas transport: 1) increased alveolar ventilation (AV) associated with a higher peak expiratory flow (PEF); 2) decreased dead space (DS), as indicated by a decreased end-tidal carbon dioxide; 3) higher hemoglobin-oxygen saturation, and; 4) less respiratory effort as evidenced by increased pleural and esophageal pressure. Additionally, a more efficient oxygen transport was observed, as demonstrated by a decreased arteriovenous oxygen concentration difference. These experiments demonstrated a better gas transport associated with the oscillatory breathing circuit than with the normal breathing circuit, indicating that further evaluation in humans is warranted.

In addition to better pulmonary gas transport, the sound energy breathing circuit may provide several additional health benefits. We previously showed that

A `QTWidget` is used to display a user interface which includes buttons and sliders to send commands from user to system. The system listens to the messages which come from the user by using a `QTConnection`. By calling the method `receive(),` a user can send a predefined command which is then executed (or not). The users' inputs are processed by a handler `pyqtinterceptor` which is implemented in Python. It interacts with the system by creating a `pyqtconcreteinterceptor,` which is a concrete subclass of `QtConnectionIntercept.pyqtconcreteinterceptor` class and registers the signals and slots. The `pyqtconcreteinterceptor` is implemented by `pyqtinterceptor.PyQtInterceptor.pyqtconcreteinterceptor.`. Also, the user can get access to the system through a method called `QtConnectionIntercept.pyqtconcreteinterceptor.qtconnection()`.

Once a user starts to use the system, a widget named `Widget` is created inside the user interface and the widget is a subclass of `QTWidget.QTWidget.`. When starting to use this system, the user can not only use `pyqtconcreteinterceptor` to interact with the system (by using the buttons/sliders described above), but also manipulate some program variables (such as `QTConnection.QTConnection.`) in Python code. # Installation
To install this extension:

`gem install vcl-clinical-trial`

# Usage

## Input a patient

From the patient note, the following patient note can be got:
```r
patientNote_1 <- read_csv("patient_1.csv")
```
The following variables of patientNote_1 are described in :
```r
attributes_1 <- patientNote_1 %*% rownames(patientNote_1)
```
In addition, here some code to input the patient notes can be found. 
```r
library(readr)
patient <- read_csv("patient_2.csv")
patientNote <- paste0("{", patient, "}")
```
After inserting the patient note:
```r
input(patientNote)
```
The following variables of patient Note_1 are described in :
```r
attributes_1 <- patientNote_1 %*% rownames(patientNote_1)
```

## Assessment
After the note is input, the trials information (Inclusion Criteria) will appear automatically:
```r
TCT <- c("TCT1", "TCT2") 
[formula]  for (i in TCT){ eval(parse_string(i)) } [/formula] 
```
Trial-level eligibility will appear:
```r
Trial-level_eligibility_1 <- 'Would not refer this patient for this clinical trial' 
Trial-level_eligibility_2 <- 'Would consider referring this patient to this clinical trial  upon further investigation' 
T_level_eligibility_3 <- 'Highly likely to refer this patient for this clinical trial.'
```
Finally, there are four types of questions:
```r
Trial_level_eligibility <- c('Patient note #1', 'Trial-level_eligibility_1', 
                      'Trial-level_eligibility_2', 
                      'T_level_eligibility_3')
```



This extension has its advantages and disadvantages to other tools. The advantages are as follow:

- This paper focuses on trial-level eligibility

## Explanation
All patients must be screened for suitability before being included in a clinical trial. This assessment is crucial to ensure that the results of the trial are reliable; results derived from patients who are not appropriately suited to trial inclusion will likely be useless. 
You have learned that there are three types of medical trials: prospective, retrospective, and concurrent. The latter is designed for patients who are already using the experimental drug but would have been eligible had they participated as a study subject. This type of trial is known as Phase IV or postmarketing surveillance. 
When you are assessing a patient for trial inclusion, you typically start by determining which trial they should do next - you match the trial to the patient first, then make the patient's eligibility. Before determining the trial, you need to learn the patient's eligibility for each trial. 
Some patient characteristics should be collected as part of routine practice and entered into electronic health records (EHR) systems, such as ethnicity and language skills. If a patient reports one or more eligibility criteria, you can be highly confident that the patient is eligible for the trial. If a patient does not have one or more eligibility criteria and you do not know whether they have those characteristics because no information exists, you should consult your clinical director. 
Thus, we need to determine whether patients are eligible for this particular clinical trial or not. For this task, we have a Python script, which has already learned the medical knowledge from textbooks and online resources. 
Here we show an example of how to determine the trial-level eligibility. First, patient information, trial description, and inclusion and exclusion criteria will be transformed to a sentence by a sentence. Then we translate this sentence to a series of expressions for extracting eligibility by using a predefined rule in a Python library, i2b2. The result will be given as the output.

Part 7 is all about the Python script for solving the problem from Part 6. Our algorithm mainly consists of three steps. The first step is to transform the raw text to a list that can be easily interpreted by the program. In the second step, we extract the eligibility conditions. The following tutorial concerns comparison operators, in particular how to handle nested loops in the comparison operator part of the code. For an example of a problem where the comparison operator could be applied, please refer to the introduction of the first Tutorial.

# Abstract

Some examples of this tutorial may look like this:

![Comparison operators](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rushkh/RUSHKH0528/master/instruction/Tutorial3/Comparison%20operators.png)

# Abstract

You are asked to compare a given pair of numbers and determine if the first number is less than, equal to, or greater than the second number. After that, you are expected to determine whether or not a given set of items is evenly distributed among three categories {0, 1, and 2}.


[/ABST]

# Example

![Tutorial3](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rushkh/RUSHKH0528/master/instruction/Tutorial3/Tutorial3.png)

# Solution

```
# First part of the code

def comparison(x, y):
    if x < 100:
        return -1
    elif x == 100:
        return 99
    else:
        return 100

class Solution:

    def isEvenlyDistributed(head, n):
        ans = False
        if n%2 != 0:
            return False
        i=0
        while head:
            i+=1
            if i==round(n/3.0):
                ans = True
                break
            head.pop(0)
        return ans

```

=== Problem 3 ===

[A:C.P.:3] Some time is passed after the last problem. You are facing yet another problem. Let's solve it to get better at solving problems! The clinical trial has been completed and you will compare each patient's condition after treatment. You should compute a 3-point scale variable, which is defined as `Condition before treatment -Condition after treatment`. This variable is used for predicting the final condition of the patients if treated. It should be noted that a patient's condition might be improved, deteriorated, or unchanged.

- **Solution**

```python
patients_condition = df_data['Condition before treatment'].subtract(df_data['Condition after treatment'], axis=1)

patients_condition = pd.Series(patients_condition)
```

- **Hint**

    This solution requires understanding the difference between subtract and subtraction. Subtracting a value from all other columns in a data frame does not modify the data frame. We can achieve the same by first defining the variable, then subtracting from all columns.

    In contrast, addition and subtraction refer to the arithmetic operations. In Python addition is equivalent to sum, while subtraction is the same as minus. There are differences in how addition and subtraction operate on matrices.

<EOD> Development of a quantitative HPLC method for determination of theophylline in human serum and evaluation of possible pharmacokinetic interaction with the H2-antagonist cimetidine, metaprotol and ranitidine.
A modification of the literature methods of analysis of 3,7-dimethyl-1-propyl-purine-2,6-dion is presented, which permits routine determinations in serum samples. The method consists in the use of reversed phase HPLC and a mobile phase consisting of acetonitrile, acetate buffer pH 3.0 and triethylamine (89:10:1, v/v). This method provided complete baseline separation of theophylline and the degradation products of theophylline, with a rapid elution time and a high sensitivity (LOD = 2 micrograms/ml and LOQ = 5 micrograms/ml). This method is suitable for the routine analysis of theophylline in serum. The technique for determination of serum vitamin B-2, described by Aebi et al. (2) in 1941, is still often used. We have been unable to obtain satisfactory results with this assay procedure. The serum samples in the assay trays had to be left in a moist chamber for 1 to 2 days before determination. The results varied considerably. Some samples remained unchanged for weeks, whereas the content of vitamin B12 increased almost tenfold in others after 24 hr under the same conditions. Furthermore, the serum samples lost vitamin B12 in two steps. The amount of vitamin B12 lost in 24 hr varied considerably (fig. 1). Another factor was that the assay-tray gave more false-positive results than did other procedures. # Examples
This tutorial has two examples.  The first one is a simple patient note, which is easy to be evaluated, so everyone could do well in this tutorial.  The second example is a very difficult patient note, which contains many confusing ideas.
## First Example
To illustrate how to evaluate a patient's eligibility, the clinical trial data is set as follows:
Evaluated variables and scores are set as follows: `Evaluated variables: 9;`. `Score_0: 0; Score_1: 0; Score_2: 9;`.

## Second Example

`Score for patient 0:
19 = 3`
Thus, our patient is highly likely to refer for this clinical trial.
Although the scores are calculated from scratch, the scores of first example are the same as the second one.

# Discussion
Your task is to evaluate eligibility of patients for a specific clinical trial. The criteria for this process are not standardized due to the difference of clinical trials. Therefore, you should read and understand the provided clinical trial note to determine the extent to which the patients described in the clinical trial are eligible for the clinical trial.
On the trial level, you will determine whether a patient is eligible. 
On the patient level, you will evaluate the factors that allow someone to participate in a clinical study called inclusion criteria.  They are based on characteristics such as age, gender, the type and stage of a disease, previous treatment history and other medical conditions. You should make a trial-level eligibility on each patient for the clinical trial.<EOD> Nail-fold capillary density decreases following antidislipidemic treatment

## Testing

`pytest` can help with testing. [Read more about testing with `pytest` here.](https://docs.python.org/3/library/pytest.html) 

First, run `py test` to automatically execute a large collection of tests (or specific tests). Next, run `pytest tests/unit_test/test_example_clinical_trial/` to test the example function at the top of the file.

To run these tests on the command line, enter the Python interpreter with ``python test.py`` then to see which tests are going to automatically execute, enter ``pytest``. By default, tests that have ``@unit`` are executed by executing `pytest` and all the following tests should run as well. 

Alternatively to this, run a test suite by ``pytest tests/test_example_clinical_trial`` to test all the example's functions. For this suite, you can enter the Python interpreter with ``python test.py`` and then type ``pytest`` to see which tests are going to automatically execute. By default, tests that have ``@unit`` are executed by specifying ```pytest``.

Next, run a module-level test suite by running ``pytest``. By default, all the module tests are executed, as specified by ``--modules`` or ``--test_modules=foo.bar.baz``. In the same way, you can define a function-level test suite with ``@pytest.mark.patch``.

Run each test in detail by ``pytest foo.bar.baz`` or ``pytest`` then to view a report of the tests, run ``pytest --reports``.
If you don't like ``pytest`` and want to write your own tests, just run ``unittest`` (the same `unittest/test_example_clinical_trial.py`-like command) in your code.

- Q1: What is the main problem/challenge that you intend to solve with this task?

1. Inappropriate assessment of inclusion criteria in eligibility check will create a significant amount of extra administrative work in the recruitment workflow.
2. Assessment of trial-level eligibility is usually performed by a team of experts rather than an individual clinician. To ensure the timely recruitment in a dynamic workflow environment, it is essential to ensure the eligibility check for trial-level will support an acceptable degree of inadequacy. This will ensure a smooth flow of patients through the recruitment process.
3. Currently there is no support for patient-level assessment or trial-level assessment for large trials and this can lead to a significant amount of manual effort during the clinical trial planning phase.
4. There is no assessment of trial-level for clinicians for multi-centre clinical trials. This will ensure the eligibility check for trial-level will support an acceptable degree of inadequacy.
--

*Inadequate assessment of inclusion criteria in eligibility check will increase the amount of extra administrative work in the recruitment workflow.

1. Lack of transparency in clinical trial and the resulting lack of trust in clinicians.
2. The process of applying the same inclusion criteria to multiple patients can be highly inefficient because it can lead to inefficiencies in workflow and staff resources. To make better use of clinician time, it is important that the assessment of trial-level be supported by the patient's specifics.
3. Lack of adequate automated assessment of patient eligibility in the clinical trial planning phase.
4. To ensure that clinical trials are conducted in a standardized way across organizations, it is essential to develop tools that allow clinical trials to be analyzed holistically. This will allow data to be used in clinical trials without being limited by the trial design.

*Lack of transparency in clinical trial planning lead to an increase in the amount of extra administrative work in the recruitment workflow. *Lack of transparency in clinical trial planning result in less trust in clinicians.

systematic synthesis of evidence and expert consensus for a range of different physical activity concepts, interventions, and behaviour change techniques. The development of the framework included a multiphase process comprising: (i) systematic searches of academic and grey literature for a range of relevant physical activity concepts and behaviour change components, (ii) an international Delphi of international experts in physical activity to establish the relevance of a range of candidate physical activity concepts and behaviour change components for application in a range of communitybased settings, (iii) a series of international consensus meetings of international experts in physical activity and related areas to develop descriptions and definitions for each physical activity concept and behaviour change component (iv) and extensive consultation with international experts in physical activity to achieve consensus regarding the content and structure of each physical activity concept and associated behaviour change component. The final product, the International Classification of Active Living (iCAL), is a structured framework comprising one physical activity concept and five associated behaviour change components. The purpose of this presentation is to describe the process by which the iCAL was developed. The iCAL builds on the physical activity taxonomy which was developed as part of the International Physical Activity and Environment Network's (IPEN) research programme and consolidates a broad range of relevant physical activity concepts and associated behaviour change components into a single, consensus-driven framework.(continued on next page)

def split_by_newlines():
    t = re.compile('\n|\r')
    res = []
    for line in t.split(trial_note):
        trial_sents=line.split('\t')
        for trial_sent in trial_sents:
            res.append(trial_note_col[line] + '\t' + trial_sents[1].rstrip('\r\t\n'))
    #df_note.loc[df_note['patient_id']==_patient_id, [str('Patient_note_to_token')]]
    #i=_patient_id+4
    for line in trial_note.splitlines():
        trial_sents=line.split('\t')
        for trial_sents in trial_sents:
            trial_sents=trial_sents.split(' ').split('\t').split(trial_sent, 1)
            trial_sents[1]=trial_sent.rstrip('\r\t\n').replace('.',' ')
        res.append(trial_note_col[line] + '\t' + trial_sents[1].rstrip('\r\t\n'))
    return pd.DataFrame(res, columns=trial_note_col)

## Your task

Given a patient note and a clinical trial, write a program in the `file` module that produces the `Trial-level eligibility`, where you input the patient note by `patient note` and input the clinical trial by `clinical trial`.

## Approach

A clinical trial note can be viewed as a nested document, with the lines and words representing the fields. The `Nested Document` class is used to define this nested structure, whereas the `NestedParser` method enables to parse the nested data.

First, we read all patient notes and clinical trials into dictionaries. We use the nested structure to perform the three-step eligibility assessment for each trial.

Once all eligibility results have been recorded as dictionary values, we obtain the top 3 trial-level eligibilities in order of patient eligibility using a heuristic function.

<EOD> Long working hours and increased incidence of obesity in middle-aged Finnish men.
OBJECTIVES
We studied the prospective association between long working hours and the incidence of overweight and obesity by comparing working hours at baseline with those at follow-up in a cohort of middle-aged Finnish men.


METHODS
Our longitudinal data were drawn from the Helsinki Heart Study, a randomized intervention trial for coronary heart disease. All participants from the Helsinki metropolitan area and southern Finland attending a follow- up examination 5.4 years after baseline were asked to participate in this study. Data on work hours at baseline and follow-up were obtained from self-administered questionnaires. Body weights were measured. A multivariate adjustment for age, marital status, education, smoking, diabetes, and physical activity (in vigorous bouts) was made.


RESULTS
The analytic sample contained 490 men with complete data on both work and weight. Men working >50 hours/week showed an overall significant increase in the incidence of overweight (body mass index ≥25 kg/m(2)) compared with men working 35-40 hours/week (adjusted odds ratio = 2.52, 95% confidence interval = 1.26-5.05). However, no difference in the incidence of overweight was observed for working 41-44 or 45-48 hours/week versus 35-40 hours/week. Working >50 hours/week was significantly related to an increase in incidence of obesity, body mass index ≥30 kg/m(2) versus working 35-40 hours/week (adjusted odds ratio = 4.30, 95% confidence interval = 1.08-17.11).


CONCLUSIONS
These data suggest that working >50 hours/week is associated with increased incidence of overweight and obesity even after multivariate adjustment. Because few subjects worked >50 hours/week, the number of participants in our study was small. Nevertheless, these data on Finnish men are consistent with other reports showing increased B

<EOD> The Effects of Caffeic Acid on the Oxidative Stress Parameters and the Antioxidant Content in the Liver and Kidneys of Sickle Cell Mice Caused by Proliferative Nephropathy

This study analyzed the effects of caffeic acid (CA) on the oxidative stress parameters and some antioxidants in the liver and kidney of mice with proliferative nephropathy-prone sickle cell anemia (PSCA) from sickle cell mice. Twentysix male PSCA mice were divided into 3 groups: Control (C), Caffeic Acid (CA), and Proliferative (Proliferative mice with oxalate renal damage). They were subjected to a 14-day CA treatment period, followed by 30 days of oxalate induction. The liver and kidneys were weighed and analyzed for iron levels, antioxidant enzymes (AOE), malondyaldehyde (MDA), glutathione (GSH), glutathione disulfide (GSSG), catalase (CAT), glutathione reductase (GR), and oxidative stress markers. AOEs were significantly higher in the CA and Proliferative groups. Glutathione, GSSG, and MDA significantly decreased in the CA group. Glutathione levels were significantly lower in the Proliferative than in the C group. In conclusion, caffeic acid significantly reduced the oxalate-induced increase in kidney iron levels, while increasing the liver and kidney antioxidant levels in PSCA mice.

`u'age_group'`

datatable.variables == [u'data', u'disease_stage', u'patient_id', u'gender', u'age_group'] # list of variables included 0th dataset

Now we create a variable, that will hold all included variables and their corresponding dataset. `dtable` is used to retrieve individual rows from the dataset object of the variable `datasets`.
```
age_group_columns = {u'age_group':'age_group', u'_dtable':'[age_group]'}

Recently, the anticancer activity of pyruvic acid derivatives in colon cancer cells has been reported. In this study, novel pyruvatum metal complexes of copper(II), zinc(II), silver(I), and gold(III) with various substituents on the pyruvic moiety (N-(pyridin-2-yl)-(1-benzyl-1H-pyrrol-2-yl)methanamine) were synthesized and characterized by FTIR, 1 H-NMR, 13 C-NMR, CHN analyses, thermal stability tests, molecular structure analysis, and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analyses for the first time. In addition, the effect of the complexes on the cell cycle of HCT-116 cells was also explored. Results found that the Ag(pyruvatum) 10 compound has the highest anti-inflammatory and anti-proliferative activity compared to the other metal complexes, while Zn(pyruvatum) 11 and Cu(pyruvatum) 0 were the least potent against the HCT-116 and HT-29 CRC cells. <EOD> Evaluating strategies to improve the adoption of evidence-based clinical practice guidelines among physicians: a Delphi consensus panel.
OBJECTIVE
To determine strategies to improve the adoption of evidence-based clinical practice guidelines.


PARTICIPANTS
56 Canadian physicians from 31 specialty and subspecialty disciplines in medicine, surgery and dentistry, including representatives from family practices.


METHOD
A Delphi technique incorporating three rounds of opinion surveys and teleconferences with group discussion, feedback on individual responses and a final consensus meeting was conducted. Draft guidelines were reviewed by the 1999 Ontario Health Technology Advisory Committee and used to frame the results and questions in the first survey.


RESULTS
A 113-item questionnaire was distributed to 56 respondents in the first survey. The response rate was 96% (N = 53). The average level of agreement for all 4 sections of the questionnaire was 94%, and the average level of agreement of items within each section (on a scale of 1 to 9) was 89% (n = 386). Respondents identified 35 strategies to increase clinician compliance with guidelines. These strategies were clustered into 6 categories: 1) improve compliance with existing guidelines; 2) improve training in clinical practice guidelines; 3) develop alternative methods of guideline dissemination; 4) create a mandate for guideline use; 5) improve the method of guideline development; and 6) develop a method for ongoing guideline revision and evaluation.


CONCLUSION
Strategies to improve the implementation of guidelines are multifactorial and may involve a combination of factors addressing clinician education, knowledge and practice patterns. The use of evidence-based guidelines offers the potential for improved quality of care.<EOD> .

At baseline, 12 women experienced one or more binge eating episodes during the last month (the BED+ group), while 18 women did not (the BED- group). The BED+ group presented significantly higher scores on BMI, I-BFQ-12, EAT-26 (restraint scale, emotional eating, bulimic behaviors), BDI, and PSQI when compared with the BED- group. Significant reductions in body weight and BMI and improvements in insomnia symptoms and depressive symptoms at 6 months were associated with BED status. <EOD> Hydroxyapatite nanoparticles loaded with doxycycline for inhibiting human osteosarcoma cells.
BACKGROUNDS
The major goal of any tumor therapeutic strategy is to reduce the side effects of treatment and improve the outcomes through novel strategies combining nanoparticles with chemotherapeutic drugs. The aim of this study was to assess the effects of hydroxyapatite (HA) nanoparticles (NPs) loaded with doxycycline (Dox) on the proliferation and viability of the U-2OS human osteosarcoma cell line.


METHODS
Dox-loaded HA NPs were applied with three methods. Cell proliferation and viability were then analyzed after 24 hr and 72 hr of treatment, respectively. The effects of the loading method on Dox release were also determined by fluorescence spectroscopy.


RESULTS
The results showed that the maximum Dox release to 24 hr was related to the HA NP/cell ratio. A direct correlation between the release ratio and amount of Dox loaded in the HA NPs was also found at 24 hr. A similar pattern was observed at 72 hr.


CONCLUSIONS
Loading Dox onto HA NPs had significant effects on the rate of Dox release from HA NPs. The amount of Dox in NPs could be controlled by varying the amount of loaded drug, and the drug release was directly proportional to the drug content. Consequently, HA NPs could also prove to be an effective DDS.<EOD> Challenges in Managing Acute Heart Fail

Here, we present a meta-analysis of the prognostic significance of lymphatic vessel density (LVD) in human cancer for the first time.Patients and methods. Relevant studies were searched via the electronic databases Pubmed, EMbase, Cochrane Library, Google Scholar, and Web of Science published up to February 10, 2015. <EOD> A Novel Approach to Cutaneous Melanoma Survival Prediction Based on a Prognostic Signature Combined with Radiomic Features from CT Images



# Background
Skin cutaneous melanoma (skin melanoma) is the most malignant type of skin cancer in which the primary tumor originates from melanocyte tumors. Among the malignant cutaneous melanoma (CM), melanoma in-situ, melanoma of the acral and mucosal surfaces, and an uncommon group of non-melanoma skin cancers including blue and brown nevi, angioblastoma (capillary or lymphatic) and dermal angiomas, and hematoma were not included. Moreover, CM is more dangerous than other skin cancers. The incidence of melanoma has increased globally over the last 50 years. Melanoma accounts for up to 79% of all skin cancer-related deaths, making it one of the top five most common cancer types in the USA.
Globally, the incidence of melanoma has increased significantly in the past 15 years, with the greatest increase in incidence in the younger (0-40 years) age group. Early diagnosis represents a vital tool for CM patients' early treatment, which is a great challenge today. Diagnosis of CM is based on the presence of specific features on the surface examination of the skin. These are referred to as the A-E-I-P-T classification of cancer of the skin, which includes the ABCD rule (A is asymmetry; B is border irregularity; C is color variation; D is diameter > 6 mm; E: has been evolution; and P is the proximity of the lesion to normal skin and/or of the nevus to the lesion). The early diagnosis of CM is essential to the timely clinical intervention, which directly affects the prognosis of patients. However, the CM prognostic assessment based on clinical, pathological, or molecular biomarkers is complicated, so a computer-aided diagnosis system is urgently needed.

<EOD> Inhibition of the activity of ribonuclease inhibitor by small-molecule organic cations.
Ribonuclease inhibitor (RI), also known as protein Z, is a large homotrimeric protein (175 kDa) consisting of identical subunits. RI inhibits RNase-like activity in a wide range of cells, tissues, and fluids by preventing the binding of RNase molecules to their target substrate (substrate RNA in RNase A or RNase 3). RI is also an elongation factor of protein synthesis that increases the elongation rate of the ribosome during translation of the polyribosome. The RI in cells is distributed between the nucleocytoplasmic compartment of cells and extracellular fluids. Intracellular RI is mostly sequestered in the nucleolus, whereas most RI molecules in extracellular media form aggregates with serum proteins. These aggregates are believed to help clear RI from the human body during serum production and to increase the RI life span in the blood. One of the main in vivo activities of RI is to bind and neutralize RNase A and RNase 3. These two exogenous RNases are released from epithelial cells of the lung where they facilitate the clearance of inhaled bacterial infections. Inhaled dusts cause the serum RI protein level to decrease because the RI aggregates with dust and subsequently cleared from cells. One of these

T he last two decades have been littered with business scandals for which many observers blame the internal morality of corporate management. The corporate scandals that came to light in the early 1990s were marked by the ethics of money-chasing greed and the perception of business as war. The Enron, WorldCom, and other company affairs scandals that followed were also marked by the internal morality of management, with executive compensation practices being the main villain. The Enron scandal exemplifies the ethical problems that have arisen from corporate misconduct; the chief executive officer of Enron was sentenced to ten years in prison for multiple crimes, while his wife made a $5.5 million donation to a charity she controls. While the actions of Enron’s top executive may have caused them moral problems, the underlying moral framework may have given company management license to pursue the interests of the organization’s top personnel and shareholders under the guise of business activity. This framework was shaped by a view of ethics that emphasized corporate success as the best and only reasonable choice for management. This ethic and related business practices are being questioned, however, with the result that, at least in rhetoric, most businesses have a greater focus on social responsibility. Although the external behaviors of corporations may be changed to address ethical concerns, the internal morality of businesses, which shapes those behaviors, has not received nearly as much attention. Indeed, the concept of internal morality is a rather recent phenomenon in management studies, especially in relation to the issues of employee ethics and corporate culture. Although this journal welcomes any article on internal morality including ethics and corporate culture, the editors found in a recent review of articles on ethics and internal morality that few are written from a business ethics point of view or from the perspective that ethics are integral to the workings of an organization or a business.<EOD> N-cadherin expression in the progression of human prostate cancer.

A control group was created in a 1:4 ratio based on live born children who came to the neonatal unit over a 6-year period and had a gestational age ≥37 weeks and no diagnosis in the hospital information system during the pregnancy period. All cases and controls were selected through computerized system, and records were reviewed to obtain data. # Method

We proposed an approach based on the rule-based method, which was developed by Hod and colleagues.  The overall task is performed by the rules. The rule-based method is flexible with easy modification for the task.  
The framework of the rule-based method is summarized as following 3 steps as.

## Step 1: Define the Task
The input and target variables are defined initially.
The patient note is given as input variable, called P N , which is the same as input variable of Step 2 in the data-driven method.
The target variable is a three-point scale: 0) Would not refer this patient for this clinical trial; 1) Would consider referring this patient to this clinical trial upon further investigation; and 2) Highly likely to refer this patient for this clinical trial.
So, we can define a variable, target, which takes integers from 0 to 2.

## Step 2: Define the Rules
Both conditionals and modifiers are defined in this step.
Conditionals are a precondition of the target variable, defining a part of the target, including the antecedent and consequent. The first antecedent in the target variable is defined to be "Inclusion Criteria" as one conditional. The consequent is defined as a part of the target variable 0 when the antecedent is not satisfied and 1 otherwise. The rule of this target variable for the clinical trial is shown below.



(1):

*

*precondition: "Inclusion Criteria";

*consequent: 1

*target: 2

*In the rule above, the target variable "Inclusion Criteria" is defined as a condition for the target labeling as 2. If the target variable "Inclusion Criteria" is true, a label of 2 (Highly likely to refer this patient for this clinical trial) is given to the target variable. Otherwise, a label of 1 (Would consider referring this patient to this clinical trial upon further investigation) is given.

Otherwise, the same modifiers "Age" and "Gender" are defined as modifiers for the last line in Step 3.

\section{Motivation}
Since 2001, more and more public data become available on the Web. One of the problems we face nowadays is finding relevant information hidden inside a large volume of public documents. The reason is that many Web pages are written to be read by humans, not machines. In particular, they contain both structured and unstructured information.  As people often represent information in structured data form, we need intelligent computer systems that can help us extract information in a structured format from texts. In recent years, much work has been devoted to the task of extracting structured information, called information extraction, from unstructured text.

The identified entities are often semantically represented by some structured form, such as a string of symbols, in which some symbols are reserved for different kinds of entities. A: Here are a few points in case you are a beginner like me.
Whenever the data is hard to obtain it is better to use something like Pandas instead of DataFrames in SQLAlchemy.
When working with dictionaries, never let Dataframes hold data. Dictionaries can be very efficiently implemented using list comprehensions. 
Also consider giving your models a name for instance "model_name_lite". I know its trivial but there is no reason to create redundant names.
A nice way of working with dictionaries would be with the DictProxy class in sqlalchemy.
In SQLAlchemy, the connection must be called before a transaction. If the query is part of a transaction, the connection can be passed to sqlalchemy directly.
Consider using the with block from sqlalchemy to create a context manager where the connection is closed/released when exiting the block.
And finally consider using the engine.connect() method which is more flexible than your solution.

The present study was conducted to determine whether angiotensin II (AII), the primary bioactive product of the renin-angiotensin system (RAS) stimulates hepatic fibrogenesis in vivo by inducing proliferation of the fibrogenic phenotype hepatic stellate cell (HSC). By using FITC-AII, we provide new in vivo evidence that AII receptors (AT-Rs) are present in the surface of normal and cirrhotic HSC. Administration of AII to Wistar rats with liver cirrhosis induced a significant increase in the number of AT-R+/GFAP- cells, a phenotype of nonproliferative but activated HSC, from 13.4 to 18.9% (P <.05). However, a significant increase in the total number of AT-R+/GFAP+ cells, a phenotype of proliferative HSC, was observed from 3.5 to 5.6% (P <.05). AII markedly stimulated (P <.05) the proliferation index of both intact and cultured AT-R+/GFAP+ cells from 30.8 +/- 3.1 to 52.5 +/- 4.5 and from 29.8 +/- 3.0 to 36.4 +/- 3.9, respectively. Furthermore, the protein levels of alpha-SMA (a marker of activated HSC) and of collagen III were significantly increased (P <.05) both by AII treatment of cultured HSC and by AII administration to rats with liver cirrhosis. Our results provide new evidence that the proliferation of activated HSC, a phenotype involved in the development of liver fibrosis, is enhanced by AII stimulation in the presence of cirrhosis.<EOD> An assessment of the humanitarian needs for displaced Iraqi refugees: a need for the emergency preparedness system.

<EOD> The Relationship Between Respiratory Compensation Point, VO2 Max, and Ppeak in Chronic Stable Methamphetamine Abusers
Purpose The respiratory compensation point (RCP) is the highest point of respiratory inefficiency at which VO2 max can be maintained. VO2 max also refers to the maximum amount of oxygen utilized during incremental exercise. This paper explores the relationship between RCP, VO2 max, and peak power output (Ppeak). Methods Male and female recreational ecstasy (3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine ) users (n = 69) and matched non-users (n = 34) aged between 18 and 30 were tested for cardiopulmonary function with a treadmill-based exercise test. Results RCP, VO2 max, and Ppeak were significantly associated with each other (rs = 0.42 to 0.52, p  .05 ). Conclusion This study demonstrates that RCP is significantly correlated to VO2 max and Ppeak in recreational MDMA users and non-users. # Related works
From the previous problem statement of the paper `Predicting trial (re)recruitment of patients with chronic diseases for interventional trials on the basis of clinical notes', the targeted data type is textual data. Therefore, methods from NLP can be applied for solving the data-centric problems, e.g., named entity recognition, relation extraction, semantic classification, relation classification, etc. The general structure of the data-centric solutions is to learn deep models and then perform inference to predict the likelihood of trial (re)recruitment, for example, by applying a softmax classifier on the top of CNN model, outputting for each word in a sentence, i.e., each time step, a probability vector to indicate the potential (re)recruitment scores for that sentence.(re)recruitment.
These works make use of the BERT base model which was pretrained on large general language data without label. Then, each word in the data of the problem statement is extracted as a time step for NLP training, such as NER and RE. Numerous NLP methods for (re)recruitment prediction can be found in the literature, e.g., NER, RE, SCL. The state-of-the-art NLP methods can be combined with recurrent neural network(RNN) in BERT, CNN, and gated recurrent unit(GRU). All of the methods can output the logits for the potential re/recruitment probability for each word in the clinical documents. The logits of all sentences will be a probability vector with some length as the input of a softmax layer for the final prediction of (re)recruitment.
However, for predicting trial (re)recruitment, we need the feature of words to be extracted for inference, e.g., semantic, grammatical, and linguistic features related to recruitment prediction.

ABSTRACT Osteoporosis is a disease characterized by low bone mass, and osteoporotic activities of plants are evaluated mostly by using animals. Osteoporosic and lathyrid activities of herbal medicines can affect skeletal morphology of embryonic chick bones. We analyzed whether osteoporotic and lathyric activities of plants, including medicinal plants, exist and affect skeletal morphology of the chick bones. Dried plants and herbal medicines were extracted with ethanol. We investigated whether these extracts have an effect on bone chondrocytes of embryonic chick bones, using the alcian blue staining. We also examined the effect of these extracts on length of tibiotarsus for a measurement of their lathyric activities. Ethanol extracts of plants exhibited a suppressive effect on alcian blue staining, and the effects were observed also by using the extracts of herbal medicines. These effects tended to weaken as elapsing time increased. The length of tibiotarsus was significantly extended in the group of ethanolic extracts of plants, suggesting the presence of lathyric activity. Moreover, the extracts of plants and herbal medicines had suppressive effect on the mRNA level of runt-related transcription factor 2 (Runx2), as well as of osteocalcin. ## Experimental Setup
One person is designated as the administrator for [email protected] during the period of the experiment. The person is responsible for the setup of the experiments as well as the collection of the task output. The person also plays the role of the assistant for trial-level eligibility assessment.

## Preparation of patient notes
We used 100 patient notes each used in both training and the test data. The first 50 were for training, and another 50 were for testing. The patients' baseline characteristics are given in [fig_ref]  Table 5: Patients' baseline characteristics [/fig_ref] . The patients were randomly chosen from the patients' list. The patients were selected so that they did not appear in both of the training and test sets in order to remove the potential memorization of the patients' baseline factors in the training data. The patient notes were prepared with the random variables in consideration.

The patient notes are divided into 4 groups (A, B, C, and D) so that they do not have information overlap. All patient notes of a single group should have the same variables, i.e., only the patient notes in the same group should contain the same variables, and the same variables should be absent from the notes of other groups.
After the random assignment, our assistant examined the baseline of the patients included to exclude unrelated baseline characteristics of random variables, such as previous drug use, history of bariatric surgery, substance use, and chronic pain. If the patients included had any of the above, those patients were removed. The same assistant also manually checked the patient notes that were input into the dataset to eliminate any typing and formatting issues such as inconsistent information style or typographical errors including numbers. Any patients with missing information in the variables such as sex and age were excluded by the assistant. Patient notes with an unusual condition not included in the random variable group were also manually checked by an assistant. If any notes were found in the dataset to have unusual conditions and/or were incomplete after manual review, they were removed from our dataset.
Because the data were limited, patient notes with duplicated variables were not detected by the manual check, but the number of variables was still very small compared to the number

<EOD> Antagonistic control of axon regeneration and myelination by the p38 MAPK neuronal activity state
Axon regrowth in mammals is often stunted by the presence of myelin, and thus successful axon regrowth may require that growth cones first navigate away from their target, as well as their target itself. We found that while the neurotransmitter glutamate drives sensory axon growth towards a target, it simultaneously activates a p38 MAPK signaling cascade in mouse DRG neurons. Surprisingly, high levels of p38 MAPK activity, associated with an inactive state of the DRG growth cone, inhibit axon outgrowth on myelin while promoting neurite branching. Blocking p38 MAPK activity in the growth cone of axons growing on myelin reduces neurite branching without a concomitant gain in process outgrowth. We propose that an elevated p38 MAPK state serves as a regulatory signal that induces axons to form branches, in preparation for subsequent rewiring, either when growth cones have navigated through a target or when they have been forced away from a target due to myelination.<EOD> Reexamining the Role of Nonsteroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drugs in Cardiovascular Risk With an Agent-Level Approach

However, the safety of NSAIDs on the cardiovascular system remains controversial. It has been suggested that there is a possibility of a class effect of cardiovascular risk of NSAIDs in a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials (RCTs). However, there was considerable variation in the effect of individual agents in the RCT findings. <EOD> Re: A population-based study evaluating the effect of anesthetic choice on cancer recurrence after breast cancer surgery.
458 E nvironmental and surgical oncologists are regularly confronted with the important question of what, if any, is the role of anesthetic technique on tumor development or recurrence. A randomized trial that compares breast cancer outcomes after cancer surgery by the same surgeon but performed by different anesthetists and/or analgesic techniques would be a high-order science study, with the potential for great clinical impact if a statistically significant difference in recurrence was shown. It is unlikely, however, that such a study will be completed in our or any lifespan. A meta-analysis, which combines and analyzes evidence from several separate studies of varying qualities, has been suggested as one alternative approach. In the past, a problem with this approach has been that the available literature is very heterogeneous. However, there is sufficient variation with respect to different anesthetic agents, techniques, and surgical procedures that can be included in the analysis. In addition, there is clear evidence that anesthetic agents can affect some of the perioperative immune processes that are relevant in tumor biology. Therefore, this meta-analysis of available literature on the topic was undertaken and presented in this issue of the Anesthesiology (1). The authors conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis of 26 studies with more than 10 million enrolled patients. Only studies with sufficient statistical power and with comparable patient populations that were undergoing cancer surgery using similar anesthetic and analgesic techniques were included. Cancer deaths were recorded as a measure of cancer recurrence, with a secondary outcome of recurrence-free survival. The results were strikingly different. The anesthetic technique and analgesic medications used were found to have little influence on cancer deaths or cancer recurrence rates. Different types of anesthetics and analgesics had only very minor effects on immune functions and cancer recurrence, but immune markers were rarely measured in this type of analysis. This meta-analysis should be viewed with one caveat. There are a number of confounding factors present in cancer surgery (3). The

ABSTRACT Bordetella pertussis, the agent of whooping cough, has evolved genetically diverse strategies to survive and replicate in the human host. Bordetella can infect different phagocytic host cells and inhibit macrophage proliferation via the type 1 tumor necrosis factor receptor (TNFR1) ligand. Pertussis toxin (PTX) is a potent virulence factor produced by the bacterium. However, the mechanism through which PTX triggers apoptosis in macrophages is poorly understood. Many viruses and other macromolecular assemblies function by merging their membranes and/or with membranes. A common feature of fusion proteins, the proteins responsible for mediating such fusions, is the presence of long, amphipathic helices; proteins like influenza hemagglutinin can be as large as 1300 residues long and contain many helical domains. These fusion peptides pack hydrophobic residues on one surface and polar and charged residues on the opposite surface. Despite the diversity of both size and structure within this class of proteins, peptides, whether from viruses, protein-binding toxins, or phage tail tubes, are surprisingly similar. The fusion events are promoted by the binding of membranes to peptides, a process where water is expelled by the formation of the peptide-membrane interface. The peptides of these proteins, when bound to membranes, associate to form tight dimers. Here we investigate the structure of the fusion peptide of the toxin protein complex DP2-3, a key component in the pore-forming system that is found in the cell wall of the Gram-positive bacteria Bacillus anthracis. <EOD> High-frequency microvibration stimulation ameliorates sciatic nerve injury via the NGF-TrkA/Akt/mTOR/PI3K signaling pathway in the rat.
Spinal cord injury (SCI) refers to the damage to the spinal cord and its surrounding supporting tissues caused by various etiologies. High-frequency microvibration stimulation (HFMS) is a novel physical stimulation method that has been increasingly applied in the clinic for tissue repair. The underlying mechanism through which HFMS exerts effects on SCI-related nerve repair, specifically, has yet to be elucidated. The purpose of this experiment was to investigate whether the neuroprotective effects of HFMS were mediated through the downregulation of nerve growth factor (NGF) and its associated signaling pathways in the sciatic nerve following SCI. Methodologically, SCI was induced in rats using the Allen method, and the animals were randomly divided into one of four groups as follows: control group; SCI group; HFMS group; and HFMS + SCI group. The rats were subjected to HFMS or the conventional massage stimulation for 28 days commencing two days after SCI. Following euthanasia, the serum was separated from the collected blood samples, and the sciatic nerves were isolated and harvested for further study. Western blot analysis revealed that the levels of NGF, PI3K and phosphorylated PI3K (p-PI3K), protein kinase B (AKT), phosphorylated AKT (p-AKT), and phosphorylated mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) (p-mTOR) were significantly decreased following the application of HFMS, and that HFMS treatment increased the PI3K and p-PI3K levels in the HFMS-treated SCI rats (P<0.05). The aforementioned results indicated that HFMS is effective in improving the behavior and peripheral nerve functions of SCI rats; this effect is achieved via neurotrophic mechanisms, enhanced axonal regeneration and remyelination. ABSTRACT In Saccharomyces cerevisiae, the pheromone and mating-type genes form a functionally coordinated gene cluster, which consists of a set of mating-defective genes, mfa, flanked by the a cell (MFα1), the α cell (FUS1), and the a cell (MFα2). The regulation of these genes is complex and involves an array of pheromone-induced transcription factors. Since the N terminus and the C terminus of a pheromone interact with the Ste2p receptor to induce gene expression, we focused on how the N- and C-terminal sequences of a pheromone determine the efficacy of the induction of mating-type expression. FUS1 gene expression in the N- and C-terminally truncated pheromones was analyzed by measuring the transcript levels of FUS1 mRNA with competitive PCR. From these results, it was found that the C- but not the N-terminally truncated pheromone was completely inhibited in the induction of FUS1 gene expression. These results indicate that a pheromone requires both its N- and C-terminal sequences for inducing FUS1 gene expression through the Ste2p receptor. <EOD> A Systematic Review of the Effects and Safety of Chinese Herbal Medicine Monotherapy or in Combination With Western Medicines in the Treatment of Myasthenia Gravis

Myasthenia gravis (MG) is a chronic autoimmune disease that primarily affects the neuromuscular junction and leads to muscle weakness. Several forms of Chinese herbal medicine (CHM) are used to treat MG. This systematic review was conducted to evaluate the efficacy and safety of CHM for MG and to determine whether CHM is a safe and effective treatment option, to explore its mechanism of action. This systematic review was guided by the 2009 PRISMA statement. The search string was "((myasthenia gravis OR myasthenia) AND (Chinese OR Chinese * OR Chinese medicine OR Chinese remedy OR Chinese herb*))". A comprehensive literature search was conducted in the following databases: Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, EMBASE, Allied and Complementary Medicine Database, Chinese Biomedical Literature Database, WanFang Database, China National Knowledge Infrastructure, and Chinese Scientific Journal Database. Two researchers performed the literature screening and study selection independently. Two researchers carried out the data extraction and bias risk assessment according to the standard Cochrane Risk of Bias tool. Three researchers independently carried out literature selection, data extraction, and bias risk assessment using the Cochrane Risk of Bias tool. Eventually, 2 RCTs and 1 cohort study were included in this study. Two RCTs and 1 cohort were included in the efficacy analysis. The CHM group showed a significantly higher total effective rate and clinical remission rate than the control group. The results revealed that the CHM group exhibited significantly lower adverse event rates than the combination group. One RCT compared CHM plus Western medicine versus Western medicine alone. Based on the available evidence, CHM may be effective and safe treatment for MG. Further research, including rigorously designed RCTs, will be needed to confirm the efficacy of CHM in treating MG. PROSPERO registration: CRD42017055987.

Background: Tonsillectomy for tonsil and/or adenoid hypertrophy is the most commonly performed ENT surgery in children, with an operation rate of 50 cases/100 000 children per year. The Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions' Risk of Bias will be employed to evaluate the risk of bias. Two review authors will independently extract data from the included papers, with any disagreement regarding inclusion being resolved by reaching consensus. Results will be expressed using odds ratios for dichotomous data, and mean difference and 95% confidence intervals from the weighted mean differences for continuous outcomes. Between 1961 and 1984, 46 patients underwent surgery for primary small bowel lymphoma. Thirty five were classified as low-grade malignant lymphomas, 7 as malignant lymphomas grade III, and 4 as high-grade lymphomas. Lymphomas of the small bowel are rare neoplasms and only represent a small proportion of intestinal malignant tumours. The clinical signs and symptoms of enteric lymphomas are similar to those of small bowel carcinomas, and the differential diagnosis between these 2 neoplasms requires clinical, radiological and histopathological studies. Diagnosis is often made many years after the onset of the symptoms, and delay in the diagnosis is therefore more frequent than in other neoplasms. Surgery is performed in more than half the patients and may be conservative in a good proportion of cases. Since the clinical symptoms are not typical but non-specific, it is often difficult to establish a clinical diagnosis of small bowel lymphoma. The diagnosis may be established using a histological specimen from a biopsy taken during an exploratory laparotomy. <EOD> Molecular Epidemiology of Klebsiella pneumoniae, Including Evolutionary Genetic Determinants of its High Global Importance

Klebsiella pneumoniae is an important human pathogen responsible for severe nosocomial and community-acquired infections. Genomic data are useful for understanding the population structure and evolutionary traits of this species. By conducting a genomics-based epidemiological study of K. pneumoniae from the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) AR bank and additional clinical isolates from the Scripps Institution of Research Center, we found a large variation in genetic diversity at the isolate and subspecies level. Two genetically distinct groups of clinical isolates were identified, which were further distinguished by different resistance phenotypes, presence in different geographic regions and association with hospital type. Analysis of the whole genome of the sequenced isolates (n = 44) in combination with K. pneumoniae genomes from GenBank (n = 1927) revealed high diversity with predominant representation of seven main sequence types. The seven sequence types were characterized by a variety of multidrug resistance (MDR) regions, including genetic features and molecular mechanisms of resistance to important antibiotics. We detected a novel pathway of macrolide and aminoglycoside drug resistance encoded by a conjugative transferable plasmid, and determined an integron carrying multidrug resistance, and T4SS, involved in the conjugal transfer of antibiotic resistance genes. This is the first study to identify genetic determinants associated with MDR regions, which can potentially lead to better understanding and predicting the evolution and spread of the pathogen in clinical settings and in the community. This knowledge will also allow researchers to develop preventive and therapeutic strategies.

# Introduction
Klebsiella pneumoniae is considered to be an opportunistic pathogen that causes infections such as pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and bacteremia. The pathogen is highly prevalent and causes substantial mortality in hospitalized patients [bib_ref]  Klebsiella spp. as nosocomial pathogens: epide

No other NMBAs were used in these patients''. However, in the description of methodology (''Statistical analysis''), they stated that they used two different NMBAs: ''cisatracurium and atracurium with the clinician's decision in the cisatracurium and atracurium group, respectively''. This leads to confusion and may be unjustified. ## 1.7.3 Explanation
Gaussian processes, in contrast to conventional probabilistic models, such as logistic regression, assume that the function is smooth to make predictions that are continuous.
In practice, the most common method for fitting Gaussian processes models to data is expectation-maximization (EM) algorithm. With Gaussian processes, you do not need to specify a specific function to model the data. Instead, you specify a covariance function for the process, e.g., squared exponential (SE) covariance function, which gives equal importance to both the mean and the variance.

To fit the model and derive the parameters, we used the scikit-learn package in Python. Here, we show how to fit a Gaussian process for binary outcomes. (For categorical outcomes, just replace the use of `is_trial_eligible_pred` from Step 2 and replace the `BinaryGaussianProcessRegression` from Step 3 with the `MultinomialGaussianProcessRegression'.)

# Implementation

### Implementing Eligibility Algorithm in EligibilityAI

The EligibiltyAI Python package implements an eligibility algorithm using natural language processing. Users can train a model to predict trial-level eligibility for their use-case using the [Train Eligibility Model](how-it-works.html). If a dataset is already prepared, it can be downloaded [here](data-preparation.html). Once training is complete, users may [intercept the data](how-to-use.html) with an EligibilityAI client by calling an API method, [get\_intercepted\_patient\_notes\_for\_analysis](API/APIv2/reference.html#get_intercepted_patient_notes_for_analysis). The data are then passed to the client's preprocess step, which prepares the data on the client for the eligiblity prediction algorithm described here. The method returns the preprocessed data.

Once the preprocessed data have been retrieved, a user may then use the EligibilityAI client to predict trial-level eligibility on new patients. The [get\_preprocessed\_intercepted\_patients\_for\_analysis](API/APIv2/reference.html#get_preprocessed_intercepted_patients_for_analysis) method returns a dataset consisting of the preprocessed patient data for all preprocessed patients, along with any other patient info specified by the user, for example the patient note text. The EligibilityAI client's [predict\_eligiblity](API/APIv2/reference.html#predict_eligibility) method returns a dataframe with predict scores for each patient. The dataframe for the predicted scores is formatted as follows.

```python
score_df={"score_1":..., "score_2":..., ...}
```

The score_1 column contains score for the trial-level eligibility score, score_n contains the score of the next trial eligibility. The algorithm predicts eligibility with a 3-point scale. If a patient is predicted to be eligible, each row describes the trial-level eligbility score predicted for each trial/factor on one patient. If a patient is predicted to not be

<EOD> The Fatty Acid Synthase Inhibitor Orlistat Displays Anticonvulsant Properties

Fatty acid synthase (FASN) inhibitors have been developed as potential therapeutics for the treatment of obesity and type 2 diabetes. Orlistat, a selective inhibitor of FASN, has been used successfully in the management of obesity in humans. Because orlistat is primarily excreted renally, we examined a potential role other than inhibition of adipogenesis in mediating its effect. Here we provide direct evidence for the first time that orlistat displays significant activity in reducing the duration of pentylenetetrazole (PTZ)-and bicuculline-induced seizures in Wistar rats without significant adverse effects. Dramatic dose-dependent increases in the latency of clonic and tonic convulsions were noted. Orlistat (30 mg/kg) produced a greater than 50% reduction in PTZ-induced seizures, and a significant enhancement in seizure threshold. Orlistat was effective in treating audiogenic seizures induced by exposure to loud noise. We further characterized its anticonvulsant potential using the maximal electroshock seizure model. Orlistat (7.5 and 30 mg/kg) was effective in preventing maximal electroshock-induced seizures, but had no effect on minimal electroshock seizures. We identified and confirmed that orlistat was able to produce an immediate and significant uptake of GABA in the brain. Finally, we discovered that orlistat inhibited the accumulation of cyclic AMP (cAMP) at the time of seizure onset. These findings indicate that an anticonvulsant action for orlistat is likely to be additive with its antiobesity properties. Hence orlistat could be a broad spectrum therapeutic candidate in the treatment of epilepsy.

## Problems with this task
There are a great many problems with this task, but what stands out is that the information is not very carefully explained in the task text, and the wording is difficult to understand for a novice clinical trialist, especially for clinicians.  For example, `would consider referring this patient to this clinical trial upon further investigation.` means different things to different people depending on their background.  So, although the text that the subject has to input sounds like something clinicians would put on a note, it is not the same thing as that.  There are no examples of a trial-level eligibility for readers to refer to (although there are some for what is meant by the word `highly likely` when making a trial-level eligibility assessment). These are not minor issues; they make it very difficult for people to complete the task.

To get better scores, we must ensure that our task design is consistent with the way someone who is really a trial assessor would evaluate a patient, and the criteria that they used to make a decision can be readily found.

Here are some suggestions to improve the current design.

> The `subject should enter a single assessment score when making a trial-level eligibility assessment` - This means that the assessment of eligibility is single-valued, and a score of 0, 1, or 2 is recorded in a trial-level assessment form for that trial (if needed). A subject should not change his/her assessment after observing the results of the clinical trial or the disease course of a patient during the trial.
> `would not refer this patient for this clinical trial` - This should never occur.  A subject that uses this option should be excluded from the task.
> The assessment should include all of the information that is currently in the trial-level assessment form.
The following fields are useful:
1. Eligibility assessment of 0 indicates that the subject should not be referred for the trial (e.g., unrealistic trial, patient refuses the trial, patient is not ready to participate in the trial).
2. Eligibility assessment of 1 should only be recorded for patients who have mild symptoms, e.g., cognitive symptoms are in the early stage and the patient still has a
