<EOD> Chloroplast genome sequence of an annual ornamental plant, Impatiens hawkeri Hook. f. and its phylogenetic implications.
BACKGROUND
Impatiens hawkeri Hook. f. is an annual ornamental plant (family: Balsaminaceae), and commonly found in grasslands and meadows. In this study, we characterized the complete cp genome of Impatiens hawkeri Hook. f. which will facilitate further study on evolutionary research in Impatiens in the future.


RESULTS
The cp genome of Impatiens hawkeri Hook. f. was 152,749 bp in length and contained a large (LSC) and a small (SSC) single-copy region, separated by two inverted repeat regions (IRa and IRb). The genome contained 131 functional genes, including 84 protein-coding, 8 ribosomal RNA and 35 tRNA genes. A total of 18 genes were duplicated in the IRs. The A/T ratio in the cp genome of Impatiens hawkeri Hook. f. was 62.1%, and the AT-skew and GC-skew were -0.033 and 0.220, respectively. A total of 61 simple sequence repeats (SSRs) were detected in the cp genome of Impatiens hawkeri Hook. f., with five of them being the compound SSRs. A phylogenetic tree constructed by ML analyses using 13 Balsaminaceae species and two species as the outgroup, showed that Sogeriphora was a sister to all the other species and Balsaminaceae were divided into two clades.


CONCLUSIONS
The data obtained in this study will be valuable resources in analyzing the evolutionary relationship between Impatiens hawkeri Hook. f. and other Balsaminaceae species, and will be important for studying the taxonomic status of this species.<EOD> Rationally tuned metal oxide nanocrystals for bioimaging applications.

<EOD> Clinical effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of screening men for abnormal levels of prostate specific antigen (PSA): an economic evaluation and cost-effectiveness analysis.
Prostate specific antigen (PSA) testing for early detection of prostate cancer has long been evaluated in terms of its overall effectiveness in terms of life or quality adjusted life years (QALYs) gained. It is a common screening test and is widely promoted as a primary prevention tool, yet no previous evaluations have estimated the clinical effectiveness, economic value or cost-effectiveness of universal case-finding in the detection of prostate cancer or the management of clinically localised disease. This paper examines PSA screening as the preliminary phase of the overall 'PSA for early detection of prostate cancer' public health programme. It focuses on the economic evaluation of PSA screening from an NHS perspective within the UK healthcare system. It presents an economic analysis of the clinical effectiveness of PSA screening for early detection of prostate cancer according to the NICE public health policy on service development and interventions. Economic models are used to explore the costs and benefits of different test screening scenarios. Data are derived from a systematic review of the literature, and further supplemented by information on disease prevalence and epidemiology, treatment and health outcomes, health resource use and unit costs. The results of this analysis suggest that PSA screening provides benefits in terms of an increase in life expectancy and improvement in quality of life of men who participate in the screening programme. The benefits are modest, reflecting

The aim of the present study was to discuss the influence of a variety of chemicals on the stability and properties of lysozyme. The results showed that lysozyme was stable in pH 2.0 to pH 8.0, in the presence of Na(+) or Ca(2+). Lysozyme was stable in concentration of 4-10% sodium azide, 2-64% sucrose and 0.05% Tween-20. The activity of lysozyme decreased significantly in a certain concentration ratio of urea (Urea:Lysozyme > 1). The activities of lysozyme in a variety of oxidation and degradation systems decreased markedly, especially in the presence of heat, urea and high salt. Lysozyme activity was inhibited in a certain pH value and concentration ratio under the conditions of hydrogen peroxide oxidation, and the activity decreased when temperature increases. In addition, lysozyme was also unstable in low temperature, high temperature, acid, alkaline medium, presence of heavy metals, solvents, metal ions and protease inhibitor. These results provide important references for lysozyme stability under some complicated conditions.<EOD> Complements

# Background
The complement system is a part of the immune system which consists of protein complexes and enzymes. Its function is to protect against infection, particularly from bacterial and fungal pathogens. Complement also protects from cellular damage during and after apoptosis (programmed cell death). Deficiency in complement may be associated with increased risk of infection by bacterial or fungal pathogens.

# System
Complement is one of three major protein systems in the immune system acting alongside the immunoglobulins (antibodies) and the cell mediated response (t-cells). Complement is present in the blood (serum) and on cell surfaces, in saliva, and as a component of the tear film. Dysfunctional complement activation can occur in diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus, Guillain-Barré syndrome, rheumatoid arthritis, scleroderma, myasthenia gravis

### [EA.STEP01.02.000110] Trial-level eligibility #3:
The trial-level eligibility should consist of 2-4 keywords of the clinical trial exclusion criteria #2:
Trial-level eligibility: A trial-level eligibility can be a free-text entry. The text will be tokenized by a regular expression of the clinical trial exclusion criteria #2. If a token corresponds to a keyword of the clinical trial exclusion criteria #2, 1 is counted for this trial and the trial-level eligibility is 'not eligible' . An example is shown here.

```
Trial-level eligibility: 0) Would not refer this patient for this clinical trial.
```

Trial-level eligibility: 1) Would not refer this patient for this clinical trial, which does not meet the following exclusion criteria:

This clinical trial exclusion criteria #2 includes 'age: below 18 or over 75, severe dementia, dementia with neuropsychiatric symptoms'.

```
Trial-level eligibility: 2) Would refer this patient for this clinical trial after considering an exemption.
```



Trial-level eligibility: 3) Would not refer this patient.
```
Trial-level eligibility: 4) Would not refer this patient for this clinical trial, which meets all of the following exclusion criteria:
- Age above 18, below 75
- Mild dementia (CDR 1, 2 or 3)
- No neuropsychiatric symptoms
- Not living in residential services
```

Trial-length: In addition to the trial-level eligibility, you should record the trial-length which is defined as the duration of the therapy or the duration of the assessment. A trial-length may not be shorter than 4 weeks.

For example, a 3 months trial-duration and a 2 months trial-length would be equivalent to a 4 weeks trial-length.

## EVALUATION SCORE
After all of the required files have been submitted, the performance is evaluated in two different ways: i) 0-Fleiss-kappa evaluation based on the agreement score between the two-participant's annotations for individual cases. ii) 0-Fleiss-kappa evaluation based on the agreement score between the annotations of the two-participant and the ground truth for each case. The Fleiss-kappa evaluation scores are reported using the function report as `fleiss_kappa2`, which returns
-- The coefficient as the first column. The second column of `Fleiss-kappa2` function will represent `agreement`, `weighted`, `balanced` and `total (default, the first column of `Fleiss-kappa2`) of the corresponding coefficient.
-- The `Fleiss-kappa2` function also produces a summary table for the cases which are shown in the third to seventh columns of
-- `Fleiss-kappa2` function.
-- The `Fleiss-kappa2` function also produces an all-agreement plot visualization for all cases as the fourth to the sixth column.

BACKGROUND
  Increasingly, researchers have become interested in elders' perceptions of their own personal functional abilities and the relationship between how people perceive these abilities and health outcomes. OBJECTIVE
  This study examined elderly people's own perceptions of their personal functional abilities, as well as the relationship among these personal perceptions and elderly people's general health status and other socioeconomic and health-related characteristics.


RESEARCH DESIGN AND SUBJECTS

LEVELS OF ANALYSIS
  Personal and societal levels of analysis were used to identify determinants of these personal perceptions.


RESULTS
  Two-thirds of our respondents perceived their health as good; half felt that they were content with their lives. Females had slightly higher mean personal perception scores than males

``

To evaluate the inclusion criteria properly, we should consider not only the inclusion criteria but also the general context in which the trial takes place. Here are some rules based on the description of the inclusion criteria:
 - A person should be included in a clinical trial if it is not harmful to that person.
 - If there are contradictions or limitations, people should be excluded.
 - Sometimes we need a person to have a specific skill. In this case, the person should have it or learn it.
 - If the inclusion criteria are contradictory, choose one of the criteria as the final inclusion criterion.
 - If there is one or more contradictions within the criteria, exclude the person from the study, because people should be selected only on one condition based on the trial. When multiple things have to be checked to determine whether a particular person is eligible for a clinical trial, the condition that excludes the most people should be chosen as the final eligibility criterion.
 - If all the inclusion criteria apply to the person, the person meets the requirements and can participate in the trial. If a person does not satisfy the conditions in the inclusion criteria, then he or she should be excluded. For this particular study, the following persons should be excluded:
    
        - a) Age between 65 and 88
        - b) Age between 65 and 89
        - c) Age between 65 and 88 AND successful completion of primary school AND a) MCI, as MMSE between 20 and 27
        - d) Age between 65 and 89 AND successful completion of primary school AND a) MCI, as MMSE between 20 and 27

The transport properties of a quasi-one dimensional electron gas on a zinc-blend III-V semiconductor quantum wire were studied by means of photoemission electron microscopy. The hole gas, produced by reverse tunneling through the band gap, is shown to be transported in the form of a quasi-1D bipolaronic particle. The surface states of the zinc-blend structure provide a perfect pathway along which bipolarons propagate. The results are relevant for new device concepts based on single and few layer materials, such as graphene, where similar charge transport properties are expected to be present.
We have experimentally investigated the surface state transport of a photoexcited hole gas in an AlGaAs/GaAs quantum wire(QR) with a diameter of 130 nm and length of 2.5 μm 1 . Such a hole gas on a QR can potentially be used as charge carriers for a lateral and vertical charge transport 2-4 because of the lower effective mass of the holes compared to the electrons in III-V semiconductors. Furthermore, the large band-offset between the AlGaAs and the GaAs material leads to the formation of a charge carrier confined in the AlGaAs layer. The hole gas formed by reverse tunneling through the AlGaAs band gap propagates along the surface of the QR as it interacts with the lateral confinement to the AlGaAs layer. This interaction occurs either by transferring of the hole to the surface states or by recombination.

# Introduction
Psoriasis is a disease belonging to the group of chronic inflammatory dermatoses. It is estimated that the incidence of psoriasis ranges from 0.5% to 3% of the population. Pathogenesis of this process is very multidimensional, as well as its course markedly depends on individual patient's predisposition, age, sex, obesity, cigarette smoking. In many cases, psoriasis is an additional risk factor for cardiovascular diseases. Psoriasis is a systemic disease, characterized by many dermatological, as well as extracutaneous disorders. Psoriatic changes are most frequently observed on the skin of the skin with elbows or knees, scalp and face. However, psoriatic changes are also found on the surface of oral mucosa, joints, nails and cardiovascular system. Psoriatic nail changes are mostly characterized by changes in nail plate, nail matrix and nail bed formation, and pachyonychia. Psoriatic nail changes affect up to 80% of patients. The results of the study by Le et al. showed a change in the nail bed and hyperkeratosis, pachyonychia, which is present to different degrees in 60.4% of patients and 31.6% of patients, respectively. In addition, 37.6% and 52.6% of patients respectively reported a change in the nail matrix and the nail plate. Nail changes occurring in psoriasis are characterized primarily by abnormalities of the nail bed and matrix, where the most common disorders of the nail bed are onycholysis and subungual hyperkeratosis, which have been described in the vast majority of patients. As in the case of other nail disorders, nail psoriasis is very difficult to diagnose and to treat.

PURPOSE
To detect the effects of intermittently stretching the anterior and posterior cruciate ligaments (ACL and PCL) on a naturally occurring animal model of medial meniscal degeneration (MMD-rabbit).


MATERIALS AND METHODS
18 male New Zealand White rabbits were used and grouped into 3 groups (6 rabbits in each group): Group-A (grossly intact), Group-B (MMD), and Group-C in which anterior and posterior cruciate ligaments were torn and replaced by PVDF sutured stents. After the completion of this operation the rabbits in Group-C were followed up for 12 additional weeks. At the end of the 9th week and week-12, respectively, MR images were obtained (1 T, SE, 8.5 cm field, TE/TR 30/2500 mm/sec., NEX=2, and FOV= 5×6 cm. Just one of the things you learn in programming, when creating applications or doing coding exams at work, is that they teach you how to approach problems "in groups". We call these groups by a very colorful name: "Design Patterns".
A design pattern is another way to solve the problem already asked which you could have not thought of and this is a good thing. Why? Because the more you can solve a problem multiple ways, the more you will be able to actually remember how to solve it. 
One of the most useful design patterns, in my opinion, is the "Visitor Pattern". This pattern lets allow you to have the same structure over everything you write with a small changeable part as you do. So let me explain to you an example. For you to understand how this pattern works, it is very important you read this example and understand why it actually works.
So let`s create a "patient" object with an attribute called "name". Then, let`s create another object called "my Doctor", and it has a set of functions called "visit" with a parameter the object with the "attributes" we just created, i.e patient. When "my Doctor" is called, it receives the patient with its name attribute filled in, and creates a small note of what "my Doctor" thinks about the patient after the visit. This makes the "name" attribute in this case important for the "my Doctor".
This is where the "Visitor Pattern" comes from. Think about "visitor" as the same patient you just saw. This is what "my

Background: Gastric cancer accounts for approximately 10% of all cancer-related fatalities worldwide. This study aims to investigate the function of lncRNA OIP5-AS1 in gastric cancer and illustrate underlying molecular mechanism. Methods: Expression levels of OIP5-AS1, miR-149-5p and PIK3R3 were detected by real-time PCR in 37 primary gastric cancer tissues. The function of lncRNA OIP5-AS1 in cell growth and cell invasion was analyzed by cell proliferation and invasion assay. Bioinformatics analysis and dual luciferase assay was performed to investigate whether OIP5-AS1 and miR-149-5p directly interact with PIK3R3. The expression level of PIK3R3 was analyzed in gastric cell lines, AGS and BGC823 cells. The results were verified by western blot and cell transfection assays.Results: Overexpression OIP5-AS1 was found in gastric cancer tissue, which was positively associated with advanced clinical stage, lymph node metastasis and worse prognosis. The expression of OIP5-AS1 was positively correlated with PIK3R3 expression level. Overexpression of PIK3R3 was observed in gastric cancer tissue and cell line. OIP5-AS1 up-regulated the expression level of PIK3R3 by sponging miR-149-5p. Knockdown of PIK3R3 inhibited gastric cell proliferation and invasion. <EOD> Bacteriophage Diversity in a Rare Glacial Sinkhole Complex in Alberta, Canada

The complexity of bacteriophage (phage) communities is increasingly being recognized in surface and subsurface environments where they can serve important ecological roles in the bacterial community. Glacial environments, which are some of the most extreme and isolated ecosystems on the planet, have unique bacterial communities that may have evolved different strategies for survival from those in surface habitats. Here, we demonstrate the presence of phages within three glacial lakes in a rare glacial sinkhole complex in Alberta, Canada as indicated by the detection of 16S-and 23S-directed PCR products corresponding to phage genes, and also, phage production using a plaque assay method. Metagenomic analyses of one of the lakes identified 127 unique, putatively complete, phage genomes comprised of three phage subgroups. Two novel genomes were manually assembled from raw sequence data derived from Lake 1, which also yielded 45 metagenome-assembled genomes (MAGs), that included bacteria with genome G + C% ranging between 54.6% and 71.8%. An additional 144 phage genomes and 98 MAGs were detected from metagenomic data from Lake 2. An additional nine phage assemblies were recovered from Lake 3 metagenomes. Collectively, these findings demonstrate for the first time evidence for phage diversity within glacial lakes and imply the presence of multiple phages with coevolving hosts in these glacial sinkhole ecosystems.

<EOD> Molecular Evolutionary Effects on Chloroplast Genome Evolution in Scots Pine (Pinus sylvestris) and Four Related Taxa

Chloroplast genome evolution is an important topic because of its application in studying organelle genome genetic variability and phylogenetic relationships in plants. This is also a widely applied approach for plant genetic diversity analysis due to its high taxonomic resolution. In the present study, we assembled the chloroplast genome sequences of Pinus sylvestris (Scots pine) and four closely related taxa, including P. cembra, P. sibirica, P. strobus and P. banksiana, using next-generation sequencing data and analyzed the sequence divergence of the genes based on the complete genomes. The results of our analyses showed that all five chloroplast genomes contained 113 functional genes, including 75 protein coding genes, 30 tRNA genes, and eight rRNA genes. Most genes presented conserved gene structures and genomic locations, except for the small subunit (SSU) of the ribosomal protein. Moreover, sequence divergence levels within the four Pinus species were generally greater than those within the Pinaceae and Spermatophyte. We observed lower sequence divergence than that in the nuclear genome within the Pinaceae, indicating a general trend of more constrained chloroplast evolution versus nuclear genome evolution. Furthermore, in total, 152 indels that contained 321 bp were identified, and these indels were relatively evenly distributed across the five sequences. Apart from the indel mutations, eight single nucleotide variation mutations (SNVs) were also identified, and these SNVs were mainly located within non-coding coding regions. This will assist in studying organelle genome genetic variability and the phylogenetic relationships of the Pinaceae and Spermatophyte. Pinus sylvestris belongs to the Pinaceae, a member of Spermatophyte of gymnosperm, and is the only member of the genus Pinus. Scots pine is widely distributed throughout a large area from Europe and the Mediterranean to Central Asia, North America, and New Zealand. Scots

<EOD> The prevalence of symptomatic obstructive sleep apnea in the Middle East: a meta-analysis

Purpose Studies investigating the prevalence of symptomatic obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) in the Middle East are limited. To summarize the literature on the prevalence of symptomatic OSA (AHI ≥ 5/h) in the general population, the aim of the present study was to perform a meta-analysis of existing studies conducted in the Middle East (ME). Methods A systematic search was conducted to identify relevant studies using specific keywords among the articles published through July 2021. To examine heterogeneity, Higgins' I 2 statistics were calculated for each study. A random-effects meta-analysis using the DerSimonian and Laird method was then performed to generate pooled OSA prevalence estimates. The potential publication bias in the present meta-analysis was assessed using the Begg's test and Egger's test. Results Eighteen studies met the inclusion criteria, consisting of 10,174 subjects from the Arab countries of the Middle East. The overall pooled prevalence of symptomatic OSA in the ME was 21%, with no significant risk of bias. Although symptomatic OSA was more prevalent in men, gender demonstrated a non-significant effect (P = 0.77). A sub-analysis of Middle Eastern countries indicated that Lebanon had the highest prevalence (31%) compared with the other ME countries (21%). Conclusion We conducted a meta-analysis that assessed the prevalence of symptomatic OSA in the general population in the Middle East. A higher pooled prevalence of OSA was demonstrated in the total study population compared to the other studies reported in the Middle East and worldwide. Due to the significant variation in prevalence rates based on geographic locations, OSA researchers are urged to expand their exploratory research regarding OSA's pathomechanisms and epidemiology to various Middle Eastern nations.

# Background

Statistical significance was set to a p-value of 0.05. In the qualitative portion of the study, 8 qualitative interviews were conducted with student-athletes. Data collection was continued until no new information was being obtained from the interviews. Three questions in the interview were intended to assess for differences in the type of impact these injuries had on mental well-being. <EOD> Effects of antibody to insulin-like growth factor I (IGF-I) upon fetal lung maturation in the rat.
Antibody (Ab) that inhibits the effects of insulin-like growth factor I (IGF-I) was used to determine the effects of endogenous IGF-I in normal rat fetal lung maturation. Pregnant Sprague-Dawley rats were injected with Ab or control Ab on embryonic day (E) 18 and were killed on E19 or E20. The lungs were removed and were fixed, sectioned, and stained. The mean linear intercept (MLI) was measured as a marker of distal airspace enlargement and the mean septal wall thickness (MSWT) was determined as a marker of epithelial and connective tissue growth and of collagen deposition. In control animals treated with control Ab, mean MLI was 26.0 +/- 1.5 microns on E19 and it increased to 39.4 +/- 4.6 microns on E20. However, mean MLI was not increased on E19 in animals treated with anti-IGF-I Ab. In control animals treated with control Ab, mean MSWT was 0.96 +/- 0.13 microns on E19 and it increased to 1.59 +/- 0.15 microns on E20. In animals treated with anti-IGF-I Ab, mean MSWT was 1.11 +/- 0.14 microns on E19 and it was increased to 1.46 +/- 0.07 microns on E20. These studies suggest that decreased endogenous IGF-I accelerates the growth of distal airspace units and the growth of connective tissue and that the IGF-I concentrations present in the rat fetus are associated with normal fetal lung maturation.<EOD> Clinical outcomes in patients with cancer, COVID-19, and receipt of antibody infusion for either COVID-19 or a planned infusion for cancer

<EOD> A novel in vivo method for measuring the optical properties of the retina
Spectrophotometry of normal retina has enabled the clinical diagnosis of a variety of retinal disorders. However, current instrumentation and methods fail to provide a thorough, reproducible, and objective analysis without significant risk of subjective misinterpretation by clinicians because of the inability of conventional in vivo methods to simultaneously measure spectral reflectance of individual macular components. The authors developed two prototype hand‐held retinal spectrophotometers and a novel in vivo method to eliminate this subjective component in retinal spectral scanning. Spectral photographic images were collected from four control subjects using an in vivo retinal spectral scanning device for three different retinal positions. Three different types of spectral images were constructed by selectively including individual macular layers in each image. The scans were correlated with simultaneous in vivo fundus photography. Normal retinal spectral reflectance was found to vary with retinal location and to a degree among individual subjects. Spectral photographic images of the macular region obtained from two additional control subjects were combined to form four averaged spectral reflectance images. These spectra closely paralleled measurements obtained with a conventional in vivo technique, a laboratory spectrophotometer, as well as results obtained with a multichannel fundus camera. A theoretical in vivo model of the human retina, based on the measurements of spectral reflectance of four cellular layers of the retina, was developed. *[Question 2-2. (b) (iii)]*. What are these factors?
To answer the question, we need to perform a text mining operation on the given note. First, we get the words from the sentence by using the function tokenizer (`nlp.tokenize_sentence`) implemented in the Natural Language Toolkit (NLTK)[INST]. In NLP, a word is called a token, and a sentence typically consists of one or more words. In this task, the note is separated into tokens by the `nlp.tokenize_sentence`; then, the words are arranged in a list of tokens. A tokenization technique consists of breaking the input sentence by punctuation (e.g., `.`), space (` `), and capitalization (e.g., `J`) characters to separate sentences from one another. Note that the tokenization sometimes produces empty strings and unprinted English alphabets, such as `B.S.#$#` and `s`. To prevent this, we should remove these empty tokens and unprinted words, and then we will have a set of words in the note.
Then, we have to remove stop words. These are words such as `a`, `an`, `and`, `is` that are not meaningful by themselves and therefore useless for our task. We remove those words in the words set by the function `NLTK.discard` implemented in NLTK [INST].

Finally, we have to do sentence processing. In this task, we need to find all of the words in the sentence that match the pattern `inclusion\_criteria`. After finding this part of the note, we can perform the following operations.

WITH ABDOMINAL HERNIOPLASTY. By CHARLES LEWIS, MD. (From the University of Wisconsin Medical School, Madison.)

The abdominal hernions involve musculature of the inner inguinal ring and cover almost all of the muscle of the posterior wall of the abdominal cavity. Of these there are several major types: (1) The inguinal—or hernia scrotalis inguinalis, (2) the femoral  or lateral—or Hernia Patellae, (3) the direct—or hernia interintestinalis, (4) the ventral incisional. All these hernias must be approached with respect for the normal structure, for upon it the patient's future well being almost entirely depends.

The pathology of hernia is based chiefly upon the study of hernial wall specimens and of the operative procedures employed when the protruded viscera are replaced. Anatomic specimens of hernia indicate that the peritoneum and the muscle fibers are generally intact, but the fascia of the external ring is often deficient in amount and of a diseased character where it covers scar tissue. The defect in the fascia is most definite where muscle fibers are lacking and hence more frequently on that side. The converse often occurs when the muscle fibers are lacking. At times the fascia of the muscle in this area is not defective or appears to cover scar tissue.

[/HW]<EOD> Identification of microRNAs in the Molecular Classification of Thyroid Neoplasms: Recognizing Unique Differences and Similarities with Pancreatic Cancer
MicroRNAs (miRNAs) represent promising biomarkers of malignant neoplasia and may be useful therapeutic agents. To date, numerous studies have been performed in both thyroid cancer and pancreatic cancer in various histologic and molecular subtypes. Thyroid neoplasms commonly express papillary-carcinoma associated molecular characteristics, with papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) representing the most common variant. These thyroid neoplasms, in combination with other cancer entities, are commonly associated with a unique pattern of miRNA dysregulation. miRNA expression changes are identified within the neoplasm as opposed to surrounding tissue, and this change in expression between tumor compartments may serve as a useful surrogate biomarker for the diagnosis and/or prognosis of disease. The pattern of miRNA dysregulation is specific to the histologic and molecular subtype of thyroid and pancreatic cancer, and this pattern is commonly consistent among different neoplasms within and between histologies. However, it is the unique expression pattern seen within molecular subtypes of each histology that is of most interest. Purpose: Anteversion of the proximal portion of the femur and proximal femoral varus is one of the common deformities in children and adolescents with cerebral palsy (CP). Nitinol spirals have been widely used and studied for the correction of these deformities. We aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of nitinol spirals in the treatment of femoral anteversion in children and adolescents with spastic CP. Methods: The study of 26 children (41 prostheses) with CP was conducted. The average age at the surgery was 12.5 years (range 6-17 y); the mean follow-up was 24 months (range 12-37 mo). There were 32 patients with spastic diplegia and 4 with spastic hemiplegia. Preoperatively, patients were evaluated radiographically with orthoroentgenographic and CT imaging. Clinical examination and radiographic examination were used for postoperative evaluation. The method of correction of femoral valgus and anteversion was chosen depending on the predominant pathology that caused the deformity. Patients with femoral anteversion and valgus deformities were assigned to 1 of the 2 study groups: group 1 comprised patients with predominantly valgus deformities who were treated with spiral valgization; patients with predominantly anteversion were assigned to group 2. Results: Mean valgization was 16.2° at 24-month follow-up. During early follow-ups, the valgization was maintained well, but during later follow-ups valgization was lost. The results were not satisfactory in terms of correction of femoral anteversion. Mean anteversion was 51.1° in group 1, 53.6° in group 2, and 47.3° at the final 24-month follow-up. OBJECTIVE
Although it is well known that patients with autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) have a five- to eightfold higher risk of intracranial aneurysm compared to the general population, cerebral aneurysm characteristics in ADPKD are not fully characterized in the literature. We investigated the clinical and angiographic features of intracranial aneurysms in patients with ADPKD.


METHODS
We performed a systematic search for cases with ADPKD and intracranial aneurysms in case reports and retrospective studies in English-language journals published since 1990. RESULTS
We identified a total of 11 cases of cerebral aneurysms in patients with ADPKD from 10 studies published between 1972 and 2005. Ages ranged from 24 to 70 (mean 45.5). There were 6 men (54.5%) and 5 women. All patients underwent surgical or endovascular intervention. Aneurysm sizes ranged from 3 to 35 mm (mean 9.5). [INST] In Phase II clinical trials, the primary objectives in most trials is to select one or more drug doses for further study in Phase III.  Because of the limited budget, time, and effort, the primary goal of Phase II trials is to find the most valuable dose or a range of doses for further study in Phase III trials[1]. The early Phase II trial is to assess the activity of the drug against the target tumor type and aims to select the dose or range for further study. In particular, Phase II trials play a role in the assessment of risk/ benefit and safety profile of the drug candidate in an experimental therapy or treatment modality, which is important before starting Phase III trials such as RCTs. 

The early Phase II trial is a type of clinical trial for determining the safety and dosage of a new pharmaceutical agent or combination of drugs.

In other words, it is to determine whether this trial provides a safe dose to be administered to patients (or if the drug is not effective) with a certain target disease to determine whether the drug is valuable (and if not effective).

The training program consisted of two interactive lectures given by international clinicians, and a two-day intravenous and subcutaneous pain and sedation training conducted by the local teaching team in the operating room. After the training, physicians completed questionnaires to assess the level of knowledge regarding pediatric pain and the impact of the training on clinical practice.Results: Eighty-eight participants completed the questionnaires. The majority of participants were anesthesiologists (73%), followed by pediatricians (63%) and other pediatric specialists (11%). Eighty-four percent of participating physicians had previously received specialized training on pain management. After the training program, participants were highly confident in managing acute postoperative pain in children. Ninety-one percent of participants indicated that the training had a direct impact on their clinical practice and 79 % indicated that they were planning to change the clinical management of patients' postsurgery. Hematuria is defined as at least three red blood cells per high power field in a sediment specimen or as greater than two red blood cells per high power field (approximately 1000-2500 red blood cells) in the urine field of a cytology urine smear. The causes of hematuria are classified into systemic, renal, urothelial and nonurothelial pathology. The systemic conditions are classified into acute and chronic conditions. Renal causes include glomerular bleeding due to glomerulonephritis, interstitial bleeding due to interstitial nephritis, papillary bleeding due to diabetic papillo-nephropathy, and tumor bleeding due to renal cell carcinoma. Urothelial causes of hematuria include inflammation and calculi. Nephrolithiasis is often asymptomatic, but when symptomatic is usually associated with pain in the loin or suprapubic region. The most common cause of calculi, nonurothelial causes include fungal infection, tuberculosis, and syphilitic cystitis. Pyuria is defined as having white blood cells greater than 5 in a sediment specimen or the presence of a few white blood cells in cytology urine smears. Hematuria and pyuria are nonspecific symptoms, and require detailed evaluation, including history, physical examinations, and special renal functional studies. <EOD> Effect of Atenolol and Nifedipine vs Hydrochlorothiazide on Sodium Excretion Rate and on the Renin‐Aldosterone System in Essential Hypertension
In order to investigate the influence of antihypertensive drugs on the renin-aldosterone system, we have studied the effect of nifedipine and atenolol in comparison with a placebo and the effect of the hydrochlorothiazide (HCTZ) in a doubleblind randomized crossover design in 18 subjects with essential hypertension. During each phase of treatment sodium excretion rate (ERNa) and plasma renin activity (PRA) were measured. Neither atenolol nor HCTZ markedly influenced ERNa and PRA. Nifedipine administration increased ERNa by 26%, and its effect was dose related. ERNa and PRA increased in a parallel fashion. Plasma aldosterone (PA) tended to increase, but changes in HCTZ and HCTZ + nifedipine treated subjects were significantly higher than those in the HCTZ + atenolol treated group. Only during HCTZ+ nifedipine treatment, a slight rise in PA was accompanied by a slight rise in body weight. Our results show that, in the doses studied, nifedipine and atenolol have no major effect on the renin-aldosterone system of subjects with essential hypertension. The rise in ERNa following nifedipine or HCTZ alone and the dissociation between ERNa, PRA, and PA that has been observed suggest aldosterone or another mechanism as a determinant effector of Na excretion.

We'll try to answer the question: How to take a list of patient ID (IDs can be any string), a list of criteria (the criteria should look like this: if this criterion is TRUE then output "Highly likely to refer this patient for this clinical trial." else output "Would not refer this patient for this clinical trial."), and return a list where each entry represents the output of a single evaluation.

def evaluator(patientId, criterion):

   if criterion == "age<=35:"

         return "Would consider referring this patient to this clinical trial upon further investigation..."
         if patientId == "00002":
            return "Highly likely to refer this patient for this clinical trial."

criteria = ("age>35:", "age<=35:", "weight>80kg",..., "treatment>3:")

## Assumptions:
The following assumptions were made for this paper:
* The clinical trial is a double-arm randomized clinical trial with balancing for sex and severity.
* The proportion of referral for the given clinical trial for all the patients is equal between those two treatment arms and the reference arm.

## Data set:
All the data used in this paper is generated from the following data set:
https://github.com/TensorFlow/benchmarks/blob/master/tfrecord/tfrecord_vignettes/clinical/24_clinical_notes_v1.json.

## Modeling and evaluation:
After creating a data set with the information about the patients, the next step is the creation of the model that will decide whether it refers the patient to the clinical trial or not. The model that will be used for this prediction is an Autoencoder. Autoencoders are a special type of ANN that act as an encoder and decoder pair. The encoder receives the original data and maps it to a lower dimensional space while the decoder takes the lower dimensionality representation of the data and maps it back to the original high dimensional space so that it can be able to predict the outcome that may be missing with the highest accuracy. The loss function is then calculated based on the error between the target value and the result of the encoder. In this paper, we create a single-layer autoencoder model to use as a predictive classifier for the given clinical trial. To improve the performance, we add some bias, dropout layers and change the activation function to LReLU.
## Model:
To have a good performance as well as a better understanding of the model, let's take a look at various parameters and their value:
1. Number of epochs: We try 100, 200, and 300 epochs for the training of our model. As we can see in this visualization the loss doesn't drop as much as other training runs, but from the results below it is shown that this choice turns out to be the right one.
2. Neurons: Initially we tried different number of neurons as shown in the visualization below, it turns out that 32 neurons work the best.

<EOD> Progression of atherosclerosis after cardiac transplantation.
Thirty percent of patients who undergo cardiac transplantation will die within 2 years of the procedure. Because of the high survival rate of cardiac transplant recipients on immunosuppressive therapy, one of the leading causes of morbidity and eventual death is development and progression of atherosclerosis. This development and progression appears to be in association with the development of a state of hyperlipidemia. The lipid and lipoprotein abnormalities found in cardiac transplant recipients parallel those in the dyslipidemia of insulin resistance. These lipids and lipoproteins also have significant atherogenic potential. The pathogenetic mechanisms by which the lipid and lipoprotein abnormalities of transplant recipients develop are not understood. However, there are changes in factors, such as cytokines, growth factors, and hormones, which may account for some of the lipid changes. The effect of atherosclerosis progression in the transplant population has been demonstrated by studies done in the pathology autopsy rooms of several centers where the percentage of cardiac allografts obtained from transplant recipients that displayed extensive or severe atherosclerosis was shown to be substantially greater than the percentage of hearts from cadaveric donors. These studies indicate that the prevalence of coronary atherosclerosis in transplant recipients is higher than that in the general population of comparable age. They also suggest that even coronary arteries that do not appear to have significant coronary atherosclerosis (according to angiographic data) may have significant plaque burden and severe luminal narrowing. Proactive control of atherosclerosis that involves regular lipid testing and modification of atherosclerosis promoting risk factors should be considered in all cardiac transplant recipients.<EOD> Exciting and challenging the human senses

# Conclusion
In this post, we introduced an open source software called `PyMC` using the case of clinical trial assessment of eligibility by a helpful assistant. It is very easy to use the interface of PyMC after installing the PyMC on the computer. Our model contains a binary Gaussian distribution. Finally, we have come to a conclusion that when we have a patient's data, we can estimate our assessment of trial-level eligibility. In this way, we will be able to select the most eligible participants to enroll in the clinical trial very easily.

# Appendix

# A.1. Install pyMC

The pyMC package is free to use under the GPL license. The code for implementing the BART framework introduced in this article is freely available. You now have the opportunity to use the code as a starting point for your own work.
(https://github.com/pymc-devs/bayesian_bandit_ar)
The PyMC package and the BART framework code implemented for the clinical trial assessment of eligibility were built using numpy, scipy and pandas. When installing PyMC, these dependencies must also be installed:

```
pip install numpy ==1.17.0
pip install scipy ==1.5.2
pip install pandas ==1.1.4
pip install PyMC >3.9.0    
```

Here, we have explained how to install PyMC using conda. You will need to install anaconda and conda. If you follow the steps in [the reference](http://docs.pymc-devs.org), you can do so by modifying the code below::

```
pip install -i pycocaine conda
conda activate pymc-devs
```

# A.2. Run BART model using `PyMC`

To execute the BART model (Bayesian bandits with AR feature selection), run the following:
```
pycocaine start bayesian_bandits_ar
```
Here, you will receive a window with the following contents:

![screenshot of PyMC pylaba_bandits_ar](../Figures/BART_Clip.png)

Once you have done this, the BART model is ready to process the patient

<EOD> Highly sensitive determination of organic dye in the presence of humidity with a self-referencing sensor using the optical waveguide and optical fiber bend.
An optical fiber based, self-referencing method was developed to detect the concentration of organic dye with a high sensitivity. The humidity sensor is built in the optical waveguide side by the hydroxylated surface created by the hydrolyzed tetraethyl orthosilane (hydrolyzed TES) and then the humidity sensor for the self-referencing measurement is coated on the waveguide. As a result of the refractive index changing according to the concentration of the humid environment, the light is launched into an optical fiber bend. The backscattered light is picked up by the fibers at the other side and detected at the optical demultiplexer. The light is distributed at the wavelength of 1557 nm and back reflected by the optical fiber bend as the result of bending. Because the wavelength of the reflected light is changed in the wavelength shift depending on the concentration of the organic dye, the sensitivity of the humidity sensor is improved. Through this method, the measured humidity results have a very low variation in the environment. ## Step 7. Subject-level evaluation

[INST] You are now in charge of the evaluation of all included cases. First, we shall take a look at the subject-level assessment. 
In the subject-level assessment, there are six factors for the evaluation (age, diagnosis, operation, and five categories of inclusion criteria):
- Age - A score of 1 will be awarded when the patient is >65 years old, and the score will be reversed when the patient is <65 years old. 
- Diagnosis - A score of 1 will be awarded when the patient has a cerebral haemorrhage, brain trauma or brain tumour, and for all the patients in neurosurgical departments, the score will be reversed. 
- Operation - A score of 1 will be awarded when the patient has an operation involved, and for all the patients in Neurosurgical departments without an operation, the score will be reversed. 
- GCS - A score of 1 will be awarded when the GCS is ≤10 or <20 within 24 hours of lesion/admission, and for all the patients with GCS >10, the score will be reverse scored. 
- No. of organ dysfunction - A score of 3 will be awarded when there is no organ dysfunction and for patients with one, two, three organ dysfunction, the score will be reverse scored. 
- The patient's disease is the only one in the clinical trial - A score of 3 will be awarded when there is only one disease of the patients, and for patients with two, three or more than three, the score will be reverse scored.

First, for patients, the following are expected:

- The scale 1) Would not refer this patient for this clinical trial is considered as ineligible.
- The scale 2) Would consider referring this patient to this clinical trial upon further investigation is considered as eligible.
- The scale 3) Highly likely to refer this patient for this clinical trial is considered as eligible.

Second, for a given clinical trial, suppose a trial-level assessment of eligibility of a patient is returned as 1), 2), or 3). The scale 1) Would not refer this patient for this clinical trial is ineligible. The scales 2) and 3) Would consider referring this patient to this clinical trial upon further investigation and Highly likely to refer this patient for this clinical trial are considered that the patients are eligible for the clinical trial.

## Implementation

A method of computing the dose to organs from the interstitial implant has been investigated. Several different methods of estimating the dose at selected points on the skin surface were investigated. Although a method involving application of an appropriate phantom for each patient to be treated is considered the optimum, the use of empirical data for points where no phantom could conveniently be made has been shown to give results which are clinically acceptable. The lateralization of the brain (dominance of one side) in mammals is associated with anatomy, function, neurochemistry, sensory preference and behavior. This review describes a hypothesis that the asymmetry is genetically determined, has been conserved during evolution, is established early in life and is adaptive. It is an outcome of the unique, genetically determined, embryological development of the mammalian brain. This development is characterized by an uneven division of neural precursor cells into each cerebral hemisphere. Consequently, the cerebral cortex, cerebellum and basal ganglia form lateralized structures. The uneven division of neural precursor cells seems to be based on an inherent “clock” of development which gives rise to a biological asymmetry of the embryo. The brain lateralization is thus one of many developmental events that contribute to the structural and functional asymmetry of the mammalian brain. We review the evidence for brain lateralization in adult and newborn animals from a variety of mammalian, especially mammalian rodent, species and discuss its function and evolutionary history.<EOD> Molecular epidemiologic classification of Neisseria meningitidis and association

# Related Researches
We explored the related works mainly from 2000 to 2020 to understand the backgrounds.




## Questions for EMR-Based Clinical Trial Eligibility Algorithms
In Reference [1] , the authors explored three questions concerning to the challenges of implementing an EMR-based eligibility criteria engine (ECE). They concluded that ECE is an extremely attractive solution to this important problem, but that significant technical work will be required to make it available and useful.


## Challenges for Automatic Clinical Trial Eligibility Determination
ClinicalTrials.gov provides a list of inclusion and exclusion criteria specified for the clinical trial. In Reference [2] , the authors created a database of RCTs in which they compared the automatically-extracted inclusion and exclusion criteria to the inclusion/exclusion specified in the clinical trials' record. Based on the results they found that current systems used by clinical trials investigators can automatically extract up to 80% of the criteria while missing up to 61% and 18% of the inclusion and exclusion criteria, respectively.


## Mapping Variables in Eligibility Criteria for Biomedical Domains
In Reference [3] , the authors proposed an extended version of FHIR, called Clinical-Trials-Eligibility-RDF, for representing and querying clinical trial eligibility criteria. They presented mappings from existing metadata standards (ClinVar, GA4GH, NDF-RT, NCI-Thesaurus) and other community-developed ontologies (UMLS, SNOMED CT) to Clinical-Trials-Eligibility-RDF. Through ontology matching, the authors also mapped terms in the Clinical-Trials-Eligibility-RDF to existing EHR vocabularies, including clinical statements, conditions, and procedure codes in L

### Assessment of Eligibility

# Construct

- Eligibility assessment, the act of evaluating whether or not a patient has certain characteristics that are considered as inclusion criteria for a clinical trial. 
- Patient eligibility, the factors that allow someone to participate in a clinical study (inclusion criteria). 
- Eligibility assessment criteria, a set of criteria for evaluating an individuals in a study based on criteria defined to the study. 
- Individual eligibility, the fact of being eligible in a study due to criteria defined to the study. 
- Trial-level eligibility, a score given to a study participant after the eligibility assessment. 
- Eligible subject, a patient who meets all the eligibility assessment criteria.

Previous studies have illustrated that the differential responses of various coccolithophores to a wide range of different conditions can determine their distribution in the oceans. Many coccolithophore species are distributed in the upper 150 m of the surface waters, where the pH is between~8.2 and~8.4. In this study, the physiological and behavioural responses of two coccolithophore species Emiliania huxleyi (EU218) and Emiliania huxleyi (CCMP1516) to their preferred growth temperature (12 - C to 20 - C), the pH values in their favoured growth conditions (pH = 7.8 to 8.3), and the co-existing nutrients of the two species (nitrate/phosphate) in the seawater were measured. It was found that the E. huxleyi (CCMP1516) species performed better than the E. huxleyi (EU218) strain in most of the tested environments. Moreover, E. huxleyi (CCMP1516) showed significantly higher photosynthetic activity under low nitrate conditions. Both of the tested species showed a higher motility rate in the seawater than in 25 mm artificial seawater, which might relate to the pH levels and the nitrate/phosphate ratios in the seawater. In the absence of phosphate, both strains of E. huxleyi showed a positive response to the higher temperature, however, the E. huxleyi strain EU218 showed a higher motility in 37 - C seawater than 30 - C seawater, while the E. huxleyi strain CCMP1516 did not. Our results can be helpful to further illuminate the physiological and behavioural responses of two coccolithophores to environmental stresses.

#### Preparation & Training
If you want to make sure that you understand all of the important details about Precision medicine and data science with genomics in the context of clinical studies and trials, this tutorial is for you. In particular, you will learn:
- how to interpret the data from a clinical study or trial,
- how to create genomic annotations of clinical studies, and
- how to run queries on large clinical study or trial datasets to understand the details of a dataset or to identify biological implications that are relevant to clinical studies or trials.
The Genomic Annotation for Clinical Studies Tutorial will guide you through the process of identifying biological data points in a clinical study or trial. You will learn techniques for identifying genes, proteins, chemicals, diseases, and tissues for datasets in Clinical Studies.

# Discussion of Precision-medicine-related data in the context of clinical trials
There are a variety of data types important to clinical trials for which a researcher could wish to generate a Genomic Annotation:
- Gene-specific data: from microarrays, sequencing studies, or other experiments. These genes may be associated with tissue enrichment or drug effects 
- Phenotype data: the phenotype of each cohort member 
- Phenotype-or gene-specific data: from microarrays, sequencing studies, or other experiments. These genes may be associated with tissue enrichment or drug sensitivity 
- Clinical data: from medical history, clinical assessment, or lab results 
- Disease-specific data: patient samples were derived from individuals with a specific disease and so the annotations of variants in a patient's genome may be associated with disease symptoms 
- Drug-specific data: patient samples were derived from individuals receiving a specific drug treatment and so the annotations of variants in a patient's genome may be associated with treatment response. In this tutorial we will explain how to make annotations when the data come from a drug treatment and the annotated entity is not the drug itself. 

# Precision medicine and Data Science with Genomics in the context of Clinical Studies
We begin by selecting the clinical study of interest in NHGRI Clinical Studies

<EOD> Anterior versus posterior circulation brain injury and outcome—reply.
In Reply: 
 
Dr. Broderick rightly queries the use of the term “acute stroke unit” in our article on the benefits of stroke units.1 Although the focus of our paper was the impact of acute units on patient outcome, we did not propose that their use be exclusively confined to them. In fact, we advocated for increased availability of stroke units across all hospitals. The current article by Dr. Broderick and colleagues demonstrates the importance of this in countries with limited health care infrastructure. Of note, the benefit of stroke units on patient outcome is comparable with similar unit structures in the United States,2 suggesting that specialized units, regardless of complexity are beneficial. 
 
However, to further advance the management of ischemic stroke requires the creation of more acute stroke units.2 A comprehensive care unit is not limited to the management of ischemic stroke. Ischemic stroke is the most common cause of neurological disability and mortality. It comprises more than 80% of all stroke cases. The remainder are hemorrhagic stroke. In fact, because stroke is primarily a disorder of the elderly, it is also associated with co-morbidities typically of the elderly such as diabetes, heart, and lung disease, all of which may benefit from comprehensive services. The development of an appropriate infrastructure to support these services is fundamental for providing optimal patient care. 
 
Additional issues include the need to focus on regional infrastructure to care for ischemic stroke. We can no longer rely on a system where a patient in most locations on the globe (outside a capital city) has limited to no access to a neurologist.3,4 For example, the current United States Health Care Policy Initiative for Stroke Care, a multidisciplinary federal health care initiative designed to improve stroke care,5 focused mainly on urban settings while ignoring rural settings. Stroke is responsible for 10% of deaths and 13% of all serious long-term disabilities due to trauma, and most cases are treated in community hospitals. These settings are also disproportionately found in poor and underserved communities. In the last 20 years, many of these hosp

<EOD> In vitro comparison of the cellular compatibility of two new calcium phosphate bone cement formulations with three commercially available products.
PURPOSE
This study compared the cellular interactions of new calcium phosphate bone cement with three other commercially available calcium phosphate cements (Cosmox, Fusio, and F2) using four cellular compatibility assays.


MATERIALS AND METHODS
Human monocyte U937 cell line and human primary osteoblasts were tested for cellular viability (3-{4, 5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl}-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide (MTT) assay) by direct mixing with the cements, proliferation (3-(4, 5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2-5-diphenyl tetrazolium (MTT) assay) using conditioned media after cement exposure, and cellular migration (wound healing assay) using cement/cells/membrane inserts.


RESULTS
Commercially available cements caused rapid cell death in direct mixing and conditioned culture (p < 0.05). Both new calcium phosphate formulations, however, supported human monocyte U937 cell line proliferation (p < 0.05). All calcium phosphate cements caused cellular migration delay (p < 0.05) when human primary osteoblast cells were exposed to cements/conditioned media.


CONCLUSIONS
These findings suggest that the inclusion of biological components within bone repair products may be crucial in the selection of the calcium phosphate cement.<EOD> Intermolecular Interactions Regulate Diffusion near Chain-like DNA Surfaces

# Discussion:
The 3-point scale used in this challenge corresponds to a 3-dimensional representation of the probability of eligibility; the more favorable the conditions, the more probably the patient would be eligible for the trial. 
Some examples:

`Trial-level eligibility: 1) Would consider referring this patient to this clinical trial upon further investigation.` means the patient is eligible.

`Trial-level eligibility: 0) Would not refer this patient for this clinical trial.` means the patient is not eligible.

`Trial-level eligibility: 2) Highly likely to refer this patient for this clinical trial.` means the patient is highly likely to be eligible.

In some settings, a 2-point scale could work better, e.g.:

`Trial-level eligibility: 0) Patient would not be eligible for clinical trial.` means the patient is not eligible.

`Trial-level eligibility: 1) Patient would be eligible for clinical trial.` means the patient is eligible.

In addition, the following terms might be useful to consider while assessing the eligibility:

1.  Exclusion criteria: Reasons for a patient to be ruled out from a clinical trial.

   1. Patients who are likely to dropout, refuse or interrupt the trial, e.g.: smokers, patients with psychiatric issues. A patient meeting an exclusion criterion must not be eligible for a trial.
   2. Patients who are likely to be inharmful to themselves, others or the trial, e.g.: pregnant patients, patients with uncontrolled diseases. A patient meeting an exclusion criterion must not be eligible for a trial. 
   3. Patients participating in other clinical trials. The reason is that these patients are likely to be in harmful situations during the whole duration of the clinical trial.

2. Inclusion criteria: Reasons for a patient to be eligible for a clinical trial.

<EOD> Acute, sub-lethal and lethal responses of fishes to heat and hypoxia. A meta-analysis and a new approach for evaluating risks to aquatic vertebrates

The effects of climate change are complex due to the high diversity of ecosystems and the range of species within each ecosystem which can be negatively impacted. For example, in a warming climate freshwater temperatures may rise to levels that, in addition to affecting species physiology, may also result in hypoxia (lower-than-normal oxygen levels). Hypoxia can occur in natural environments even without anthropogenic intervention, but more frequently hypoxia occurs along with increased temperatures. We use meta-analysis, generalized and linear-mixed models to evaluate the independent and combined effects of thermal and hypoxia stress on 12 indices of fitness and survival from 19 experimental studies. Specifically, we tested the effect of hypoxia alone, warming alone and the combined warming and hypoxia on fishes. Our meta-analyses suggest that both thermal and hypoxia stress individually impact survival and fitness of fishes and that the combined stress reduces fitness even further than thermal or hypoxia stress alone. However, the responses vary greatly depending on the level of exposure, species ecology, temperature and the way that survival and fitness were measured. Overall, physiological data is more consistent and interpretable than survival and/or fitness data alone. We propose a new method based on meta-analytical results to estimate how temperature thresholds for specific responses of fishes in hypoxic environments change with respect to the mean background conditions. This new approach enables to assess realistically the probability that certain temperatures and oxygen levels will be exceeded in natural environments in a future climate, and to estimate the magnitude of associated risks to ecosystems and biota.The rapid warming of Earth's climate has dramatic effects on the survival and fitness of species 1,2 . The negative impact of climate change is being felt by fishes around the world 3,4 and is the most important threat to tropical fishes, resulting in a rapid shift of biological processes and faunal composition 5,6 . ### Think critically
As a programmer, you should spend time and effort thinking through each and every line of code to check its correctness and elegance, especially your first time trying out a new algorithm. You probably know of many people who are smart and very good at solving many algorithmic problems. If you ever need a helping hand, try to reach out to such people. Besides, do not overlook your friends, family, and anyone who may be able to help you, as they just might have the answer you need! It is better to ask your friends. ### Practice
To become a competent programmer is a long and winding road. But it is essential to practice and practice, and then practice some more. Your coding experience will only improve with time. 2113.output:
<EOD> Numerical Approach to Dry Deposition of Aerosols in a Coupled Aerosol-Atmospheric Model with Emphasis on Surface-Layer and Boundary-Layer Aerosols

A theoretical and numerical study is presented to examine dry deposition of aerosols on land. A coupled aerosol-atmospheric model, including four processes, dry deposition, vertical diffusion, horizontal diffusion and gravitational settling is considered. Atmospheric boundary layer and surface-layer flows over homogeneous and smooth ground surface are examined. Surface roughness due to bare ground and vegetation, and the impact of surface roughness on dry deposition velocity are also investigated. Numerical results show large difference in dry deposition velocity with the change of surface roughness. Inhomogeneous distribution of atmospheric temperature is not considered which is shown to yield a slight difference to the case with uniform temperature distribution. Large dry deposition velocities are observed at certain atmospheric wind directions. Large dry deposition velocities are also found at the beginning of the atmospheric nocturnal convective regime which results in considerable mass exchange with the land.

# Introduction
Atmospheric boundary layer (ABL) is the region from the Earth's surface to the upper limit of the atmospheric layer, and contains most of the land surface. ABL is a strongly heterogeneous atmosphere (density, temperature, humidity, turbulence, composition and aerosol distribution) characterized by a pronounced diurnal variation in horizontal stability. ABL is mainly formed by three processes: (1) the buoyancy produced in the surface layer; (2) the turbulence induced by the horizontal shear of wind and (3) the turbulence induced due to the vertical shear induced by surface-layer, valley-/canyon-scale topography. The vertical temperature structure and the atmospheric flow profiles of ABL are strongly influenced by the physical properties of the surface layer. Under stable conditions, the ABL is in a quasi-neutral state, and hence the near-surface turbulence is weak. The ABL contains a number of sub-layers. The lowest layer is the surface layer (also called the mixing layer) which has the highest surface value among all ABL sub-layers. As depth increases, the temperature

<EOD> Sensorimotor Deficiencies in Parkinson's Disease: Inability to Use Memory of Unilateral Perturbation to Prevent Falling
Falls are common in people with Parkinson's disease (PD). Although sensorimotor impairments have been implicated in the risk of falls, we show them to be insufficient. Our purpose was to quantify postural control and perturbation defenses during voluntary movements in people with PD. Sixteen people with PD and 16 age-matched healthy older adults performed rapid pointing movements with the wrist and ankle in the presence of a wrist motor-inertia perturbation on one side and an ankle motor-inertia perturbation on the other. Although the PD group exhibited no difference in performance compared with the healthy group, they exhibited no perturbation-side specificity. In response to a perturbation, the PD group used sensory signals to the same degree on both sides. As a result, they were unable to anticipate perturbations on both sides and had to rely more heavily on compensatory reflexes to attenuate movement errors.<EOD> Proton translocation by the oxalate-degrading oxaloacetase/oxalateguanine amidohydrolase from Acidomonas sp. AIU 820
The enzyme oxaloacetase/oxalateguanine amidohydrolase from Acidomonas sp. AIU 820 functions as a proton symporter, utilizing the free energy of an inwardly directed proton concentration gradient. As determined by chemical and radioactive assays, the stoichiometry of the steady-state reaction is 1 mol.oxalate reduced per mol.of oxaloacetase. A 22,000-g supernatant fraction was isolated from cells grown in oxalate medium, and this fraction consisted of 20% oxaloacetase activity and greater than 90% of the total activity of another oxalate metabolizing enzyme, oxalateguanine amidohydrolase. <EOD> A Comparison of the Antioxidant and Oxygen Uptake Capacity of Virgin and Vegetable Oils

This study investigates the oxygen uptake capacity (OUC) and antioxidant capacity of virgin olive oil, walnut oil, hazelnut oil, olive oil, sunflower oil, palm oil, soybean oil, olive pomace oil, and peanut oil. Total phenol content (TPC) and 2,2-diphenyl-1-picryl-hydrazyl (DPPH) radical scavenging ability were measured to determine antioxidant capacity. Oil peroxide level, hydroperoxide, and p-anisidine values were analyzed for the determination of the oxidative stability of the oil samples. The results showed that TPC and DPPH radical scavenging ability, OUC values, and oxidation parameters of olive, hazelnut, and walnut were higher than those of the other oil samples. Hazelnut oil has the highest free radical scavenging and TPC, whereas the highest OUC is seen in hazelnut oil which was considered as the most potent free radical scavenger of the oil samples.

# Introduction
Free radicals are the products of normal metabolic processes in our bodies as well as the consequence of our exposure with chemical carcinogens and other environmental factors. <EOD> Complementary and alternative medicine use in the USA: data from the 2007 National Health Interview Survey
OBJECTIVE
The objective of this paper is to provide a comprehensive overview of the complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) market and use in the population through analysis of the 2007 National Health Interview Survey (NHIS) data.


METHODS
The objective of this paper is to provide a comprehensive overview of the complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) market and use in the population through analysis of the 2007 National Health Interview Survey (NHIS) data. This study used data from NHIS to describe the current patterns of CAM use in the United States. A total of 21,974 adults in the United States participated in NHIS as it relates to CAM issues in 2007.


RESULTS
Over the past decade, CAM practitioner visits have more than tripled and the percentage of adults reporting use of CAM has increased from 34% to 52%. The most commonly used modality was herbal remedies or vitamin/mineral supplements, with 93% reporting use, over the past 12 months.


CONCLUSION
The trend towards CAM use in the past decade has been increasing at an almost exponential rate. Effector cytokines, such as interleukin-1 (IL-1) potentiate tumour-induced angiogenesis. We have previously shown that 1,25(OH)D3 inhibits IL-1-induced angiogenesis by inducing IL-1Ra. Using a rat renal proximal tubule cell (RPTC) line, we measured the effects of 1,25(OH)D3 on IL-1Ra expression by Northern blot analysis. 1,25(OH)D3 induced IL-1Ra mRNA expression in a dose- and time-dependent manner. This induction correlated with the enhancement of IL-1Ra production found by ELISA. We then studied the effects of calcitriol on IL-1Ra expression in human colon cancer cells. The LS 174 T and HT-29 human epithelial cell lines were used. In contrast to RPTCs, 1,25(OH)D3 did not induce IL-1Ra expression in these cells. Hospital readmission is costly with substantial impact on the child's family and health care services. Yet, factors associated with hospital readmission are not clear and few studies have directly evaluated the effectiveness of interventions targeted at vulnerable children.


PURPOSE
To determine the effectiveness of interventions to prevent hospital readmissions, and to identify program and family characteristics associated with the effectiveness of interventions to prevent hospital readmissions


METHODS
A systematic review of published and unpublished literature. The 2005 Cochrane Intervention Review's definition of intervention to prevent hospital readmission was used as the initial step in identifying relevant interventions. Databases searched included the PubMed Medline and Medline In-Process & Other Non-Indexed Citations, Cumulative Index of Nursing and Allied Health Literature, and Cochrane database. Search terms included "hospital readmission" and "child" or related terms. Studies were also identified through the personal library of the authors, review of reference lists in pertinent texts, and consultation with expert librarians.


RESULTS
Following the initial search, 663 articles were reviewed resulting in identification of 13 studies that met inclusion/exclusion criteria.


CONCLUSIONS
In comparison to control patients, intervention (intensified home services) resulted in significant reductions in readmissions (P < .0001) among high-risk hospitalized children. However, because of few studies conducted, and conflicting findings, recommendations cannot be made regarding the most effective program for preventing readmission for individual conditions or patient groups.<EOD> The impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and emerging variants on clinical trials of COVID-19 vaccine candidates

OBJECTIVE
To assess the associations of diagnostic imaging before lumbar microdiscectomy and improved functional outcomes one-year post-surgery.


METHODS
Retrospective review of 1373 patients who underwent lumbar microdiscectomy was performed. A total of 665 (49%) patients underwent diagnostic imaging prior to surgery. The use of imaging was categorized as computed tomography, magnetic resonance imaging, or both. Independent associations between use of diagnostic imaging and post-surgical outcomes were assessed using multivariable logistic regression models.


RESULTS
In multivariable logistic regression models, patients who underwent diagnostic imaging prior to surgery were more likely to undergo postoperative radiation therapy (odds ratio (OR)=2.43; 95% CI: 1.24 - 4.81) and were less likely to have improved pain and functional status one-year post-surgery (OR=0.22; 95% CI: 0.12 - 0.42). In sensitivity analyses restricted to patients who were classified as American Society of Anesthesiologist (ASA) performance status 1 (ASA=1) or 2 (ASA=2) the association with improved pain and functional status one-year post-surgery was non-significant.


CONCLUSIONS
The use of diagnostic imaging prior to surgery was associated with poorer postoperative pain and functional outcomes in patients who underwent lumbar microdiscectomy. The lack of significance in this relationship in ASA1 and ASA=2 patients further suggests that pain and physician decisions surrounding the use of diagnostic imaging were correl

## Sprints and racewalking: sprinting
Exercise Submission Information

Instructions 

In this assignment you will compare a number of different racewalking gaits.

Racewalking is a competitive sport and is a legal walking method that is used in a number of different endurance competitions. When racewalking, a person can not take more than two steps per meter or use a running gait. Racewalkers are allowed to bounce and swing their arms, but not lift their leading knee to make a stride. Racewalking is the slowest officially sanctioned form of locomotion. The first racewalker to break the 3-hour barrier in 2008 was a Chinese man that took 2:59.03 to complete a marathon. A record that has not been broken since! This man held the record until a Belgian man broke it in 2011. The fastest marathon racewalking in history was a Polish man that used a different running style and was credited with running a marathon in 2:05:09. However, a Czech competitor disputed this claim because the man broke 23 rules during the race, thereby removing him from the record books. 
Olympic long-distance racewalking began in the 1980s and was added to the program in 200m races. Men and women competed in both 20km and 50km races. Racewalking is now one of the most popular sports in Russia, and in fact some Russian cities claim more than half of the world's top 100 racewalkers.
 

1) Record of all racewalkers whose race you are about to model. Race length and average speed (km/hour). Use information such as you see in this table to create a vector with the following format:

race
 race.record 
 race.speed

2) Create another (third) vector for the corresponding parameters for sprinters from the following table information as the vector:

sprint
 sprint.record 
 sprint.speed

3) Model these data to find the relationships between the race, race

# 5.1.7 Eligibility Criteria

# 5.1.8
<EOD> Comparison of the efficacy and safety of tegoprazan and vonoprazan in the treatment of erosive gastroesophageal reflux disease: a matched cohort study

Background: This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of tegoprazan and vonoprazan (VPZ)-based triple therapy for treating patients with erosive gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).Methods:We retrospectively reviewed 300 patients with GERD who were enrolled in the GERD registry and had been treated with tegoprazan and VPZ (with and without co-administration of proton pump inhibitors or vonoprazan) for a minimum of 4 weeks between December 1, 2018 and November 30, 2021. Patient characteristics and clinical parameters were collected to assess medication efficacy and safety based on patient records. Results: The most frequently used proton pump inhibitor was rabeprazole in the tegoprazan group. Cigarette smoking and alcohol abuse were negligible in both groups. Patients treated with tegoprazan plus PPI showed a higher proportion of complete symptom resolution (CSR, 53.1% vs 40.0%, P ¼ 0.003) and endoscopic healing (62.6% vs 54.9%, P ¼ 0.036) compared with those treated with VPZ plus PPI. Other clinical outcomes except for CSR and endoscopic healing were similar between groups. Regardless of the regimen, the endoscopic healing or CSR rates were higher in patients with Barrett's esophagus and those who had taken a high daily dose of proton pump inhibitors. Overall safety profiles were similar between groups. No major safety signals were detected. Conclusion: Treatment with tegoprazan showed potential advantages over VPZ-based trials for improving patients with GERD. Regardless of the regimen, the high Barrett's es

<issue_comment>username_30: ### Description
The `trialledit` component aims to improve the editorial experience for trial editors and trial administrators. It allows the creation of nested indented paragraphs, and the insertion of images and formatted text. All the changes are saved inside a transaction for versioning.
