<EOD> Influence of genetic background on the antigenicity of the merozoite surface protein-2 (MSP-2) of Plasmodium falciparum in a murine model.
A recombinant Plasmodium falciparum MSP-2 (Pfs25), a surface protein that elicits a potent, strain-transcendent immune response, was evaluated for its potential as a vaccine in a murine model, to discriminate if the mouse antipathogen humoral response was cross-reactive for the P. falciparum 3D7 MSP-2. The ability of the recombinant antigen to induce a humoral immune response in a number of inbred strains, was examined. Significant, diverse cross-reactive IgG antibody responses were seen in all but three murine strains. There was no statistical correlation between the humoral antibody response in BALB/c and either the C3H or NZW strains, whereas C3H and NZW strains were discordant. The response of all mouse strains examined did not appear to be strain-dependent and were comparable to the response seen in P. berghei-infected rats. These results suggest that the P. falciparum MSP-2 is more conserved than was previously expected.<EOD> The Role of S-Nitrosoproteins in Cell Death and Protection.
S-Nitrosylation is a well-studied post-translational modification that plays a critical role in many physiological processes to preserve cellular homeostasis. Dysregulations in S-nitrosylation networks are associated with neurodegenerative diseases, such as Alzheimer's and Parkinson's diseases, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, depression and ageing. S-nitrosylation of enzymes of the tricarboxylic acid cycle (TCA) cycle leads to metabolic reprogramming and provides the basis for an alternative metabolic theory of neurodegenerative diseases. OBJECTIVE
To observe the influence of sodium selenite on the expression of the cell surface markers Ly-6C and F4/80 in the liver and lungs of intrahepatic cholestatic rats, which was the model of systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS), and to probe the possible mechanism in protecting the tissues of SIRS rats through sodium selenite.


METHODS
Twenty-four SD rats were employed. The model of SIRS was reproduced in 16 rats, while 6 of the rats received the sham operation. After 24 h, the rats were intraperitoneally injected with sodium selenite at a dose of 1 ml/kg per day for 4 times. The pathological examinations were performed at the fifth day in rat liver and lung tissues. Then, the serum was collected to detect the levels of alanine transaminase (ALT), aspartate transaminase (AST), total bilirubin (TBIL), total protein (TP), globulin (GLO), blood urea nitrogen, and alanine transaminase deaminase through biochemical analyzer. The expression of the cell surface markers Ly-6C and F4/80 in liver and lung tissues was detected by immunohistochemistry and Western blot.


RESULTS
As compared with the sham operation-operated rats, the model of SIRS rats exhibited obvious histological and biochemical abnormal manifestations. Sodium selenite injection alleviated the above symptoms and abnormal manifestations in the model of SIRS rats. Western blot and immunohistochemical analyses showed that in rat liver tissues the expression levels of Ly-6C and F4/80 were enhanced (P < 0.05, P < 0.01 vs. the model). Suggestive evidence was obtained from a detailed study of the spectral behavior of a family of natural product intermediates that the 9-epimers of the fusidane (C36-C41) fatty acids and their tetrahydropyran derivatives can be expected to possess strong electronic absorptions in the vis-NIR region and to be nonfluorescent. The feasibility of such nonfluorescent structures should enable their total synthesis in conjunction with direct comparison with 9-isomers of known absorption and fluorescence properties. From an overview of the structural and spectral properties of the 9-tritols, it was determined that a total synthesis approach would require the stereoselective enolization of the C-9 epoxide to an enantiomeric alcohol with the 9β conformation. With stereoselective methods to the fore, direct comparison of a 9β-hydroxy and 9β,10α-dihydroxy C41 fatty acid would afford the definitive answer to the question of structure-fluorescence-lifetime relationship in the 9-, 10-, and 12-isomers. The synthesis of the proposed precursor compounds 21 and 22 is reported in this paper. The 9β-hydroxylation of the enantiomeric 9β,10α-epoxyfusidic acid 23 was achieved using a combination of the asymmetric catalysts Cu(OAc)(2)(diPTBP)Cl (14) and BAIBS in CH(2)Cl(2) solvent with a diastereomeric ratio greater than 90:10 in favor of the (2S, 9α) configuration. Your task is to compare a given patient note and the inclusion criteria of a clinical trial to determine the patient's eligibility. [/HEAD] <EOD> Preoperative MRI for Diagnosis and Management of Cerebrospinal Fluid Rhinorrhea After Endoscopic Endonasal Approach.
OBJECTIVE
The objective of this study is to evaluate the accuracy of preoperative magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in prediction of dural tears after endoscopic endonasal approach (EEA) for pituitary adenoma and other lesions in the nasal and paranasal sinuses. The authors then reviewed and compared MRI findings with operative results and surgical findings.


STUDY DESIGN
Retrospective case review.


METHODS
This retrospective review was conducted between January 2011 and March 2013. The study population included 58 patients who underwent preoperative MRI followed by EEA for pituitary adenoma and other tumors of the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses.


RESULTS
Preoperative MRI showed 33 (57%) cases with normal finding, 13 (22%) cases with arachnoid cyst, and 12 (21%) cases with incidental findings. The dural tear occurred in 11 (19%) cases with normal findings. Preoperative catheter drainage was not done in any of the above 11 cases although it was performed for 23 (41%) of 55 cases in which imaging study revealed dural defect or dural cyst.


CONCLUSION
Preoperative MRI shows high false positive rate compared to intraoperative and postoperative findings; thus the decision to proceed with preoperative catheter drainage, which carries its own risks, should not be made hastily without consideration of the potential negative effects.<EOD> Excessive sleepiness is strongly associated with reduced health-related quality of life in adults with sleep apnea

For the purpose of developing an efficient screening and inoculum preparation technique for fungi, we compared three different methods: tape prep (TP), potato‐dextrose‐agar‐incubation (PDF) and enrichment in Sabouraud medium (SS). Forty‐seven clinical samples containing fungi that had been isolated and grown in Sabouraud medium were analysed. After 3 days of incubation, the tape preparations were evaluated for colour, morphology and motility of the fungi. The PDF and SS procedures were evaluated for differences in the number of recovered colonies and the time required for the procedure. After 5 days of incubation, all isolates recovered by the three techniques showed good correlation with each other. Furthermore, all preparations demonstrated a high probability of recovering fungi. However, after an incubation period of 7 days, only the TP method demonstrated complete agreement with the first results. This technique showed a significant shortening of the incubation period for some species and a 20‐fold increase in the number of viable fungi. <EOD> .
The present work examines the effect of the administration of a low birth rate of vitamins A, E, and D in the diet of weaned pigs. The experiment was carried out with 580 hybrid female piglets weighing 9.7 kg. They were distributed equally in four treatments. During the first 28 d of life, all of the groups were fed with an isocaloric and isonitrogenous diet. Then, all groups were fed with the same diet, which was modified substituting for natural vitamins the synthetic vitamins A, E, and D in the following proportions: 15 g/100 kg diet; 55 g/100 kg diet; and 340 g/100 kg diet, respectively. The results reported evidence that it is possible to decrease the amount of vitamins A, E, and D in the diet of piglets without producing a negative effect on performance. On the contrary, the groups fed with low vitamin supplications gained faster over the second period, and attained a greater weight at slaughter. The groups with low levels of vitamin supplementation needed considerably lesser additions of vitamins A, E, and D during the growing period. We have shown previously that a neutral proteinase present in soluble conditioned media of human neuroblastoma cell lines, Kelly (NBL-K, C2) and SK-N-SH (NBL-SK), is neutralized by gelatin- or fibrinogen-specific alpha 2-macroglobulin. In the present study we demonstrate that the neutralization of KELLY and SK-N-SH TEP by alpha 2-macroglobulin is highly specific. We tested alpha 2-macroglobulin's ability to neutralize 2,700 purified proteases, one serine proteinase (ST-K) isolated from soluble conditioned media of Kelly cells and one of SK-N-SH cells. Neutralization of TEPs from Kelly and SK-N-SH as well as from human umbilical vein endothelial cells was obtained with alpha 2-macroglobulin purified from human plasma. The neutralization of purified ST-K with alpha 2-macroglobulin was comparable to that of KELLY and SK-N-SH TEPs. Incubation of purified alpha 2-macroglobulin with Kelly conditioned medium depleted of active ST-K and Kelly TEP resulted in a substantial increase of TEPs' catalytic activity and decreased neutralization by alpha 2-macroglobulin. The neutralization of KELLY and SK-N-SH TEP by alpha 2-macroglobulin was accompanied by the generation of a high molecular mass complex (greater than 670 kDa). It was degraded by incubation with alpha 2-anti-plasmin

# Task Description
This task is a task for training deep neural networks (DNNs) to predict the trial-level eligibility of a given patient for a clinical trial. In the process, each patient is assigned with a patient note, which reflects the actual information from a patient. The patient note is represented by a word or phrase vector. The vector is a high-dimensional, dense representation of the patient note word by word, word by word. The dimension is 100 (from the pretrained Med2vec embedding).
During the analysis of patient notes in the training trials, we realize that the number of words and phrases, i.e., words concatenated with special words, is relatively small compared to the number of words with actual information in each note. For example, the word 'BMI' appears in 581 of the 1742 patient notes (33.4%); therefore, 'BMI' should carry valuable information that is useful for predicting eligibility. We investigate whether we can incorporate knowledge from past training trials, and extract important words and phrases (and then form a vector for each) by simply observing past training trials during the training of the neural network. The DNN is then trained to predict the trial-level eligibility of the test trial based on the combination of the actual note and the extracted phrases, which we term the vectorized note (or patient note + phrases, the vector size is 1100, i.e., 100 + 1000).
For simplicity's sake, we call the vectorized note the target note (or target vector). The trial-level eligibility of the target trial is then compared with those trained in the past. 
You are expected to learn from previous training trials to predict the trial-level eligibility of the test trial. More specifically, the question that you would like to answer through the comparison with past knowledge is: can learning from previous training trials improve prediction performance for the current test trial? What part of the past training trials (i.e., the part of the words/phrases that the neural network is trained to observe and utilize) matters? How much improvement can we get from the past trials? Finally, how important might the training trials be to predict the trial level eligibility of a new trial? As an

<EOD> Conjugated linoleic acids in food sources: production, bioavailability, and health implications

As a group of fatty acids (FAs), conjugated linoleic acids (CLAs) have two conjugated double bonds, one of which is placed between one and two atoms, and the other is placed between two and three atoms, in the cis-trans configuration. CLAs have been widely found in dietary sources with the existence of cis-trans double bonds. CLA has been associated with a variety of biological effects, including anti-cancer, anti-oxidant, anti-proliferative, anti-diabetic, and anti-lipid effects. CLA is synthesized through natural biochemical pathways including rumen metabolism by intestinal microbes in dairy and meat products as well as milk products produced by cows through dietary supplementation of CLA. To date, CLA has been mainly produced from the synthesis of CLA via bacterial fermentation. It is difficult to obtain enough CLA from food sources alone, due to its low content. It is known that the conjugation of dietary FAs in ruminant products is catalyzed by the rumen bacteria. The CLA content in foods depends on the diets fed to domestic animals, including milk fat from cows, lamb, and goats, and various food products such as cheeses. The dietary intake of CLA is estimated as 0.25-0.4 g/day in a regular diet, and foods have limited and small concentrations of CLA isomers; generally, the CLA content is about 0.1% of total FAs (TFAs) in butter, 0.25% TFAs in meat, and 0.5-5% TFAs in dairy fat. Therefore, human health could be substantially improved by increasing the content of CLA in food sources, which could be accomplished by dietary recommendations, as well as the production of CLA by dietary supplementation through different CLA sources and/or fermented dairy products. The present study reviews the properties, effects, clinical studies, and mechanisms of action of CLA associated with human health and the biological conversion of

This narrowed segment of the esophagus was excised, and a second band of constriction was seen at the anterior surface of the aorta. PURPOSE
To analyze the association of human leukocyte antigen (HLA)-haplotypes and T-cell variable (TCRV) chain polymorphisms with myasthenia gravis (MG) and to determine whether HLA-restricted T cell clones derived from affected patients express TCRV chain forms that are associated with the disease.


METHODS
The TCRV chain polymorphism in patients with MG was investigated in T cells of 34 patients with MG of different severities and compared with healthy controls. To define the consequences of the TCRV141I polymorphism for the structure of the full TCRV region, a set of T-cell clones was isolated from MG patients that showed an increased number of TCRV141I-positive T cells. The association between HLA-haplotypes and TCRV genes was studied in a cohort of 145 patients with MG from different ethnic backgrounds.


RESULTS
A statistically significant association between HLA-DQA1*05, -DR*01, and -B*18 allotype and MG was found. The TCRV chain polymorphism investigated in patients with MG revealed that the TCRV gene 24/A12 was predominantly associated with the TCRV141I polymorphism. Moreover, both wild-type and homozygous TCRV24/A12 T cell clones with the TCRV141I mutation showed significantly enhanced stimulation with antigen-presenting cells when they were transduced with the full-length receptor chain compared with the wild-type TCRV24/12 receptor chain.


CONCLUSION
We describe for the first time a T-cell receptor polymorphism that is significantly associated with the autoimmune disease MG and demonstrate that such polymorphisms modify the TCR structure.<EOD> Changing patterns of HIV-1 infection from 1995 to

<EOD> Antibody response to measles, mumps and rubella vaccine in children aged 2 and 7 months at administration. Long-term kinetics of measles antibody in blood and saliva.
OBJECTIVE
To determine the antibody response to vaccination against measles, mumps and rubella in 2- and 7-month-old infants.


METHODOLOGY
137 children received the combined vaccine against measles, mumps and rubella. Venous blood and saliva samples were collected from 116 infants 6 days before vaccination, on the day of vaccination (day 0) and then at 7, 30 and 365 days after vaccination. 137 blood samples were collected from an equal number of healthy adult volunteers on the same days.


RESULTS
The rate of seroconversion one week after vaccination was significant, 100% in the group of children at 2 months of age and 100% in the group of children at 7 months of age; all the children were seropositive when the vaccine was administered. The antibody rate 365 days later was 95% in the group of children at 2 months of age and 100% in the group of children at 7 months of age, showing a slight drop in seropositivity levels for measles antibody. The levels of measles, mumps and rubella antibodies were similar in children and adults at the day of vaccination, but children's antibody levels increased significantly in the following days.


CONCLUSIONS
Administering the combined vaccine in 2- vs. 7-month-old infants results in the seroconversion of the same number of children at 1 week later only. The high levels of salivary antibodies of children at either 2 or 7 months of age suggest that this fluid is a good alternative for diagnosing immune conditions.<EOD> Role of the sialoproteins in the interaction of chicken egg lysozyme with lipid membranes and bacteria.

During 1980 to 1990, 1,033 patients with hepatic disorders (males, 721; females, 312; average age, 59) were studied by means of computed tomography (CT), including intravenous and oral-cholecystographic scanning. In 1980 and 1983, the former method was used; in 1987, oral-cholecystography was introduced; and in 1990, oral-cholecystopancreatographic scanning of the bile ducts was applied. The incidence of hepatic disorders was low in 1980 (13.0% as seen by contrast media). The incidence of liver cysts, sclerosing cholangitis, and gallbladder polyposis increased significantly (13.6%, 11.9%, 2.2%, p < 0.01) by 1983. In 1987, the incidence rate of hepatic disorders increased to 20.2%, i.e., there was a significant rise in liver cystic diseases (21.0% vs. 22.1%, p < 0.01), gallbladder polyposis (2.1% vs. 3.2%, p < 0.05) and sclerosing cholangitis (17.5% vs. 19.7%, p < 0.05), but the number of patients with cirrhosis increased by a lesser amount. The rise is significant by tendency for bile duct diseases, liver adenomas and hepatic abscess as well. These hepatic disorders are often accompanied by bile duct diseases. The findings indicate that the incidence of liver cysts increases with age. The incidence of gallbladder abnormalities

INTRODUCTION
The article presents data of a study conducted with 162 elderly persons (over 86 years old) in the Nursing Home, as to self care and dependence in activities of daily living.


AIMS
The objectives of this work were: to assess the self care competence and the dependence in activities of daily living, comparing both sets of information; to relate competence levels in the ADLs and self care, and gender; and to correlate the independence in activities of daily living and self care with the cognitive status, taking gender into account.


METHODOLOGY
To obtain the results the Barthel Index was employed to assess the ADLs and the Self-perception of Care Instrument II (ISCOPE II) was applied to evaluate the competence level in self care. Also, the MMSE was used as a cognitive indicator.


RESULTS
The sample consisted of 165 elderly people, 51% being men and 49% women. The results evidenced significant gender differences in self care and ADLs (p0.0). Regarding the relationship between competence in ADLs, in self care, and cognitive status, no such correlation was found.


DISCUSSION
Significant gender differences in functional self care were identified. These differences were not found in relation to cognitive status. A 29-year-old women initially showed features of acquired aplastic anemia (AA) and was treated with oral prednisolone (PSL) and mercaptopurine for 6 months, but her hematological status worsened. We treated her with PSL, azathioprine, ciclosporin A (CsA), and danazol (DZ), and achieved complete remission of pancytopenia. After stopping ciclosporin A and danazol, her hematological abnormalities developed progressively. At 24 months after the discontinuation of CsA and DZ, her bone marrow was hypercellular with trilineage hematopoiesis and with > 80% megakaryocytes. There were no signs of immune-mediated aplastic anemia or paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria either clinically or morphologically. At the age of 36, she experienced acute hepatitis, and her hematological abnormalities increased again. Treating hematological abnormalities with PSL, a new agent of DMARD, resulted in complete remission. <EOD> .
It has been proposed to determine, in a number of studies, whether the presence of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) in the pediatric patient is a risk factor for laryngeal lesions such as vocal cord dysfunction (VCD). The review of the current literature provides us with two theories: a relationship between the chronic inflammation of the larynx that is the pathological finding in patients with GERD and the pathophysiology of VCD and an excessive number of reflux episodes in patients with GERD. The evidence of a relationship is contradictory and the causal mechanism for this relationship is very weak. The review of the existing literature does not allow us to conclude if VCD is a GERD complication or if GERD is a subclinical manifestation of VCD. We have performed an epidemiological study on a pediatric hospital population with the objective of determining the relationship between the presence of GERD and an extra-esophageal affectation with a laryngeal alteration. The aim was to determine whether there exists a relationship between GERD and VCD and the pathophysiological mechanism. Among our 188 patients with proven GERD, ten patients (5.3%) were diagnosed with VCD. The majority of these were adolescent male patients diagnosed with symptomatic disease (esophagitis and/or VCD and/or dysphagia). Therefore, we may infer that the presence of GERD in the pediatric patients is not a risk factor for the development of laryngeal pathology, but rather an associated pathology.<EOD> The Impact of Surgical Factors, Neurological Severity, and Medical Comorbities on Flap Failure.

To date no study has evaluated the use of laminar ventilation with tidal volume larger than 4 ml/kg ideal body weight. Ten infants, aged 1‐5 days were anaesthetised, mechanically ventilated and enrolled in the study. A flow, pressure and volume sensor were inserted into the endotracheal tube. <EOD> Antimicrobial agent susceptibility: a comparison of Mueller-Hinton agar and a chemically defined medium for clinical isolates.
The in vitro susceptibility of organisms to 31 antimicrobial agents was evaluated on Mueller-Hinton agar and 10 ml chemically defined medium (CDM) inoculated in test tube cultures. Organisms included 224 gram-negative isolates and 1,049 gram-positive organisms from a general hospital clinical microbiology laboratory. The comparison of susceptibility patterns on Mueller-Hinton agar with CDM was determined by calculating a susceptible, intermediate, resistant, and susceptible plus intermediate susceptibility ratio by using the two methods. The ratio for each antimicrobial agent in each organism group was statistically tested for a significant bias by using the chi 2 statistic. Significant differences in susceptibility ratios were found when data for all organisms, gram-negative organisms, or gram-positive organisms were examined. The overall significance level was P = 0.0001. No single causative agent was responsible for the shift in susceptibility ratios.<EOD> EFFECTS OF RESISTANCE EXERCISE TRAINING ON BLOOD PRESSURE IN HYPERTENSIVE OLDER ADULTS: A CLUSTER ANALYSIS
